questions.question: Which of the following culture media is used to differentiate other E.coli species from E.coli O157 : H7?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Sorbitol MacConkey agar:   Sorbitol MacConkey agar is a selective and differential culture medium commonly used to isolate and differentiate E. coli O157:H7 from other E. coli species. E. coli O157:H7 is a pathogenic strain that does not ferment sorbitol, whereas most other E. coli strains do.   The agar contains sorbitol as the fermentable carbohydrate source, along with bile salts and crystal violet, which inhibit the growth of Gram-positive bacteria and most Gram-negative bacteria other than E. coli.   When E. coli O157:H7 is inoculated on Sorbitol MacConkey agar, it appears as colorless colonies, indicating that it does not ferment sorbitol. In contrast, other E. coli species that can ferment sorbitol will produce pink colonies due to the acid production from sorbitol fermentation. Incorrect Options: Option A - Mannitol salt agar: It is used to isolate and differentiate Staphylococcus aureus (yellow color) from S. epidermidis (no color change). Option B - Xylose lysine deoxycholate agar: It is used to isolate and differentiate Salmonella and Shigella species based on their ability to ferment xylose and lactose and produce characteristic colonies. Option D - CLED medium: Cystine Lactose Electrolyte Deficient is used to isolate and differentiate urinary microbes.

questions.question: Which of the following agents is classified as a category A biothreat in bioterrorism?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Anthrax:   Bioterrorism agents are categorized into three levels based on their potential threat to public health and national security.   Category A agents are considered the highest priority due to their high potential for mass casualties, ability to spread easily, and the potential for major public health impact.   Organisms include in bioterrorism category A are: Cat ego ryCharacteristics Examples Cat ego ry AHigh priority due to high potential for mass casualties, easy dissemination, and major public health impactAnthrax (Bacillus anthracis), Smallpox (Variola virus), Botulism (Clostridium botulinum toxin), Plague (Yersinia pestis), Tularemia (Francisella tularensis), Viral hemorrhagic fevers (e.g., Ebola, Marburg) Cat ego ry BSecond-highest priority, moderate morbidity and low mortality ratesBrucellosis (Brucella species), Q fever (Coxiella burnetii), Glanders (Burkholderia mallei), Melioidosis (Burkholderia pseudomallei), Psittacosis (Chlamydia psittaci) Cat ego ry CThird-highest priority, emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass disseminationNipah virus, Hantaviruses, Tickborne hemorrhagic fever viruses (e.g., Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus), Drug-resistant tuberculosis Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.question: A patient presented with complaints of fever for 3 days and general fatigue. Echocardiography revealed vegetations on the valves and blood culture was done. The organism in the culture showed alpha hemolysis on blood agar and was resistant to optochin and bile. Which of the following bacteria is most commonly implicated in this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Streptococcus Sanguinis:   The patients presentation is suggestive of infective endocarditis. Organisms causing infective endocarditis are: Staphylococcus aureus Coagulase-negative staphylococci (e.g., Staphylococcus epidermidis) Streptococci (Viridans streptococci and others) Enterococci Pneumococci Fastidious gram-negative coccobacilli (HACEK group) Enterobacteriaceae Pseudomonas spp. (usually in drug users) Candida species Diphtheroids   Staphylococcus aureus   Coagulase-negative staphylococci (e.g., Staphylococcus epidermidis)   Streptococci (Viridans streptococci and others)   Enterococci   Pneumococci   Fastidious gram-negative coccobacilli (HACEK group)   Enterobacteriaceae   Pseudomonas spp. (usually in drug users)   Candida species   Diphtheroids   Cuture showing alpha-hemolysis on blood agar with resistance to optochin and bile is suggestive of the streptococcus viridans group, a normal flora of mouth and upper respiratory tract.   Streptococcus sanguinis, formerly known as Streptococcus sanguis, is a Gram-positive facultative anaerobic coccus species of bacteria and a member of the Viridans Streptococcus group.   S. sanguinis is a normal inhabitant of the healthy human mouth, particularly in dental plaque. It can cause infective endocarditis (IE) when it gains access to the bloodstream, typically through dental procedures. IE is a serious infection that can damage the heart valves. The patient, in this case, has several risk factors for IE, including fever, fatigue, and vegetation on the heart valves.   Other members of streptococcus viridans are S. mitis, S. mutans, and S. salivarus.   Staphylococcus aureus   Coagulase-negative staphylococci (e.g., Staphylococcus epidermidis)   Streptococci (Viridans streptococci and others)   Enterococci   Pneumococci   Fastidious gram-negative coccobacilli (HACEK group)   Enterobacteriaceae   Pseudomonas spp. (usually in drug users)   Candida species   Diphtheroids Incorrect Options: Option A- Mycoplasma: Mycoplasma are causative organism of meningitis, encephalitis, GBS, Steven Johnson's syndrome, and carditis. They are cultured on PPLO agar and show a fried egg colonies. Option C - Enterococcus: Enterococcus are gram-positive facultative anaerobic cocci that show alpha-hemolysis on blood agar. Option D - Streptococcus Agalactiae: The gram-positive coccus Streptococcus agalactiae, generally known as group B streptococcus or GBS is a facultative anaerobe that shows beta-hemolysis on agar.

questions.question: A patient has complaints of fever with a mild headache associated with some difficulty in swallowing. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils which bleeds on scraping the lesion. A sample is taken from the exudate and a gram stain is done, which is as shown below. What is the organism associated with the disease?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Corynebacterium Diphtheria:   The patient's presentation is suggestive of diphtheria caused by Corynebacterium diphtheria.   The gram staining shows gram-positive bacilli with a characteristic appearance resembling a Chinese letter (V or L shaped) or cuneiform arrangement, and the ends show metachromatic granules, giving it a club-shaped appearance.   Corynebacterium diphtheria primarily infects the throat and produces a toxin (diphtheria toxin) that causes exudative pharyngitis and membranous tonsillitis. It is a pseudomembrane because it bleeds on, peeling it off. Incorrect Options: Option A and B - Parvovirus and HHV6: Both the options represent the virus, lacking the cell wall and do not show gram staining. Option D - Beta hemolytic streptococci: Streptococci pyogenes is a beta-hemolytic streptococci, it is gram-positive cocci that occur in pairs or chains. It can cause tonsillopharyngitis, acute otitis media, pneumonia, skin and soft-tissue infections.

questions.question: A patient was diagnosed with TB and while testing for resistance he was found to be resistant to Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Amikacin, and levofloxacin. What is this type of TB called?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Extensively drug-resistant TB:   This kind of TB is called Extensively drug-resistant TB (XDR-TB).   It is resistant to first-line drugs isoniazid and rifampicin, along with resistance to one of the fluoroquinolones (levofloxacin) and one injectable (amikacin). Incorrect Options: Option A - Poly-drug resistant TB: This includes resistance to more than 1 first-line drug other than both rifampicin and isoniazid. Option B - Multi-drug sensitive TB: This type of TB is resistant to Isoniazid and Rifampicin with or without resistance to other first-line drugs. Option D - Rifampicin-resistant TB: As the name suggests, this type of TB is resistant to Rifampicin.

questions.question: In a resource-limited setting, what diagnostic method can be utilized to identify the condition when there is a visible painless hardened genital ulcer following unprotected sexual activity, as reported by a truck driver?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Dark Field Microscopy:   The patient's presentation of a painless, indurated genital ulcer with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse is suggestive of syphilis caused by Treponema pallidum.   It can be seen in a low-resource setting by examining clinical specimens from the ulcer under dark field microscopy. It enables the direct viewing of the spirochetes in the samples, which is especially helpful when an active ulcer is present.   Using a dark field microscope, which illuminates the material with tangential or oblique light, the motile spirochetes can be observed as dazzling, silver-white, or golden-yellow corkscrew-like structures on a dark backdrop. Incorrect Option: Option B - Fluorescent treponema antibody absorption (FTA-ABS): FTA-ABS is a serological test used to detect antibodies against Treponema pallidum. It is not used for direct visualization of the organism and requires a laboratory setup for testing. Option C - Venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test: The VDRL test is also used to detect syphilis. It works by detecting antibodies that the body makes in case of Treponema pallidum infection and requires a laboratory setup for the test. Option D - Treponema pallidum immobilization (TPI) test: A specialized serological test called the TPI test is performed to validate the presence of Treponema pallidum antibodies in the blood and requires a laboratory setup for the test.

questions.question: A 21-year-old girl who presented with multiple beefy-red painless ulcers over the vulval region is diagnosed with granuloma inguinale. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Klebsiella Granulomatis:   Klebsiella granulomatis, a gram-negative bacteria, is the causative organism for granuloma inguinale, also known as Donovanosis.   Granuloma inguinale is a chronic sexually transmitted disease in which painless, beefy-red ulcers develop in the genital and inguinal regions. Incorrect Options: Option A - Chlamydia Trachomatis: Chlamydia trachomatis can causes diseases like trachoma, ophthalmia neonatorum, non-gonococcal urethritis, and lymphogranuloma venereum. Option C - Haemophilus Ducreyi: Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, which is painful genital ulcers. Option D - Herpes Simplex Virus 2: Herpes simplex virus 2 causes painful genital ulcers with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, meningitis, and encephalitis..

questions.question: A farmer with a history of flea bite in a godown presents with the features of high fever, painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, vomiting and diarrhea and hypotension. Smears prepared from the discharge of these swellings revealed bacteria with bipolar staining. Which stain will help in the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Wayson's Stain:   The patient's presentation of high fever, severe inguinal lymphadenopathy, nausea, vomiting, and hypotension, as well as a history of a flea bite suggestive of bubonic plague caused by Yersinia pestis.   Yersinia pestis is a gram-negative bacteria that has the ability to exhibit bipolar staining, giving it a safety pin appearance when stained with Wayson stain. Incorrect Options: Option A - Neisser Stain: It is used for staining the volutin granules of Corynebacterium diphtheriae, spirillum, and Gardnerella. Option C - Albert's Stain: It is also used for staining the volutin granules of Corynebacterium diphtheriae, spirillum, and Gardnerella. Option D. McFadyean's Reaction: It is a reaction characterized by an amorphous purple capsule surrounding blue bacilli (polychrome methylene blue stain)used for the diagnosis of anthrax.

questions.question: A patient presented with meningitis, and the CSF sample was subjected to gram staining, which appeared in the microscopic image below. Which of the following is true of the organism?
questions.solution: Correct Option D - α-hemolytic and lanceolate-shaped:   The most common bacterium responsible for meningitis are Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, H. influenzae, Listeria, streptococcus agalactiae, and E. coli.   The above given microscopic image shows gram-positive cocci arranged in the chain. Hence, they are likely to be Streptococci pneumoniae.   Streptococcus pneumoniae is a lanceolate-shaped, gram-positive, capsulated diplococci that is bile soluble.   It shows α-hemolysis on blood agar and is a catalase and oxidase-negative organism.   It ferments inulin and is optochin sensitive, differentiating from streptococcus viridans. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D for an explanation.

questions.question: A 55-year-old patient had a tooth extraction three days back. He now presents with a mass in the submandibular region, which is otherwise asymptomatic. There is no ulcer on the oral mucosa. On drainage of the discharge, it was foul-smelling with a lot of yellow granules. What is the most likely implicated pathogen?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Actinomyces Israelli:   The patient had a recent tooth extraction, and the subsequent mass in the submandibular region suggests an infection spreading from the oral cavity.   Actinomyces israelii is a commensal bacterium in the oral flora, and it can cause infection when there is a breach in the mucosal barrier, such as after dental procedures or trauma.   The presence of foul-smelling discharge and yellow granules is a characteristic finding in actinomycosis.   Actinomyces form aggregates called sulfur granules, which are composed of bacterial colonies surrounded by host tissue reaction. These granules are typically yellowish and contain tangled filamentous structures seen on microscopy. Incorrect Options: Option A - Fonsecaea Pedrosoi: It causes chromoblastomycosis, a chronic, granulomatous infectious skin disease also known as verrucous dermatitis seen in barefoot walkers. Option B - Mucor: It causes mucormycosis, which is often referred to as zygomycosis because the fungi that cause it reproduce by forming zygospores. It commonly causes pneumonia, sinusitis, and CNS infection in immunocompromised people. Option C - Histoplasma Capsulatum: Histoplasmosis is a fungal infection caused by the fungus Histoplasma capsulatum caused due to bat or bird droppings. Histoplasmosis commonly causes pneumonia and meningitis in immunocompromised people.

questions.question: Which pathogen causes attachment & effacement lesions in the intestinal mucosa, as shown in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Enteropathogenic Escherichia Coli:   Attachment - effacement lesion in intestinal mucosa is caused by EPEC (Enteropathogenic Escherichia coli).   Enteropathogenic E coli are non-invasive and do not produce enterotoxins.   EPEC has two factors: EPEC adherence factor (EAF) The chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenicity island that promotes the tight adherence characteristic of EPEC (attachment and effacement).   EPEC adherence factor (EAF)   The chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenicity island that promotes the tight adherence characteristic of EPEC (attachment and effacement).   After attachment, there is a loss of microvilli (effacement) and formation of filamentous actin pedestals or cuplike structures, causing entry of the EPEC into the mucosal cells. This attachment-effacement lesion disrupts the normal absorptive function of the intestinal epithelium and can lead to diarrhea.   EPEC adherence factor (EAF)   The chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenicity island that promotes the tight adherence characteristic of EPEC (attachment and effacement). Incorrect Options: Option A - Enterotoxigenic Escherichia Coli: Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC) ETEC is another type of Escherichia coli bacteria that causes traveler's diarrhea. It produces toxins that act on the intestinal mucosa and cause watery diarrhea by adhering to the intestinal mucosa by fimbriae called colonization factor antigens. Option C - Enteroinvasive Escherichia Coli: Enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC) is a type of Escherichia coli bacteria that invades and damages the intestinal epithelial cells, leading to an inflammatory response. It can cause dysentery-like symptoms but does not specifically cause effacement and attachment of intestinal cells like EPEC. Option D - Diffusely adherent Escherichia Coli: Diffusely adherent E. coli forms a diffuse adherence pattern on the intestinal epithelium but does not cause attachment-effacement lesions.

questions.question: A 45-year-old man developed generalized muscle spasm with arching of his back, as shown in the image, a few days after sustaining a puncture wound to his leg. The toxin responsible for this type of abdominal posturing acts by which of the following mechanisms?

options.A: Presynaptic inhibitor of GABA and glycine release
options.D: Cleavage of SNARE proteins preventing Ach release.

questions.solution: Correct Option A - Presynaptic inhibitor of GABA and glycine release:   The presentation described, with generalized muscle spasm and arching of the back after a puncture wound to his leg, is characteristic of tetanus. Tetanus is a condition caused by the neurotoxin produced by the bacterium Clostridium tetani.   The toxin responsible for tetanus, called tetanospasmin, acts by inhibiting the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters, specifically gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and glycine, at the presynaptic level in the central nervous system.   GABA and glycine are neurotransmitters that have inhibitory effects on motor neurons. Their release normally helps to regulate muscle activity and prevent excessive muscle contractions.   By inhibiting the release of GABA and glycine, the toxin disrupts the balance between excitatory and inhibitory signals in the nervous system. This leads to hyperreflexia, muscle spasms, and spastic paralysis. Incorrect Options: Options B and C are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation. Option D - Cleavage of SNARE proteins preventing Ach release: This mechanism is seen in botulism caused by botox toxin. It is produced by C.botulinum.

questions.question: BCYE medium is used to culture:
questions.solution: Correct Option D - Legionella:   BCYE (Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract) medium is a specialized culture medium that supports the growth of Legionella bacteria. Legionella is a pathogenic bacterium responsible for causing a severe respiratory illness known as Legionnaires' disease.   BCYE medium contains yeast extract, which provides essential growth factors, and activated charcoal, which helps to absorb and neutralize inhibitory substances, buffered salts maintain the appropriate pH. Legionellae grow slowly; visible colonies are usually present after 3 days of incubation. Colonies are round or flat with entire edges. They vary in color from colorless to iridescent pink or blue and are translucent or speckled. Incorrect Options: Option A - Leptospira: Leptospira is a spirochete bacterium that causes an infectious disease known as leptospirosis. It is typically cultured using specific media such as the Ellinghausen-McCullough-Johnson-Harris (EMJH) medium. Option B - Bacillus cereus: Bacillus cereus is a gram-positive bacterium that can cause food poisoning. It is cultured on mannitol egg yolk phenol red polymyxin (MYPA) agar. Option C - Campylobacter: Campylobacter is a genus of bacteria that includes species responsible for gastrointestinal infections, such as Campylobacter jejuni. Campylobacter is commonly cultured using selective media like Skirrow's, Butzlers, or Campy BAP selective medium.

questions.question: A 16-year-old boy is admitted with fever, icterus, conjunctival injection, and hematuria for 15 days. Which serological test should be done for diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Microscopic Agglutination Test:   The patient's presentation of fever, jaundice, conjunctival injection, and hematuria are classic symptoms of leptospirosis, aka hepatorenal syndrome, aka Weil's disease, caused by leptospira interrogans.   Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT) is the specific and most commonly used serological test for diagnosing Leptospirosis. It detects the presence of antibodies against Leptospira bacteria in the patient's serum. The test involves agglutination reactions between the patient's serum and a panel of different Leptospira serovars. A positive result indicates thepresence of specific antibodies and confirms the diagnosis of Leptospirosis. Incorrect Options: Option A - Widal test: It is primarily used for diagnosing typhoid fever caused by Salmonella typhi and Salmonella paratyphi. Option C - Weil-Felix reaction: The Weil-Felix reaction is a serological test that uses cross-reacting antigens from different Proteus strains to detect antibodies against rickettsial infections. Option D - Paul-Bunnell test: The Paul-Bunnell test, also known as the Monospot test, is used for the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).

questions.question: A veterinarian developed an ulcer with a central black eschar over the forearm, as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Bacillus Anthracis:   The image shows an ulcer with a central black eschar on the forearm, and the occupation of the patient is highly suggestive of cutaneous anthrax, which is caused by the bacterium Bacillus anthracis. Incorrect Options: Option A - Pseudomonas Aeruginosa: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common cause of various hospital-acquired infections like meningitis, endocarditis, and infection of burns. Option B - Yersinia Pestis: Yersinia pestis is the causative organism of plague, which typically presents with symptoms such as fever, lymphadenopathy, respiratory symptoms, and shock. Option D - Francisella Tularensis: Francisella tularensis is the bacterium responsible for tularemia, also known as rabbit fever. It primarily causes ulceroglandular tularemia, which presents with skin ulcers and swollen lymph nodes.

questions.question: Which of the following is not used as an immediate test in the screening of urinary tract infections (UTI)?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Pour Plate Culture:   Pour plate culture is not used as an immediate test in the screening of urinary tract infections (UTIs). Pour plate culture is a quantitative method used for bacterial culture and enumeration, it is not a screening test for UTI. Incorrect Options: Option B - Griess Nitrite Test: The Griess Nitrite test is a rapid screening test used to detect the presence of nitrites in the urine. Nitrites are produced by certain bacteria, such as Escherichia coli, commonly associated with UTIs. The presence of nitrites indicates the possibility of a UTI. Option C - Leukocyte Esterase Test: The leukocyte esterase test is a rapid screening test used to detect the leukocyte esterase secreted by pus cells in the urine. The presence of leukocyte esterase suggests inflammation and a possible UTI. Option D - Wet Mount Examination: The wet mount examination is a microscopic examination of urine sediment, which is used for the detection of pus cells in urine. Pyuria of more than 8 pus cells/mm3 is taken as significant for UTI.

questions.question: What is the investigation of choice for neurosyphilis?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Venereal Disease Research Laboratory (VDRL) Test:   Neurosyphilis is a form of syphilis that affects the central nervous system. The VDRL test is the most preferred screening test for syphilis, including neurosyphilis.   The VDRL test is a non-specific test that detects reagin antibodies in the serum or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of individuals with syphilis by using cardiolipin antigen extracted from beef heart. Positive VDRL results indicate the presence of antibodies, suggesting an active infection. Incorrect Options: Option B - FTA-ABS-Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption Test: The FTA-ABS test is a specific test for syphilis. It detects antibodies specifically against Treponema pallidum, the bacterium that causes syphilis. It is highly sensitive and specific for syphilis diagnosis, including neurosyphilis. However, the FTA-ABS test is not the investigation of choice specifically for neurosyphilis. Option C - RPR – Rapid Plasma Reagin Test: The RPR test is another non-specific test used for the screening and diagnosis of syphilis. It detects antibodies against cardiolipin, a substance found in the plasma. It is more expensive than VDRL. Option D - TPI – Treponema Pallidum Immobilization Test: The TPI test is a specific test used to detect antibodies against Treponema pallidum. It involves mixing patient serum with live Treponema pallidum organisms and observing for immobilization.

questions.question: Contact based isolation is employed for which of the following diseases?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - MRSA:   Contact-based isolation precautions are employed for MRSA (Methicillin Resistance Staphylococcus Aureus). These precautions prevent the transmission of the bacteria from an infected or colonized individual to others.   It includes hand washing, isolation of patients with open staphylococcal lesions, and detection of staphylococcal lesions among surgeons. Incorrect Options: Option A - Diphtheria: It requires droplet precautions because it is primarily transmitted through respiratory droplets. Droplet precautions involve wearing a mask and other appropriate measures to prevent the spread of infectious droplets. Option C - Mumps: It is also transmitted through respiratory droplets, and droplet precautions are necessary to prevent its transmission. Option D -Asthma: It is a chronic respiratory condition and not an infectious disease. It does not require isolation precautions since it is not transmissible from person to person.

questions.question: An 18 year old female presents with a severe headache and high fever of 101°F. On examination, papilloedema and nuchal rigidity was present. Gram staining of the CSF is shown below. Causative organism is
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Neisseria Meningitidis:   The clinical presentation of the patient is suggestive of meningitis.   The most common bacterium responsible for meningitis are Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, H. influenzae, Listeria, streptococcus agalactiae, and E. coli.   Gram staining of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) showing gram-negative diplococci suggests the diagnosis of Neisseria meningitidis. Incorrect Options : Option A - Haemophilus Influenzae Type B: While Haemophilus influenzae can cause meningitis, it is a gram-negative present as clusters of coccobacillus and would not appear as gram-positive diplococci on Gram staining. Option C - Streptococcus Pneumoniae: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a gram-positive bacterium that can cause bacterial meningitis, but it appears as gram-positive diplococci, giving a lanceolate shape. Option D - Listeria Monocytogenes: Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacterium associated with meningitis, but it is characterized by its rod-shaped and exhibits differential motility.

questions.question: A 12-year-old girl presents with a severe headache, photophobia, and a high fever of 101 degrees F. On examination, papilledema and nuchal rigidity was present. Kernig’ and Brudzinski's signs were positive. CSF examination shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes with the predominance of neutrophils. Gram staining of the CSF is shown below. The causative organisms are.
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Neisseria Meningitidis:   Severe headache, photophobia, high fever along with papilledema, nuchal rigidity, kernig’s sign and brudzinski sign being positive points towards bacterial meningitis.   Reduced glucose, increased protein, and leukocytosis with neutrophilic predominance point towards a bacterial cause of meningitis.   Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Haemophilus influenzae are the most common bacterial causes of meningitis in children and teenagers.   Gram staining of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) showing gram-negative diplococci suggests the diagnosis of Neisseria meningitidis. Incorrect Options: Option A - Haemophilus Influenzae: It is a gram-negative coccobacilli arranged in clusters. Option C - Streptococcus Pneumoniae: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a gram-positive bacterium that can cause bacterial meningitis, but it appears as gram-positive diplococci, giving a lanceolate shape. Option D - Listeria Monocytogens: Listeria is known to cause meningitis in extremes of age i.e. meningitis in infants and elderly. It is a gram-positive rod-shaped bacteria and exhibits differential motility.

questions.question: A 4-year-old boy presents with complaints of fever and sore throat. On examination, he has extensive cervical swelling and a well-demarcated white-gray exudative substance adherent to his oropharynx and attempts to remove this membrane result in bleeding. The parents report that all his childhood vaccines were skipped due to religious beliefs. A throat swab under Albert’s staining is as below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Diphtheria:   The clinical presentation and Albert staining showing volutin granules are suggestive of Diphtheria caused by Corynebacterium diphtheria.   It is characterized by the fever and formation of white-gray exudate that adheres tightly to the mucous membrane of the tonsils, soft palate, mouth, and sometimes larynx and bleeds on peeling, hence called pseudomembranous which can cause difficulty in breathing and swallowing.   Corynebacterium diphtheriae on Albert stain demonstrates the volutin granules, aka Babe-Ernst granule aka metachromatic granules, are stained at the end of the bacilli as shown in the image Incorrect Options: Option A - Streptococcal pharyngitis: It is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes presents with fever, cervical lymphadenopathy, erythema and swelling of pharyngeal mucosa with purulent exudate formation. Volutin granules are not characteristic of Streptococcus pyogenes. Option C - Tetanus: Tetanus is caused by the bacterium Clostridium tetani and is characterized by muscle stiffness and spasms after a penetrating injury. Option D - Pertussis: Pertussis, also known as whooping cough, is caused by the bacterium Bordetella pertussis. It is characterized by severe coughing spells and a whooping sound during inhalation.

questions.question: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of cholera toxin?

options.B: Toxin causes increased guanyl cyclase activity

questions.solution: Correct Option C - Activates adenylate cyclase:   Cholera toxin is produced by Vibrio cholerae bacteria and is responsible for the characteristic clinical features of cholera, including profuse, watery diarrhea ("rice water stools") and severe dehydration.   The cholera toxin is a bipartite consisting of two main fragments: A and B.   Fragment A (action): This fragment is responsible for the intracellular actions of the toxin. It has two fragments, A1 and A2. The A2 fragment only links the biologically active A1 fragment to the B subunit. A1 fragment activates adenylate cyclase, which is an enzyme responsible for converting ATP to cyclic AMP (cAMP). Increased levels of cAMP in the intestinal epithelial cells lead to phosphorylation of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulatory protein (CFTR), leading to increased secretion of Cl- and HCO3- ions into the intestinal lumen. This disrupts the normal osmotic balance and results in a massive efflux of water, leading to the profuse, watery diarrhea seen in cholera. A1 fragment activates adenylate cyclase, which is an enzyme responsible for converting ATP to cyclic AMP (cAMP). Increased levels of cAMP in the intestinal epithelial cells lead to phosphorylation of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulatory protein (CFTR), leading to increased secretion of Cl- and HCO3- ions into the intestinal lumen. This disrupts the normal osmotic balance and results in a massive efflux of water, leading to the profuse, watery diarrhea seen in cholera.   Fragment B (binding): It has 5 subunits, responsible for binding to the GM1 ganglioside on the surface of intestinal epithelial cells. The binding allows the toxin to be internalized into the cells, where the A fragment exerts its effects.   This fragment is responsible for the intracellular actions of the toxin. It has two fragments, A1 and A2.   The A2 fragment only links the biologically active A1 fragment to the B subunit.   A1 fragment activates adenylate cyclase, which is an enzyme responsible for converting ATP to cyclic AMP (cAMP). Increased levels of cAMP in the intestinal epithelial cells lead to phosphorylation of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulatory protein (CFTR), leading to increased secretion of Cl- and HCO3- ions into the intestinal lumen. This disrupts the normal osmotic balance and results in a massive efflux of water, leading to the profuse, watery diarrhea seen in cholera. Incorrect Options: Option A - Inhibit elongation factor-2: This mechanism is associated with the action of diphtheria toxin and Pseudomonas exotoxin decreasing protein synthesis. Option B - Toxin causes increased guanyl cyclase activity: This mechanism is associated with the action of heat-stable enterotoxins produced by certain strains of Escherichia coli (E. coli). Option D - Inhibit 60S subunit: This mechanism is associated with the action of shiga like toxin, decreasing protein synthesis.

questions.question: Safety pin appearance is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Burkhuloderia pseudomallei:   Safety pin appearance is due to bipolar staining shown by some organisms, in this the terminal parts of the organism is darkly stained and centre is poorly satined giving safety pin appearance.   Organisms showing safety pin appearance are: Burkholderia pseudomallei Burkholderia mallei Yersinia pestis Vibrio parahemolyticus Haemophilus ducreyi Klebsiella granulomatis   Burkholderia pseudomallei   Burkholderia mallei   Yersinia pestis   Vibrio parahemolyticus   Haemophilus ducreyi   Klebsiella granulomatis   Burkholderia pseudomallei   Burkholderia mallei   Yersinia pestis   Vibrio parahemolyticus   Haemophilus ducreyi   Klebsiella granulomatis Incorrect Options: Options A, C , and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.question: What is the causative organism of bull neck?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Corynebacterium diphtheriae:   Bull’s neck diphtheria, also called respiratory/faucial diphtheria, is caused by Corynebacterium Diphtheriae. It is characterized by massive tonsillar swelling and neck edema. Patients present with foul breath, thick speech, and stridor (noisy breathing). Incorrect Options: Option B - Corynebacterium jeikeium: It is known to cause cutaneous and bloodstream infection (endocarditis) in immunocompromised individuals. Option C - Corynebacterium minutissimum: It causes erythrasma, a localized infection of the stratum corneum usually affecting the groin and axilla. Option D - Corynebacterium urealyticum: It is mostly known to cause urinary tract infections.

questions.question: A 34-year-old HIV-positive male presented with low-grade fever, cough, night sweats, and weight loss for the past 3 weeks. In view of TB investigations, the Mantoux test was negative; chest X-ray showed non-specific findings, and an adequate amount of sputum could not be collected for slide examination. Which of the following is used to diagnose latent TB infection in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Interferon-gamma release assay:   In an HIV-positive individual with suspected latent tuberculosis (TB) infection, the Mantoux test may yield false-negative results due to the impaired immune response. Therefore, the alternative method used to diagnose latent TB infection in such cases is IGRA (interferon-gamma release assay).   Interferon-gamma release assay measured using ELISA. T-lymphocytes are exposed to antigens: ESAT6 TB 7.7 CFP 10 Exposure stimulates the release of interferon-gamma released by CD 4 T cells in response - measured by ELISA. Advantage: Negative in BCG vaccination.   T-lymphocytes are exposed to antigens: ESAT6 TB 7.7 CFP 10   ESAT6   TB 7.7   CFP 10   Exposure stimulates the release of interferon-gamma released by CD 4 T cells in response - measured by ELISA.   Advantage: Negative in BCG vaccination.   T-lymphocytes are exposed to antigens: ESAT6 TB 7.7 CFP 10   ESAT6   TB 7.7   CFP 10   Exposure stimulates the release of interferon-gamma released by CD 4 T cells in response - measured by ELISA.   Advantage: Negative in BCG vaccination.   ESAT6   TB 7.7   CFP 10 Incorrect Options: Option A - CBNAAT: It is used to diagnose active tuberculosis and detection of resistance to rifampicin. Option B - MGIT system: It is an automated culture method used for the diagnosis of active tuberculosis and to detect resistance against antitubercular drugs. Option D - Line probe assay: It is used for the diagnosis of active tuberculosis and detection of resistance to 1st and 2nd line antitubercular drugs.

questions.question: A middle-aged man presents with a painless genital ulcer, as shown below. A Microscopy of a sample from the lesion is also shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Granuloma Inguinale:   The presentation of a painless genital ulcer and lesion on microscopy showing bipolar staining is suggestive of Granuloma inguinale (donovanosis) caused by a gram-negative bacterium Klebsiella granulomatis. It causes a painless papule that ulcerates throughout the disease.   The first image shows a red beefy ulcer that bleeds profusely on touch or contact is characteristic of granuloma inguinale.   The second image is a microscopy image showing Donovan's body, large cyst-like macrophages filled with deeply stained capsulated bacilli having a safety-pin (bipolar) appearance. Incorrect Options: Option B - Lymphogranuloma venereum: It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, characterized by a painless genital ulcer with painful lymphadenopathy(Inguinal bubos). The inguinal lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament swell up and appear like groove sign. Option C - Chancroid: Also called oft Chancre/chancroid, is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi characterized by painful genital ulcer. Option D - Gonorrhea: It is caused by Neisseria Gonorrhoeae. It usually presents as cervicitis, prostatitis, urethritis, or vaginitis associated with purulent discharge out of the urethral or vaginal meatus.

questions.question: An EI Tor vibrio was identified as the causative agent of a diarrhea epidemic. Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of this organism?

options.A: Resistant to EI Tor phage V
options.D: Not susceptible to group IV phage

questions.solution: Correct Option A - Resistant to EI Tor phage V: Differences between classical and EI Tor V. Cholerae Biotypes of V. Cholerae O1 Classical biotype EI Tor biotype β -hemolysis on sheep blood agar Negative Positive Chick erythrocyte agglutination Negative Positive Polymyxin B (50 IU) Susceptible Resistant Group IV phage susceptibility Susceptible Resistant EI Tor Phage V susceptibility Resistant Susceptible VP (Voges-Proskauer) test Negative Positive Cholera toxin gene CTX-1 CTX-2 Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.question: GeneXpert detects mutations in which of the following genes?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - rpoB:`   GeneXpert is a molecular diagnostic tool used for the rapid detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance targeting five different sequences of the rpoB (RNA polymerase subunit B) gene.   GeneXpert is a CBNAAT system recommended by WHO as the initial test for the diagnosis of extrapulmonary tuberculosis. Incorrect Options: Options A and C - inha & KatG: inhA (Enoyl ACP reductase) and KatG (Catalase-peroxidase) gene is associated with resistance to isoniazid and is detected by line probe assay. Option D - pncA: The pncA (Pyrazinamidase) gene is associated with resistance to the drug pyrazinamide and is detected by line probe assay.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about scrub typhus is false?

options.C: Produces NLF producing colonies in MacConkey agar

questions.solution: Correct Option C - Produces NLF-producing colonies in MacConkey agar:   The Scrub typhus is caused by orientia tsutsugamushi. Among all stages of mites, the larvae (called chiggers) are the only stage that feeds on humans. Hence also called chiggerosis.   The classic presentation of scrub typhus consists of a triad of an eschar (at the site of the bite), regional lymphadenopathy, and maculopapular rash.   Humans are considered accidental hosts of Orientia tsutsugamushi. The natural hosts of the bacterium are small rodents, such as mice and rats, which serve as reservoirs.   It is an obligate intracellular pathogen and does not grow on standard laboratory culture media like MacConkey agar. It requires specialized cell culture like the Yolk sac of an embryonated hen's egg (or) Cell lines - Varo, Hela, Hep2, Detroit 6. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.question: Pneumonia due to a gram-negative pleomorphic bacillus growing on chocolate agar, which is catalase and oxidase–positive is due to:
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Haemophilus Influenzae:   Haemophilus influenzae is a gram-negative pleomorphic (coccobacilli) bacillus that can cause respiratory tract infections, including pneumonia. It grows well on chocolate agar, which contains factors that support its growth. It is catalase and oxidase-positive, which helps differentiate it from other bacteria. Incorrect Options: Option A - E. Coli: E. coli is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, and oxidase-negative bacilli. It may cause urinary tract infections, gastrointestinal infections, sepsis, or pyogenic infections. Option B - Pseudomonas: Pseudomonas is a gram-negative, catalase, and oxidase-positive bacillus that can cause pneumonia. It is grown on nutrient agar, MacConkey agar, and blood agar. Option D - Actinomyces: Actinomyces is a gram-positive, filamentous bacterium that can cause chronic granulomatous infection characterized by indurated swellings with sulfur granule discharge.

questions.question: A 30-year-old male presented to the OPD with painful genital ulcers. Which of the following can cause a painful ulcer on the glans penis ?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - H. Ducreyi:   Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi. It is characterized by the development of painful genital ulcers, which can occur on the glans penis, shaft, or in the pubic area. questions.solution: Correct Option B - History of exposure to cat:   The presentation of a blister on the hand, followed by axillary lymphadenopathy, is highly suggestive of cat scratch disease among the given options   It occurs when an infected cat licks a person’s open wound or bites or scratches a person hard enough to break the surface of the skin. It is caused by the bacteria Bartonella henselae, characterized by a febrile illness with lymphadenopathy.   In immunocompromised patients, it causes bacillary angiomatosis, in which vascular nodules appear on skin and mucosa.   B. henselae can be demonstrated in lymph node biopsy with Warthin-Starry staining. Incorrect Options: Option A - History of rat bite: Rat bite can cause rabies, but it does not present with regional lymphadenopathy. questions.question: What does Burkholderia cepacia exhibit resistance to among the options provided?
questions.solution: Correct Option D - Cefotetan:   Burkholderia cepacia is known to exhibit intrinsic resistance to cefotetan.   This resistance is primarily attributed to the presence of various mechanisms, including efflux pumps, enzymatic degradation, and alterations in target sites.   Burkholderia cepacia is resistant to aminoglycosides, polymyxine, 1st and 2nd generation cephalosporins, and carboxypenicillins.   Burkholderia cepacia is susceptible to Ceftazidime, Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, Temocillin, doxycycline, meropenem, and piperacillin. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and C are incorrect. questions.question: What is the causative agent for scombroid food poisoning among the following organisms?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Pseudomonas Aeruginosa:   Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacterium that can cause various infections in humans.   Scombroid poisoning is caused by the consumption of fish.   Organisms responsible for causing Scombroid poisoning are Morganella morganii, Escherichia coli, Klebsiella species, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.   They are commensal in seafish and can break down histidine present in fish into histamine, which can cause food poisoning following seafood intake. Incorrect Options: Option A- Salmonella: Salmonella is a group of bacteria that causes typhoid fever characterized by step ladder pattern fever, bradycardia, and pea soup diarrhea. Option B- Staphylococcus: It causes food poisoning with the consumption of milk and meat products with an incubation period of 1 to 6 hours. Option D- Peptostreptococcus: Peptostreptococcus is a genus of anaerobic bacteria that can be part of skin, mouth, intestine, and vagina. It is associated with puerperal sepsis and skin and soft tissue infection.

questions.question: Bacterial transduction occurs by

options.D: Uptake of genetic material by other bacteria

questions.solution: Correct Option C - Bacteriophage:   Bacterial transduction occurs through the action of bacteriophages, which transfer bacterial genetic material from one bacterium to another. Types of Bacteriophages Virulent phage Temperate phage Dangerous Follow only lytic cycle Ex: T1 and T2 phage of E.coliLess dangerous Follow both lytic and lysogenic cycle Ex: Lambda phage of E. coli Incorrect Options: Option A - Plasmids: Plasmids are circular, extrachromosomal DNA molecules that can be found in bacteria. While plasmids can carry genetic information and can be transferred between bacteria through a process called conjugation where plasmids are transferred between bacteria through direct physical contact. Option B - Sex pilli: Sex pilli, or pili, are appendages found on the surface of certain bacteria that facilitate the transfer of genetic material during conjugation. Option D - Uptake of genetic material by other bacteria: This refers to the gene transfer by transformation, a mechanism of horizontal gene transfer in bacteria, where bacteria can uptake free extracellular DNA from the environment and incorporate it into their own genome.

questions.question: TB test done only on whole blood sample is ______________.
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Interferon-gamma release assay:   Interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA) is a type of tuberculosis (TB) test that is performed on whole blood samples.   IGRA tests measure the release of interferon-gamma by T-cells in response to specific TB antigens (ESAT, 6TB 7.7, and CFP 10). Incorrect Options: Option A - TrueNat TB: TrueNat TB is a molecular diagnostic test for the detection of tuberculosis. It utilizes a cartridge-based platform to perform real-time PCR (polymerase chain reaction) to detect Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA in sputum samples. TrueNet TB is not specifically limited to whole blood samples, as it is primarily used for sputum-based testing. Option B - GeneXpert: GeneXpert is a molecular diagnostic platform that uses real-time PCR technology to detect tuberculosis and resistance against rifampicin. The test is typically performed on sputum samples or other respiratory specimens rather than whole blood. Option D - MGIT system: It is a molecular diagnostic platform that uses probe-based detection of amplified DNA in the specimen to detect tuberculosis and resistance 1st line and 2nd line antitubercular drugs. The test is typically performed on sputum samples or other respiratory specimens.

questions.question: What causes the formation of multiple abscesses with discharging sinuses that show the presence of sulphur granules in the pus?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Actinomyces Israelii:   Multiple abscesses with discharging sinuses and the presence of sulfur granules in pus are characteristic features of actinomycosis caused by actinomyces israelii a commensal bacterium in the oral flora.   Actinomyces form aggregates called sulfur granules, which are composed of bacterial colonies surrounded by host tissue reaction. These granules are typically yellowish and contain tangled filamentous structures seen on microscopy. Incorrect Options: Option B - Nocardia: Nocardia can cause pulmonary infections in immunocompromised individuals and cutaneous lesions in immunocompetent individuals. Option C - Salmonella: Salmonella bacteria are primarily associated with gastrointestinal infections, such as dysentery characterized by bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever. Option D - Tularemia: Tularemia, also known as rabbit fever, is caused by the bacterium Francisella tularensis. It typically presents as a flu-like illness with symptoms such as fever, fatigue, and swollen lymph nodes.

questions.question: Which antibiotics are Mycoplasma naturally resistant to?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Beta-lactam Antibiotics:   Beta-lactam antibiotics: Mycoplasma is inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics.   This is because mycoplasmas lack a cell wall, which is the target of penicillins (like β -lactamase inhibitors) and cephalosporins.   The absence of a cell wall makes mycoplasmas naturally resistant to these types of antibiotics. Incorrect Options: Option B - Macrolides: Mycoplasma is susceptible to macrolide antibiotics such as erythromycin, azithromycin, and clarithromycin. Macrolides are commonly used in the treatment of mycoplasma infections. Option C - Tetracycline: Mycoplasma is susceptible to tetracycline antibiotics. Tetracyclines, including doxycycline and minocycline, are often effective in treating mycoplasma infections. Option D - Fluoroquinolones: Mycoplasma is susceptible to fluoroquinolone antibiotics such as ciprofloxacin and levofloxacin. Fluoroquinolones are commonly used in the treatment of mycoplasma infections.

questions.question: What is the incubation period of lymphogranuloma venereum ?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - 3-35 days:   The incubation period of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is typically between 3 days to 5 weeks.   Lymphogranuloma venereum is a sexually transmitted infection caused by L1, L2, and L3 serovars of the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis, after which a small, painless, papulovesicular lesion appears on the genitalia. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.question: Identify the organism shown below, which causes effacement and attachment of intestinal cells.
questions.solution: Correct Option C - EPEC:   Attachment - effacement lesion in intestinal mucosa is caused by EPEC (Enteropathogenic Escherichia coli).   Enteropathogenic E coli are non-invasive and do not produce enterotoxins.   EPEC has two factors: EPEC adherence factor (EAF) The chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenicity island that promotes the tight adherence characteristic of EPEC (attachment and effacement).   EPEC adherence factor (EAF)   The chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenicity island that promotes the tight adherence characteristic of EPEC (attachment and effacement).   After attachment, there is a loss of microvilli (effacement) and formation of filamentous actin pedestals or cuplike structures, causing entry of the EPEC into the mucosal cells. This attachment-effacement lesion disrupts the normal absorptive function of the intestinal epithelium and can lead to diarrhea.   EPEC adherence factor (EAF)   The chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenicity island that promotes the tight adherence characteristic of EPEC (attachment and effacement). Incorrect Options: Option A - ETEC (Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli): ETEC is another type of Escherichia coli bacteria that causes traveler's diarrhea. It produces toxins that act on the intestinal mucosa and cause watery diarrhea by adhering to the intestinal mucosa by fimbriae called colonization factor antigens. Option B - EIEC (Enteroinvasive Escherichia coli): EIEC is a type of Escherichia coli bacteria that invades and damages the intestinal epithelial cells, leading to an inflammatory response. It can cause dysentery-like symptoms but does not specifically cause effacement and attachment of intestinal cells like EPEC. Option D - EAEC (Enteroaggregative Escherichia coli): EAEC is a type of Escherichia coli bacteria associated with persistent diarrhea, particularly in young children. It forms aggregative adherence patterns on the surface of intestinal cells but does not cause the effacement and attachment observed in EPEC infections.

questions.question: The test shown below, which uses a bacitracin disc, is useful in identifying …………
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Streptococcus Pyogenes:   The test shown, which uses a bacitracin disc on a blood agar culture plate with a zone of inhibition around the disc, is useful in identifying Streptococcus pyogenes.   The test being referred to is the bacitracin susceptibility test. In this test, a disc containing a standardized concentration of bacitracin is placed on a blood agar culture plate that has been inoculated with the bacterial isolate. Streptococcus pyogenes is highly sensitive to bacitracin than other streptococci, showing wide range of inhibition as shown in the image. Incorrect Options: Option A - Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is resistant to bacitracin, so it would not show a zone of inhibition around the disc in this test. Option C - Staphylococcus epidermidis: Staphylococcus epidermidis is resistant to bacitracin, so it would not show a zone of inhibition around the disc in this test. Option D - Streptococcus agalactiae: Streptococcus agalactiae is resistant to bacitracin, so it would not show a zone of inhibition around the disc in this test.

questions.question: A cook prepares sandwiches for 10 people going for picnic. Eight out of them develop severe gastroenteritis within 4-6 hrs of consumption of the sandwiches. It is likely that on investigations the cook is found to be the carrier of:
questions.solution: Correct Option D - Staphylococcus Aureus:   Staphylococcus aureus is a bacterium that can cause food poisoning when contaminated food, particularly carbohydrate and protein-rich food, milk, meat, and fish, is consumed.   Staphylococcus aureus can produce heat-stable enterotoxins that can withstand 100°C for 10 to 40 minutes and cause rapid-onset symptoms of nausea and vomiting, typically occurring within a few hours (within 6 hours is characteristic) of ingesting contaminated food. Incorrect Options: Option A - Salmonella typhi: Salmonella typhi is the bacterium responsible for causing typhoid fever. It is transmitted through the ingestion of contaminated food or water. However, the incubation period for typhoid fever is usually much longer, ranging from 7 to 14 days. Option B - Vibrio cholerae: Vibrio cholerae is the bacterium that causes cholera, a severe diarrheal disease. Cholera is typically associated with the ingestion of contaminated water or food, usually in settings with poor sanitation. The incubation period for cholera is less than 24 hours to 5 days. Option C - Entamoeba histolytica: Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite that causes amoebic dysentery, a form of severe diarrhea. The incubation period for amoebic dysentery is typically longer, ranging from 2 weeks to 4 weeks.

questions.question: What is the most probable cause in a case of granuloma with acid-fast bacilli positivity?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Leprosy:   When encountering a case of granuloma with positive acid-fast bacilli (AFB), leprosy is the most likely cause. Leprosy, also known as Hansen's disease, is a chronic infectious disease caused by the bacteria Mycobacterium leprae. It primarily affects the skin, peripheral nerves, mucosa of the upper respiratory tract, and the eyes.   Leprosy is characterized by the formation of granulomas in the affected tissues, which are clusters of immune cells, including macrophages, that surround and attempt to contain the mycobacteria. Acid-fast staining is a diagnostic test used to visualize mycobacteria, such as Mycobacterium leprae, which retain the stain despite being exposed to acid. Incorrect options: Option A - Cat scratch disease: Cat scratch disease is caused by the bacterium Bartonella henselae, and it typically presents with swollen lymph nodes and a papule or pustule at the site of a cat scratch or bite. It does not cause granulomas with positive AFB staining. Option B - Trench fever: Trench fever is caused by the bacterium Bartonella quintana and is transmitted by body lice. It is characterized by recurrent fever, headache, and bone pain. Trench fever does not typically present with granulomas or positive AFB staining. Option D - Syphilis: Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. It presents with painless genital ulcer and inguinal lymph node, condylomata lata, and neurosyphilis. However, syphilis does not commonly present with granulomas or positive AFB staining.

questions.question: Legionnaires disease is implicated in causation of which among the following?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Respiratory Disease:   Legionnaires disease is a severe form of pneumonia caused by the bacterium Legionella pneumophila. It primarily affects the respiratory system, leading to respiratory disease symptoms like mild fever, myalgia, non-productive cough, and respiratory failure.   The bacteria Legionella pneumophila are transmitted through inhalation of contaminated water droplets, typically from sources such as air conditioning systems, hot tubs, or showers. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect. These conditions are not associated with legionnaire's disease.

questions.question: When should you perform a Widal test in a case of Typhoid?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - 2nd week:   The Widal test is a serological test used for the diagnosis of typhoid fever caused by the bacterium Salmonella typhi. It detects antibodies in the patient's blood against specific antigens of the Salmonella typhi bacteria.   Performing the Widal test in the 2nd week of illness is considered the most appropriate timing for obtaining reliable and accurate results. During the 2nd week of typhoid fever, the patient's immune response has had sufficient time to produce detectable levels of antibodiesagainst Salmonella typhi antigens.   Tests performed for the diagnosis of typhoid during the course of infection. Week Test performed Week 1 Blood culture Week 2 Antibody test (Widal) Week 3 Stool culture Week 4 Urine culture Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an example.

questions.question: Hemolytic uremic syndrome is associated with?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - E. Coli 0157:   Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) is a condition characterized by the combination of hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury. HUS can have several causes, but the most common and well-known association is with infection by the bacterium Escherichia coli (E. coli) serotype O157:H7 and shigella.   E. coli O157: H7 is a strain of E. coli that produces toxins called Shiga toxins. These toxins can cause damage to the lining of blood vessels, leading to red blood cell destruction, platelet clumping, and kidney injury, which are characteristic features of HUS. Incorrect Options: Option B - Malaria: Malaria is caused by Plasmodium parasites transmitted by infected mosquitoes. It is characterized by fever, and severe cases of cerebral malaria caused by P. falciparum can be seen. It is not typically associated with HUS. Option C - Parvovirus B19: Parvovirus B19 is a viral infection that primarily affects children and can cause a condition called erythema infectiosum (fifth disease). Option D - Bartonella Henselae: It is a bacterium that causes cat scratch disease, a usually benign infection characterized by swollen lymph nodes and fever. Bartonella infections can have various manifestations, including neurologic and cardiac complications, they are not typically associated with HUS.

questions.question: The disruption of which of the following is responsible for watery diarrhea in cholera caused by Vibrio?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Zonula occludens:   Vibrio cholerae causing watery diarrhea occurs due to the disruption of the zonula occludens, also known as tight junctions, in the intestinal epithelial cells. The zonula occludens form a barrier between the cells, regulating the movement of ions, water, and solutes across the intestinal lining.   When Vibrio cholerae infects the small intestine, it produces a toxin called Zonula toxin. This toxin binds to the surface of intestinal cells and interferes with the function of the tight junctions. It leads to increased secretion of chloride ions and water into the intestinal lumen, resulting in the characteristic watery diarrhea seen in cholera. Incorrect Option: Option A - Intercalated discs: Intercalated discs are specialized junctions found in cardiac muscle cells that help coordinate the contraction of the heart. Option B - Macula densa: Macula densa is a structure located in the distal convoluted tubules of the kidney and is involved in the regulation of renal blood flow and filtration. Option D - Hemidesmosomes: Hemidesmosomes are structures found in epithelial cells that help anchor them to the underlying basement membrane.

questions.question: A patient is exhibiting symptoms of urethral discharge. A sample of the discharge is used to create a gram stain smear, revealing the provided microscopic image. Based on this information, what is the most probable organism responsible for the symptoms?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Neisseria Gonorrheae:   The clinical presentation of urethral discharge is suggestive of urethritis, and the presence of gram-negative intracellular diplococci in the microscopic image suggests the likely causative organism is Neisseria gonorrhea.   This bacterium is known to cause sexually transmitted infections, including urethritis with semen-like discharge (most commonly), prostatitis in males, vaginitis, cervicitis, urethritis in females, and ophthalmia neonatorum in infants contracted during birth. Incorrect Option: Option A - Trichomonas: Trichomonas is a protozoan parasite that causes a sexually transmitted infection and non-gonococcal urethritis, prostatitis, and cystitis in males. It is typically observed as pear-shaped or oval flagellated organisms. Option B - Chlamydia trachomatis: Chlamydia trachomatis is a bacterial pathogen known to cause non-gonococcal urethritis. They are gram-negative bacteria, and elementary bodies are seen on a microscope. Option D - Gardnerella: Gardnerella vaginalis, which is associated with bacterial vaginosis and a few cases of urethritis. It is gram-negative coccobacilli with metachromatic granules.

questions.question: Yaws is caused by:
questions.solution: Correct Option A - T. Pertunae:   Yaws is a tropical disease caused by the bacterium Treponema pertenue. It is a subspecies of Treponema pallidum, which causes syphilis. questions.question: Which bacteria show Quellung reaction?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Streptococcus Pneumoniae:   The Quellung reaction is a phenomenon in which the capsule surrounding bacteria swells and becomes more visible when exposed to specific antibodies. questions.question: In the small intestine, cholera toxin acts by:

options.A: ADP ribosylation of the G protein

questions.solution: Correct Option A - ADP ribosylation of the G protein:   Cholera toxin produced by Vibrio cholerae acts by ADP ribosylation of the G protein in the intestinal cells by the A1 subunit of the toxin, leading to increased production of cyclic AMP (cAMP) and subsequent activation of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) ion channel, resulting in massive secretion of electrolytes and water into the lumen of the small intestine. Incorrect Options : Option B - Inhibition of adenyl cyclase: Cholera toxin actually stimulates adenyl cyclase, leading to increased production of cAMP. Option C - Activation of GTPase: Cholera toxin does not activate GTPase. It acts by ADP ribosylation of the G protein. Option D - Active absorption of NaCl: Cholera toxin disrupts the normal absorption of electrolytes and water, resulting in excessive fluid secretion rather than active absorption of NaCl.

questions.question: A 12-year-old boy presents with right upper quadrant pain, calf pain, conjunctival suffusion, icterus, and fever. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Leptospirosis:   Leptospirosis is a bacterial infection that can occur in humans and animals. It is caused by the spirochete bacterium Leptospira interrogans.   The clinical presentation of this patient, including right upper quadrant pain, calf pain, conjunctival suffusion, icterus, and fever, is consistent with the diagnosis of a severe form of leptospirosis, aka Weil's disease, aka hepato-renal-hemorrhagic syndrome. Incorrect Options: Option B: Chikungunya: It presents with fever, joint pain, headache, muscle pain, joint swelling, and rash. While fever is a common symptom in both leptospirosis and chikungunya, the other symptoms are not consistent with the presentation of this patient. Option C: Dengue hemorrhagic fever: It presents with fever, headache, joint and muscle pain, and rash. Dengue hemorrhagic fever is a severe form of the disease that can lead to bleeding, shock, and death. While fever is a common symptom in both leptospirosis and dengue fever, the other symptoms are not consistent with the presentation of this patient. Option D. Encephalopathy caused by hepatitis A: It presents with fever, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, dark urine, and jaundice. While jaundice is a common symptom in both leptospirosis and hepatitis A, the other symptoms are not consistent with the presentation of this patient.

questions.question: Regarding Clostridium difficile infection, which of the following statements is false in the case of a woman prescribed a broad-spectrum antibiotic for recurrent diarrhea?

options.A: Oral fidaxomicin is used for treatment
options.D: Pseudomembrane is a layer of inflammatory cells and debris

questions.solution: Correct Option C - No risk of Fulminant Infection:   Clostridium difficile is a gram-negative bacteria responsible for causing acute colitis with bloody or watery diarrhea and pseudomembrane colitis in a patient on long-term usage of broad spectrum antibiotics like clindamycin, ampicillin, fluoroquinolones, and 3rd generation cephalosporins.   It is responsible for the production of enterotoxin A and cytotoxin B, responsible for the disruption of the epithelial cell barrier causing diarrhea and pseudomembrane colitis.   Pseudomembrane is composed of necrotic leukocytes, fibrin, mucus, and cellular debris.   It can lead to fulminant colitis characterized by hypotension or shock, ileus, and megacolon.   Treatment for Clostridium difficile infection typically involves discontinuing the offending antibiotic and initiating treatment with a fidaxomicin (drug of choice) and oral vancomycin. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.solution: Correct Option A - Leptospira:   Leptospira is a genus of bacteria that causes the infectious disease leptospirosis. questions.question: A 28-year-old woman with a recent travel history to Africa presents with fever, confusion and neurological deficits. Laboratory analysis reveals the following findings. This organism exhibits a specific property that facilitates sequestration in vascular beds to avoid splenic clearance. What is the phenomenon called?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Cytoadherence:   The phenomenon described, where infected red blood cells adhere to endothelial cells, is known as cytoadherence. This process is particularly associated with Plasmodium falciparum infection and is mediated by specialised proteins, such as PFEMP1 (Plasmodium falciparum Erythrocyte Membrane Protein 1), which are present on the surface of infected red blood cells.   At times, inflammatory cytokines, notably IFN-gamma, generated by the malaria parasite, enhance the expression of endothelial cytoadherence receptors such as thrombospondin, E-selectin, VCAM-1, and ICAM-1 in brain capillaries, chondroitin sulfate B in the placenta, and CD36 in various organs. This leads to the adherence of infected red blood cells within capillaries and venules, eventually causing blockage. Incorrect Options: Option A - Rosetting: Rosetting refers to the clustering of uninfected red blood cells around an infected red blood cell, often seen in Plasmodium falciparum infection. These results in clinical manifestation of cerebral malaria. Option - B Agglutination: Agglutination involves the clumping together of particles or cells, often mediated by antibodies. Option D - Schizogony: Schizogony is the process of asexual reproduction in Plasmodium parasites, leading to the release of merozoites.

questions.question: A farmer presents with a lesion on his arm after working with cattle on his farm. Gram staining of a sample from the lesion reveals gram-positive rods with square ends and central spores. What is the most likely organism causing this lesion?
questions.solution: Correct Option C- Bacillus anthracis:   Bacillus anthracis is the causative agent of anthrax, which commonly affects individuals exposed to infected animals such as cattle.   The characteristic gram-positive rods with square ends and central spores, known as " boxcar" appearance, are typical of Bacillus anthracis.   The clinical presentation of a lesion with central necrosis, erythema, and raised borders is consistent with cutaneous anthrax, often seen in individuals handling infected animal products. Incorrect Options: Option A- Brucella abortus: Brucella species are gram-negative bacteria responsible for brucellosis, a zoonotic disease transmitted from animals to humans. The gram-staining appearance and clinical presentation of brucellosis, such as fever, arthralgia, and hepatosplenomegaly, differ significantly from the findings in the presented scenario. Option B- Pseudomonas aeruginosa: This gram-negative bacterium is known for causing opportunistic infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. Option D- Bacillus cereus: Bacillus cereus is a gram-positive, spore-forming bacterium that can cause food poisoning after consumption of Chinese fried rice. It does not produce skin lesions.

questions.question: A 68-year-old woman was hospitalized for three days for left leg cellulitis. She was treated with clindamycin. Two days after her discharge, abdominal pain, and watery diarrhea. Lab results showed leukocytes 17,500/mm3, elevated ESR and CRP. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution: Correct Option C- Clostridioides difficile:   Clostridioides difficile is a gram-positive bacterium that is the cause most implicated in antibiotic-associated diarrhea.   Antibiotic use is the leading risk factor for C. difficile infection. Several classes of antibiotics, such as penicillins, cephalosporins, fluoroquinolone, and clindamycin, are implicated.   Apart from antibiotic usage, other risk factors involved in the causation include advanced age, chemotherapy, use of proton pump inhibitors, chronic renal disease, chronic liver disease, and malnutrition.   Watery diarrhea with mucus or occult blood, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, low-grade fever, and lower abdominal pain are the symptoms. Incorrect Options: Option A- Escherichia coli: While E. coli can cause diarrhea, it is less likely in this scenario because the patient developed symptoms after being discharged and being on clindamycin, not due to contaminated food or water sources commonly associated with E. coli infections. Option B- Norovirus: Norovirus is a common cause of viral gastroenteritis. It is less likely in this case because the patient's symptoms and history of antibiotic use are more consistent with a bacterial infection. Option D- Rotavirus: Rotavirus is another viral cause of gastroenteritis, primarily affecting children. It presents with symptoms like fever, vomiting, and watery diarrhea. It is less likely in an adult patient like the one described here.

questions.question: Which of the following acts by the following MOA?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Streptococcus pyogenes:   Superantigens, in contrast to conventional antigens, don't require processing and presentation by antigen-presenting cells (APCs) to activate T cells. Instead, they interact laterally with the variable beta (V β) part of the T-cell receptor (TCR) outside the peptide-binding groove. Superantigens, in contrast to conventional antigens, don't require processing and presentation by antigen-presenting cells (APCs) to activate T cells. Instead, they interact laterally with the variable beta (V β) part of the T-cell receptor (TCR) outside the peptide-binding groove. Incorrect Options: Option A - Vibrio cholerae: Cholera toxin is produced by Vibrio cholerae, the bacterium responsible for cholera. The toxin acts by ADP-ribosylation of the Gs protein in intestinal cells. This leads to increased intracellular cAMP levels, resulting in the continuous activation of the CFTR chloride channel and the efflux of chloride ions into the intestinal lumen. The osmotic imbalance causes massive diarrhea, leading to dehydration and potentially severe electrolyte imbalances. Option C - Clostridium difficile: Clostridium difficile is a bacterium that can cause antibiotic-associated diarrhea and colitis. It produces toxins, particularly toxin A (enterotoxin) and toxin B (cytotoxin).The toxins produced by Clostridium difficile rapidly target and attack the GTP-binding proteins, specifically Rho, Rac, and CDC 42. This attack results in considerable damage to the actin cytoskeleton, ultimately leading to cellular death. Option D -Clostridium botulinum: Clostridium botulinum produces botulinum toxin, which is one of the most potent toxins known. Subtypes A, B, and E cause infections, with A being the most severe. The toxin induces flaccid paralysis by blocking acetylcholine release, targeting Snare proteins. In neurons, it cleaves Snap 25, Syntaxin 1, and Synaptobrevin, preventing muscle contraction and causing floppy muscles. Clinical manifestations include the absence of muscle contraction, leading to flaccidity.

questions.question: Which bacterial toxin acts by interfering with EF-2 function?
questions.solution: Correct Option A- Diphtheria Toxin:   Produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, the bacterium that causes diphtheria.   Mechanism of Action: Diphtheria toxin inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylation of EF-2. This modification prevents EF-2 from participating in the translocation step during protein synthesis, leading to the inhibition of elongation and ultimately causing cell death. Incorrect Options: Option B- Clostridium Toxins (Botulinum and Tetanus Toxins):   Clostridium botulinum toxin and Clostridium tetani toxin act on different targets. Botulinum toxin inhibits the release of acetylcholine at neuromuscular junctions, leading to muscle paralysis.   Tetanus toxin interferes with neurotransmitter release, causing spastic paralysis. Option C- Bacillus anthracis Toxin:   Bacillus anthracis produces a toxin known as anthrax toxin.   Anthrax toxin does not directly interfere with EF-2 function but exerts its effects through the disruption of cellular signaling pathways. Option D- Vibrio cholerae Toxin (Cholera Toxin):   Cholera toxin primarily affects the regulation of ion transport in host cells by increasing intracellular levels of cyclic AMP (cAMP).   It does not directly interfere with EF-2 function.

questions.question: Identify the organism and staining
questions.solution: Correct Option A- Nocardia and acid-fast stain:   Nocardia is a Gram-positive bacterium that appears purple after Gram staining, forms filaments , and is detectable using the Ziehl-Neelsen staining method. Incorrect Options: Option B- Streptococcus gram stain:   Streptococcus bacteria stain purple in the Gram staining method, indicating their Gram-positive nature. Streptococcus bacteria typically have a spherical or ovoid shape and can form chains or pairs. Unlike Nocardia, they do not display filamentous structures. Option C- Cryptococcus india ink:   Cryptococcus yeast cells are round to oval and may be encapsulated. The capsule is the key feature that will be visible in the India ink preparation, creating a halo around the stained cells. Unlike Nocardia, they do not display filamentous structures. Option D- Coccidioidomycosis PAS stain:   Coccidioides species will appear magenta or pink due to the PAS stain, and characteristic structures like spherules may be visible. Unlike Nocardia, they do not display filamentous structures.

questions.question: Organism showing movement transcellular by ACTIN FILAMENTS?
questions.solution: Correct Option A- Listeria:   Listeria monocytogenes is a bacterium that can move within and between cells by exploiting the host cell's actin cytoskeleton.   It uses host cell machinery to polymerize actin filaments at one end of the bacterium, pushing it into the cell membrane. This allows Listeria to move within the host cell and from cell to cell. Incorrect Options: Option B- EIEC (Enteroinvasive Escherichia coli):   EIEC does invade and multiply within the epithelial cells of the colon, but its mechanism of movement is not primarily based on actin polymerization like Listeria. Option C- Salmonella:   Salmonella also invades host cells, but it uses a different mechanism involving a type III secretion system. It induces rearrangement of the host cell cytoskeleton, but its movement is not primarily transcellular by actin filaments

questions.question: A 26-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of fever, abdominal pain and diarrhoea for 3 days.
