Which causative agent is the most likely?
questions.solution: Correct option D - Vibrio parahaemolyticus:   This is a case of acute gastroenteritis as the patient presents with complaints of fever, diarrhoea and abdominal pain for 3 days.   Further history reveals that he had consumed raw fish 3 days back.   The most likely agent to have caused this illness is Vibrio parahaemolyticus.   Vibrio parahaemolyticus causes gastroenteritis. It is also found in raw fish. The selective media is Wagatsuma agar. Incorrect options: Option A - Vibrio cholerae:   Vibrio cholerae causes cholera. Option B - Salmonella typhi:   Salmonella typhi is the causative agent of enteric fever.   The selective media for Salmonella is Wilson Blair Media. Option C - Shigella sonnei:   Shigella infections are always invasive and generally will have a little pus in the stool.

questions.question: A 54-year-old female with a history of rheumatic heart disease underwent prosthetic valve replacement surgery 6 months ago. He presents to the cardiology clinic with complaints of fever, fatigue, and worsening shortness of breath over the past few weeks. Physical examination reveals a new heart murmur and splinter hemorrhages on the nail beds. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely causative organism responsible for this patient's infective endocarditis?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Staphylococcus epidermidis   Staphylococcus epidermidis a coagulase-negative staphylococci is a common cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis, especially within the first year after surgery Incorrect Options: Option B - Streptococcus viridans: This is a common cause of native valve endocarditis, not prosthetic valve endocarditis. Streptococcus viridans is a part of the normal flora of the mouth and throat and can cause endocarditis after dental procedures or in people with poor oral hygiene. Option C - Enterococcus faecalis: This bacterium is a common cause of healthcare-associated infections, including urinary tract infections, wound infections, and, less commonly, endocarditis. While it can cause endocarditis, it is not the most likely cause in this patient who has a prosthetic heart valve. Option D - Staphylococcus saprophyticus: Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a coagulase-negative staphylococci associated with urinary tract infections commonly.

questions.question: A 10-year-old child presents to the pediatric clinic with complaints of joint pain, swelling, and difficulty in walking. On examination, the child is found to have a tender, swollen knee joint and a history of recent sore throat. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers. A renal biopsy is performed, and it shows glomerular changes consistent with PSGN. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for both the acute rheumatic fever and PSGN in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Streptococcus pyogenes   Streptococcus pyogenes, also known as group A Streptococcus, is the correct answer. This bacterium is responsible for both acute rheumatic fever (ARF) and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). ARF is a systemic immune-mediated inflammatory disorder that can develop after an untreated or inadequately treated streptococcal pharyngitis (sore throat). It can lead to joint pain, inflammation, and other clinical manifestations. PSGN, on the other hand, is a kidney disease that can occur as a result of an immune response to a streptococcal infection, particularly in the skin or throat. The elevated antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers and the glomerular changes seen on renal biopsy in the given scenario are indicative of a streptococcal infection-related condition. Incorrect Options: Option A - Streptococcus pneumoniae: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common cause of bacterial pneumonia and other respiratory infections. It is not typically associated with acute rheumatic fever or post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Option C - Streptococcus agalactiae: Streptococcus agalactiae, also known as group B Streptococcus, is a common cause of neonatal infections and can also cause infections in adults with underlying medical conditions. It is not associated with acute rheumatic fever or PSGN. Option D - Streptococcus mutans: Streptococcus mutans is primarily associated with dental caries and oral infections. It is not a common cause of acute rheumatic fever or PSGN.

questions.question: A neonate admitted with the features of meningitis. Bacteria isolated from CSF is bacitracin resistant. Neonatal meningitis is caused by which organism?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B Streptococcus)   This is the correct answer. Group B Streptococcus is a known cause of neonatal meningitis, particularly in the first few days after birth. It is often found in the birth canal of asymptomatic carriers and can be transmitted to the newborn during delivery. Bacitracin resistance is a characteristic feature of Group B Streptococcus. Incorrect Options: Option A - Pneumococcus (Streptococcus pneumoniae): Pneumococcus is a common cause of bacterial meningitis, but it is not typically associated with neonatal meningitis. Pneumococcus is generally sensitive to bacitracin. Option B - Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus): Streptococcus pyogenes is more commonly associated with conditions like strep throat and skin infections. It is not a common cause of neonatal meningitis, and it is also sensitive to bacitracin. Option D - Meningococci (Neisseria meningitidis): Meningococcal meningitis is more common in older children and adults. It is not a common cause of neonatal meningitis. Neisseria meningitidis is typically sensitive to bacitracin.

questions.question: A 28 year old patient presented with watery diarrhoea and dysentery. After taking history, it is noted that he had eaten Oysters on his recent trip. Which of the following can be responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Vibrio Parahemolyticus   Vibrio parahemolyticus is a bacterium commonly associated with consuming raw or undercooked seafood, particularly oysters. It causes gastroenteritis with symptoms like watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, nausea, vomiting, and sometimes low-grade fever. The incubation period is usually short, ranging from a few hours to a couple of days after consuming contaminated seafood. Incorrect Options: Option B - Staph aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is a bacterium that can cause food poisoning when certain strains produce toxins. However, symptoms usually manifest within a few hours of consuming contaminated food and involve rapid onset of nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, and occasionally diarrhea. This bacterium is not typically associated with dysentery (bloody diarrhea) as described in the patient's case. Option C - E. coli: Certain strains of Escherichia coli (E. coli) can cause foodborne illnesses, including those leading to diarrhea. However, these infections are not usually associated with dysentery. E. coli strains like enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) or enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) tend to cause watery diarrhea rather than dysentery. Option D - Vibrio Cholerae: Vibrio cholerae is responsible for causing cholera, which leads to profuse watery diarrhea, rapid dehydration, and electrolyte imbalances. Cholera typically results in a "rice-water" appearance of stools due to its watery nature. While cholera can lead to severe diarrhea, it does not usually cause dysentery with bloody stools.

questions.question: Among the following conditions, which one does not result from exotoxins?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Meningitis:   Meningitis is typically the result of a direct invasion of the meninges by bacteria or viruses, and it is not primarily caused by the production of exotoxins. Incorrect Options: Option B - HUS: HUS is often associated with Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC) infections. Shiga toxin is an example of an exotoxin, and it plays a role in the pathogenesis of HUS. Option C - Toxic shock syndrome: TSS is typically caused by exotoxins produced by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes. Exotoxins are a primary factor in the development of TSS. Option D - Pseudomembranous colitis: Pseudomembranous colitis is primarily caused by Clostridium difficile infection. The main virulence factor in C. difficile infection is the production of toxins (exotoxins), particularly toxins A and B, which contribute to the characteristic symptoms of this condition.

questions.question: A patient from Uttarakhand presented in the month of September with fever and myalgia after a bite with a mite. The patient was started on IV ceftriaxone, but it did not help; later, the patient noticed cutaneous lesions on examination (black eschar), as given below in the figure. What is your diagnosis ?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Scrub Typhus:   The patient presenting with fever, myalgia, and cutaneous lesions (black eschar) after a bite with a mite in Uttarakhand during September is suggestive of Scrub typhus.   Scrub typhus is a bacterial infection caused by the Orientia tsutsugamushi bacterium. It is transmitted to humans through the bite of infected chiggers (larva of trombiculid mites) found in areas with dense vegetation. Scrub typhus is commonly seen in rural areas, particularly in regions with heavy vegetation, such as forests or grasslands.   The clinical presentation of scrub typhus includes fever, headache, myalgia (muscle pain), and a characteristic eschar at the site of the chigger bite. The eschar is a black, necrotic lesion surrounded by an area of inflammation. Incorrect Options: Option B - Murine Typhus: Murine typhus is caused by the bacteria Rickettsia typhi, transmitted to humans by rubbing or inhalation of the feces of infected fleas. It typically presents with fever, headache, myalgia, anorexia, and rash (involving the trunk more often than the extremities). Option C - Q Fever: Q fever is caused by the bacteria Coxiella burnetii, transmitted to humans through ingestion of contaminated milk or by handling wools, hides or meat. It can cause a flu-like illness, hepatitis, meningoencephalitis or endocarditis. Option D - Louse Borne Typhus: Louse-borne typhus also known as epidemic typhus, is caused by the bacteria Rickettsia prowazekii and is transmitted to humans through rubbing of louse (Pediculus humanus corporis) feces on an abraded skin. It presents with high fever, headache, and rash starting from trunk and spreading to limbs.

questions.question: A patient presented with severe watery diarrhea resembling that of rice gruel stool. Damage of which structure is likely to have resulted in this diarrhea?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Zona occludens:   Rice watery stool is a characteristic of cholera caused by vibrio cholerae. A toxin against the Zona occludens, or tight junctions is produced in the cholerae disrupting the junction leading to increased permeability, leakage of fluid and electrolytes resulting in rice water stools. Incorrect Options:   Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.solution: Correct Option B - Toxin assay:   Clostridium difficile is a bacterium that can cause pseudomembranous enterocolitis characterized by watery diarrhea.   The most common method for diagnosis of C. difficile is the detection of the toxins A or B in stool by ELISA.   Other diagnosing methods are:   Colonoscopy: 100% specificity, 50% sensitivity   Media: CCFA: Cefoxitin Cycloserine Fructose Agar CCYA: Cefoxitin Cysteine Yeast Extract Agar   CCFA: Cefoxitin Cycloserine Fructose Agar   CCYA: Cefoxitin Cysteine Yeast Extract Agar   GDH assay: It is present in both toxigenic and non-toxigenic strains, therefore called as C. difficile common antigen. Detection of GDH, in the absence of toxin A/B, indicates the presence of non-toxigenic strains of C. difficile in the specimen.   CCFA: Cefoxitin Cycloserine Fructose Agar   CCYA: Cefoxitin Cysteine Yeast Extract Agar Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.question: Slit skin smear
questions.solution: Correct Option B - History of exposure to cat:   The presentation of a blister on the hand, followed by axillary lymphadenopathy, is highly suggestive of cat scratch disease among the given options   It occurs when an infected cat licks a person’s open wound or bites or scratches a person hard enough to break the surface of the skin. It is caused by the bacteria Bartonella henselae, characterized by a febrile illness with lymphadenopathy.   In immunocompromised patients, it causes bacillary angiomatosis, in which vascular nodules appear on skin and mucosa.   B. henselae can be demonstrated in lymph node biopsy with Warthin-Starry staining. Incorrect Options: Option A - History of rat bite: Rat bite can cause rabies, but it does not present with regional lymphadenopathy. Option C - History of similar complaints among family members: A history of similar illness among family members is not relevant in the case of blister with regional lymphadenopathy. Option D - History of louse bite: A louse bite can cause epidemic typhus characterized by fever and a rash starting from the trunk and spreading to the limbs sparing palms and sole without regional lymphadenopathy.

questions.question: A patient with a history of penicillin allergy has been diagnosed with Enterococcus infective endocarditis. Which of the following antibiotics is the most appropriate treatment option?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Vancomycin:   In Enterococcus infective endocarditis patients with penicillin allergy or penicillin resistant strains, the drug of choice in the treatment of such cases is vancomycin.   Enterococci are intrinsically resistant to a wide array of antimicrobial agents, and they are generally resistant to killing by any of the single agents (e.g., ampicillin or vancomycin) that are bactericidal for most other gram-positive cocci.   Effective bactericidal activity can only be achieved with the combination of a cell wall–active agent, such as ampicillin or vancomycin, and an aminoglycoside, such as gentamicin or streptomycin. Incorrect Options: Option B - Ceftriaxone:   Ceftriaxone is 3rd generation cephalosporins used in the treatment of community acquired gram negative infections. Option C - Piperacillin:   Piperacillin is frequently used in treating gram negative infections in neutropenic/immunocompromised or burn patients. Option D - Aztreonam:   Aztreonam is Beta-lactam antibiotic that inhibits enteric bacilli, H.influenzae, and pseudomonas.

questions.question: In which of the following bacteria is increased penicillin drug resistance is noted?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Neisseria gonorrhoeae:   The Gonococcal Isolate Surveillance Project (GISP) is a national collaborative surveillance project in the United States. The program was established in 1986 to analyze and monitor antimicrobial resistance trends among N. gonorrhoeae.   Meningococci were uniformly sensitive to penicillin and other antibiotics, but resistant strains have emerged and become common in many areas.   This penicillin resistance is due to the ability of the Neisseria to produce penicillinase.   They are also resistant to fluoroquinolones. Incorrect Options:   Option A, C and D: Penicillin resistance is not noted in these diseases.

questions.question: Which among the following is the most specific disease of Streptococcus agalactiae?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Neonatal sepsis:   Streptococcus agalactiae is a group B ■- hemolytic streptococci which is the single most common cause of neonatal meningitis.   Early onset type- Occurs within a week of birth   Late onset type- Develops between second and twelfth weeks of life.   The more common early onset type presents as meningitis or septicemia and is often fatal. Incorrect Options: Option B - Infective endocarditis: Infective endocarditis is caused by Staph. aureus, Staph. epidermidis, Streptococcus viridans. Option C: - Dental caries: Dental caries is caused by other species of streptococcus like Streptococcus mitis. Option D - Pharyngitis with or without tonsillitis: Pharyngitis with or without tonsillitis is caused by Group A streptococcus.

questions.question: A patient came to the OPD with an injury caused by a rusted metal. What is the mechanism of action of Tetanus?

options.C: Inhibit the release of GABA and Glycine

questions.solution: Correct Option C - Inhibit the release of GABA and Glycine:   Tetanospasmin is the toxin responsible for tetanus   Tetanospasmin resembles strychnine in its effects. The tetanus toxin specifically blocks synaptic inhibition in the spinal cord, presumably at inhibitory terminals that use glycine and GABA as neurotransmitters.   The abolition of spinal inhibition causes uncontrolled spread of impulses initiated anywhere in the central nervous system.   This results in muscle rigidity and spasms due to the simultane - ous contraction of agonists and antagonists, in the absence of reciprocal inhibition. Incorrect Options: Option A - Inhibition of protein synthesis: Shiga toxin or verotoxin which is similar to EHEC verotoxin acts by inhibition of protein synthesis. Option B - Inhibit the release of Ach: Botulinum toxin acts by inhibiting the release of ACh. Option D - Inhibit the release of Norepinephrine: Release of norepinephrine is inhibited by certain drugs like alpha-2 agonists.

questions.question: Which of the following diseases is spread via all components of blood?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Syphilis:   Syphilis is transmitted through blood transfusions and its antigen can be transmitted through all the components of the blood. Incorrect Options: Option B - Toxoplasmosis: Toxoplasma is transmitted through nucleated cells in the blood, especially WBC’s. Option C - Malaria: Malaria is transmitted through the RBC’s in the blood. Option D - Filarial infection: Filarial infection is mainly transmitted through the plasma of the blood.

questions.question: A female patient presents with swollen Bartholin glands. Discharging pus showed gram negative intracellular diplococci. Which is the organism?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Neisseria gonorrhoeae:   In women, the initial infection involves the urethra and the cervix uteri and it can extend to Bartholin’s glands, the endometrium and the fallopian tubes.   On microscopy the Gram negative diplococci present in pairs can be seen. Incorrect Options: Option B - Chlamydia: Chlamydia appears as a cluster of spores like on microscopy. Option C - Chancroid: The bacilli may be arranged in small groups or whorls or in parallel chains, giving a 'school of fish' or 'railroad track' appearance. Option D - Syphilis: Syphilis on dark microscopy shows thin forward and backward moving organisms.

questions.solution: Correct Option B - R. prowazekii:   The clinical presentation of a febrile patient with rash sparing palms and soles and lice infestation is suggestive of epidemic typhus, which is caused by the bacterium Rickettsia prowazekii.   Rickettsia prowazekii is a gram-negative, obligate intracellular bacterium that is transmitted to humans through the bites of infected lice.   The bacterium infects endothelial cells, causing vasculitis and capillary leakage, which leads to the characteristic rash and other systemic manifestations.   Treatment for epidemic typhus involves the use of antibiotics such as doxycycline or chloramphenicol. Supportive care may also be necessary, including management of hypotension and fluid resuscitation. Incorrect Options: Option A - Rickettsia typhi: Rickettsia typhi causes endemic or murine typhus, which is typically transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas. The clinical presentation of endemic typhus is similar to epidemic typhus, but the rash typically appears on the trunk and spreads to the extremities, including the palms and soles. Option C - Rickettsia akari: Rickettsia akari causes rickettsial pox, which is typically transmitted to humans through the bites of infected mites. The clinical presentation of rickettsialpox includes fever, headache, and a papulovesicular rash that typically starts at the site of the mite bite and spreads to other areas of the body. Option D - Rickettsia conorii: Rickettsia conorii causes Indian tick typus, which is typically transmitted to humans through the bites of infected ticks. The clinical presentation includes fever, headache, myalgias, and a maculopapular rash that typically starts on the extremities and spreads to the trunk. The palms and soles may be involved in some cases.

questions.question: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of diphtheria toxin?

options.A: ADP phosphorylation of EF-2 - Decreasing protein synthesis

questions.question: A 40-year-old farmer presents with retro-orbital pain, burning red eyes, conjunctival suffusion, fever with chills, calf tenderness, and joint pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Leptospirosis:   Leptospirosis is a bacterial infection caused by Leptospira species. The given clinical features, especially conjunctival suffusion, are characteristic of leptospirosis. Incorrect Options:   Options A, B, and D do not show signs of conjunctival suffusion and calf tenderness.

questions.question: A patient from a military background presents with fever, a rash, and neck rigidity. Laboratory investigations reveal a lack of membrane-attacking complex. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Neisseria meningitidis:   Neisseria meningitidis is the likely cause of bacterial meningitis. The symptoms of fever, rash, and neck rigidity, combined with the deficiency in the membrane-attacking complex, are consistent with this diagnosis. Incorrect Options: Option B - Neisseria gonorrhoea: Neisseria gonorrhea primarily affects the genital tract and anorectal region and is not associated with meningitis. Option C - Klebsiella: Klebsiella causes community-acquired pneumonia, catheter-associated UTI, and sepsis. Option D - CMV: Cytomegalovirus typically causes hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, and purpuric rashes.

questions.question: A female patient with a urinary tract infection (UTI) has more than 10^4 colonies of novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus. What is the appropriate course of action?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Consider UTI:   The presence of novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus (likely Staphylococcus saprophyticus) in significant numbers (>10^4 colonies) suggests a urinary tract infection. Incorrect Options:   Options B, C, and D are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.question: A child presents with chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and cerebral calcifications. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Toxoplasma:   The triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and cerebral calcifications is characteristic of congenital toxoplasmosis caused by Toxoplasma gondii. Incorrect Options:   Options B, C, and D do not cause cerebral calcifications.

questions.question: A patient has a history of infection by Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC) 0157, H7. What does the "H" represent?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Flagella:   The "H" in EHEC 0157, H7, refers to the flagella of Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli. Incorrect Options:   Options A, C, and D are not denoted by “H”.

questions.question: An adult man presents with a purulent discharge from the urethra with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse. On microscopy, gram-negative intracellular cocci are noticed. What is the drug of choice (DOC) for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Tab Cefixime 400mg:   Cefixime or ceftriaxone is the drug of choice for treating gonorrhea, which is the likely cause of purulent urethral discharge after unprotected sexual intercourse and as gram-negative diplococci in pairs are seen in the image. Incorrect Options:   Options B, C, and D are not preferred in the management of gonorrhea.

questions.question: A regular contact lens user presents with corneal ulcers and diminished vision. He was very careless about his lens fluid. On microscopy, an organism with spikes is identified. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Acanthamoeba:   Acanthamoeba is most likely responsible for this patient's condition. Acanthamoeba keratitis is associated with improper use of contact lenses, and spikes are seen on microscopy. Incorrect Options:   Options B, C, and D are not responsible for causing this patient’s condition, as explained above.

questions.question: A traveler with a history of oyster consumption presents with diarrhea, abdominal pain, and vomiting. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - V. Parahemolyticum:   Vibrio parahaemolyticus is a common cause of gastroenteritis linked to the consumption of raw or undercooked seafood, especially oysters. The typical symptoms include diarrhea, abdominal pain, and vomiting, often appearing within 24 hours of ingestion. Incorrect Options: Option A - S. Typhi: S. Typhi causes enteric fever. Option C - Staphylococcus: Staphylococcus aureus can cause food poisoning after consumption of stale meats and dairy products. Option D - Cholera: Vibrio cholerae causes cholera, characterized by severe, watery diarrhea ("rice water stools").

questions.question: A farmer suffered a wound on the dorsum of his foot. It later involved the subcutaneous tissue and became a discharging ulcer. Microscopy reveals gram-positive branching filaments. Identify the organism.
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Nocardia:   Nocardia is a gram-positive bacterium that forms branching filaments and is often associated with causing cutaneous infections in immunocompetent individuals. Incorrect Options: Option B - Sporothrix: Patients with sporotrichosis will usually present with a history of thorn prick followed by ulcers/pustules formation at the trauma site and lymphadenopathy. Option C - Histoplasma: Histoplasmosis is caused by bat or bird droppings and affects the reticuloendothelial system. Option D - Candida: On microscopy, candida will appear as both buds and pseudohyphae forms.

questions.question: Patient with HIV presenting with bouts of cough and fever. Which medium is appropriate for diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium Explanation: A patient with HIV presenting with cough and fever raises suspicion of tuberculosis (TB), which is common in immunocompromised individuals. Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium is a specialized culture medium used to isolate Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Lab Investigations for TB: Investigation sPurpose Advantages Limitations Sputum smearInitial screening for pulmonary TB. Samples are stained using the Ziehl-Neelsen method or Auramine-O stain to visualize acid-fast bacilli (AFB) under a microscope.Quick and inexpensive. Can provide results within a few hours.Low sensitivity, especially in cases of extrapulmonary TB or in patients with HIV. Cannot differentiate between Mycobacterium tuberculosis and non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM). Culture MethodsConfirm the diagnosis of TB and assess drug susceptibility. Solid Media: Sputum is inoculated onto solid culture media like Löwenstein-Jensen or Middlebrook agar. Liquid Media: Automated systems like BACTEC or MGIT are used to detect growth faster.The gold standard for TB diagnosis. Allows for drug susceptibility testing.Time-consuming; results can take weeks. Requires specialized laboratory facilities. Xpert MTB/ RIFDetects Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance. Method: A cartridge-based system that performs nucleic acid amplification (NAAT). Sputum or other specimens are processed directly in the cartridge.Rapid results (within 2 hours). High sensitivity and specificity. Simultaneously detects rifampicin resistance.More expensive than smear microscopy. Does not provide full drug susceptibility testing. LAMP (Loop -Mediated Isothermal Amplificatio n)Detects DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosi s. Method: Amplifies DNA at a constant temperature without the need for thermal cycling. Sputum or other specimens are used.Rapid results (within 1-2 hours). High specificity and sensitivity. Can be performed at the point of care. Used for patients with HIV with CD4+ counts of less than 100 cells/ µL irrespective of signs and symptoms of TB.Less widely available than PCR-based tests. Cannot detect drug resistance directly. TrueNat Point-of-care test for TB detection. Method: Uses a micro-PCR technology to amplify DNA. Results are available within 60 minutes.Portable and easy to use in peripheral health facilities. Provides results quickly, facilitating immediate treatment decisions. Line Probe Assay (LPA)Detects TB and drug resistance (rifampicin and isoniazid). Method: Sputum samples are processed, and DNA is extracted. Amplified DNA is hybridized to specific probes on a membrane strip.Rapid results (within 1-2 days). Can detect multiple mutations associated with drug resistance.Requires a laboratory setup and trained personnel. Not suitable for all strains of TB. RFLP IS6110 restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis is widely used for molecular epidemiological studies of tuberculosis. Restriction enzymes Nru I, EcoN I, Pst I, and Pvu II were used to analyze IS6110 fingerprints in Mycobacterium tuberculosi s strains H37Rv (virulent) and H37Ra (avirulent). Tinsdale medium (Option A) is used for Corynebacterium diphtheriae, which causes diphtheria. MacConkey agar (Option C) is used for gram-negative bacteria, particularly enteric pathogens like E. coli and Klebsiella. Loeffler serum slope (LSS) (Option D) enhances the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.question: A firefighter was admitted with fever, cough, culture shown in the image reveals gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacilli. Colonies transilluminating while passing under UV light. Choose the correct agent.
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa Explanation: The firefighter with fever and cough has a culture showing gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacilli with fluorescent colonies under UV light, which is characteristic of Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Diagnostic Tests for Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Diagnostic MethodDescription Specific Features for Pseudomonas aeruginosa Sample Collecti onCollect specimens such as sputum, urine, wound swabs, blood, ear discharge, eye discharge, or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).Specimens vary based on the site of infection. Microscopy Gram stain Gram-negative rods; motile with flagella. Culture Growth on common laboratory media: Blood agar Produces beta-hemolytic gray, moist colonies. MacConkey agarProduces pale, non-lactose fermenting colonies, Fluorescence under UV light. Nutrient agar Produces large, irregular colonies with a metallic sheen. Peptone water Forms uniform turbidity with surface pellicle. Cetrimide Agar Selective medium that inhibits other Gram-negative bacteria; specifically selected for Pseudomonas aeruginosa; pigment production (e.g., pyocyanin). King’s medium used to increase pigment production by pseudomonas Biochemical TestsVarious biochemical tests to identify specific metabolic properties: Oxidase test Positive Catalase test Positive ICUT Test: Indole test Negative Citrate test Positive Urease test Negative Triple sugar testShows alkaline slant with no gas and hydrogen sulfide. Molecular MethodsPCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction), 16S rRNA sequencingProvides specific and sensitive detection of Pseudomonas aeruginosa DNA. Antimicrobial Susceptibility TestingDisk diffusion method, Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) testingDetermines the susceptibility of Pseudomonas aeruginosa to various antibiotics. Klebsiella (Option A): Although Gram-negative, it is oxidase-negative. It does not produce fluorescent pigments under UV light and typically forms mucoid colonies due to its capsule. Staphylococcus aureus (Option B) is Gram-positive, whereas the given organism is Gram-negative. It does not produce fluorescent pigments under UV light and forms golden-yellow colonies, not greenish ones. Serratia (Option D) is Gram-negative and oxidase-negative. Some Serratia species produce red pigment (prodigiosin), but they do not fluoresce under UV light like Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

questions.question: A group of students consumed fried rice in a restaurant. Six hours later, they start vomiting. What is the etiological agent?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Bacillus cereus Explanation: Bacillus cereus causes rapid-onset vomiting (within 1–6 hours) after consuming contaminated fried rice. Clinical Features of Bacillus cereus: Table rendering failed Diagnosis of Bacillus cereus: Diagnostic Method Details Food Poisoning Culture of implicated food essential. >105 B. cereus cells per gram confirms the diagnosis. questions.question: A farmer presents with fever and subconjunctival hemorrhage. The microscopic agglutination test turns to be positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Leptospira Explanation: A farmer with fever and subconjunctival hemorrhage along with a positive microscopic agglutination test points toward Leptospira infection (Leptospirosis). Leptospirosis: Causative Agent Leptospira interrogans (bacteria) Transmission Zoonotic disease Indirect: Contact with water, moist soil, or surfaces contaminated with animal urine. Direct: Contact with urine or parturition products from infected animals. Pathogenesis PhasesSepticemic Phase: Entry through mucosa or skin, dissemination via bloodstream to organs. Immune Phase: Antibodies develop, spirochetes disappear from blood; antigen-antibody complexes form, and renal colonization occurs. Clinical Syndrom esMild Anicteric Illness: Seen in 90% of cases, flu-like symptoms with fever, headache, conjunctival suffusion, nausea, vomiting, and myalgia. Weil’s Disease: Severe icteric illness in 10% of cases; rapid progression, fatality rate of 5-15%. Culture Media ... (content truncated) Diagnosis Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT): Considered the gold standard for Leptospira detection, MAT measures antibodies in serum samples. The Modified Faine’s Criteria used to aid in the diagnosis of leptospirosis, especially in endemic areas.This scoring system combines clinical, epidemiological and laboratory data to increase diagnostic accuracy. PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction): Provides a faster diagnosis by detecting leptospira DNA in blood or urine, especially effective in the early stage. ELISA: Used for antibody detection and is helpful for confirming infection in the later stages. Treatment Antibiotics: Early antibiotic therapy is crucial and often involves: Doxycycline: Typically used for mild cases and prophylaxis. Penicillin or Ampicillin: Preferred for severe cases. Brucella (Option A) causes undulant fever and hepatosplenomegaly but does not cause subconjunctival hemorrhage. The standard test is the serum agglutination test (SAT), not the microscopic agglutination test (MAT). Escherichia coli (Option C) primarily causes gastrointestinal and urinary tract infections and is not associated with conjunctival hemorrhage, or a positive MAT. Staphylococcus aureus (Option D) causes skin infections, pneumonia, and endocarditis but does not cause subconjunctival hemorrhage or a positive MAT, which is specific for Leptospira.

questions.question: A 70-year-old man was admitted with a murmur and blood culture positive for Gram-positive cocci. Choose the common agent causing prosthetic valve infective endocarditis.
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Staphylococcus epidermidis Explanation: Staphylococcus epidermidis, a coagulase-negative Staphylococcus (CoNS), is the most common cause of prosthetic valve infective endocarditis. It is a leading cause of healthcare-associated IE, often seen in intravenous drug users (IVDU) and patients with catheters or implanted devices. Though they can infect prosthetic valves, they are not the primary causative agent.

questions.question: A patient’s laboratory results were positive for malarial antigen, and the Widal test findings were as follows: O ag >1:300, H ag >1:20, A >1:20, B >1:20. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Recent infection by Salmonella spp Explanation: A significantly elevated O antigen titer (>1:300) only in the Widal test suggests a recent Salmonella infection. Widal Test:   It is a highly sensitive but poorly specific serological test used to diagnose typhoid fever caused by Salmonella typhi.   It detects specific antibodies in the patient's serum that react with the antigens of Salmonella typhi. questions.question: MOA of botulinum toxin is
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Inhibits the release of acetylcholine Explanation: The mechanism of action of botulinum toxin is inhibition of acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction. Mechanism of Action of Botulinum Toxin: Botulinum toxin binds to acetylcholine receptors at neuromuscular junctions, preventing the release of acetylcholine, which is essential for muscle contraction. This leads to flaccid paralysis, a hallmark of botulism. Inhibits Elongation Factor 2 (Option A): This describes the MOA of Diphtheria toxin and Pseudomonas exotoxin A, which inhibit protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylation of Elongation Factor-2 (EF-2), leading to cell death. Inhibits the release of GABA (Option B): This describes the action of Tetanus toxin, which blocks inhibitory neurotransmitters (GABA and glycine) in the spinal cord, causing spastic paralysis. Increases cAMP (Option D): Toxins that increase cyclic AMP (cAMP) include cholera toxin and pertussis toxin, which cause fluid secretion (diarrhea) and immune modulation, respectively.

questions.question: A person with the H/o long-term sexual relationship presented with painful ulcers on his genitals with tender lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis?

questions.question: A patient admitted with fever and nuchal rigidity. CSF analysis shows decreased glucose and increased protein and neutrophils. Choose the correct treatment
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Ceftriaxone Explanation: The clinical scenario of a patient with fever, nuchal rigidity, and CSF findings of decreased glucose, increased protein, and neutrophilic pleocytosis points towards a diagnosis of bacterial meningitis. Ceftriaxone is the first-line antibiotic for treatment of bacterial meningitis. Bacterial Meningitis in Adults and Prevention Causes Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitides are the primary causes. Listeria monocytogenes is a significant risk in adults over 50, especially in those with diabetes, alcoholism, or weakened immune systems. Pathophysiological Process Classic Triad of Symptoms Fever Headache Nuchal rigidity (stiff neck) CSF Findings Opening pressure: Elevated Predominant cell type: Polymorphonuclear neutrophils (PMNs) Protein: Elevated Glucose: Decreased Gross appearance: Turbid Treatment Immediate Management: Start with intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover pathogens. First-line antibiotic of choice: Ceftriaxone Treatment is then adjusted based on the identified organism and its susceptibility Adjunctive Therapy: Dexamethasone may be given to reduce inflammation and prevent complications, particularly if administered early. Supportive Care: Manage complications like raised intracranial pressure and seizures. Prevention Vaccines for H. influenzae type b, N. meningitidis, and S. pneumoniae. No vaccine currently exists for group B meningococcal infections. Chemoprophylaxis: Close contacts of individuals with meningococcal meningitis should receive prophylactic antibiotics like rifampicin, ciprofloxacin, azithromycin or ceftriaxone to reduce the risk of secondary infections. Rifampicin - 600 mg 12 hourly for 2 days Ciprofloxacin - 500 mg single dose Azithromycin 500 mg single dose Ceftriaxone - 250 mg Intramuscular single dose Ampicillin (Option A) is primarily used in Listeria monocytogenes meningitis, which is more common in neonates, elderly, and immunocompromised patients. It is not first-line for typical bacterial meningitis in healthy adults. Penicillin (Option C) was historically used for Neisseria meningitidis but is not sufficient as monotherapy due to increasing resistance. Empirical therapy requires broader coverage. Vancomycin (Option D) is used in combination with Ceftriaxone when penicillin-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae is suspected, but it is not sufficient alone.

questions.question: KAT G mutation associated with:
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Isoniazid Explanation: The katG mutation causes Isoniazid resistance by preventing its activation inside Mycobacterium tuberculosis, making the drug ineffective. Mechanisms of Isoniazid Resistance KatG gene mutation INH is a prodrug, converted to the active form by catalase-peroxidase produced by the Kat G gene. The mutated catalase enzyme does not form the active drug KasA gene mutation Component of cell wall mycolic acid InhA gene overexpression Causes cross-resistance to Ethionamide (second-line drug) Rifampicin (Option B) resistance is associated with mutations in the rpoB gene (RNA polymerase β-subunit), not KAT G. Levofloxacin (Option C) resistance is linked to mutations in the gyrA and gyrB genes, which encode DNA gyrase, a key enzyme for bacterial DNA replication. Ethambutol (Option D) resistance is associated with mutations in the embB gene, which affects arabinosyl transferase, an enzyme involved in mycobacterial cell wall synthesis.

questions.question: Based on the properties of viruses, which of the following sentences is not true?

questions.question: Identify the mismatched pair of viruses and their site of viral replication. Adenovirus - Cytosol Poxvirus - Cytosol Parvovirus - Nucleus HIV - Mixed
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Adenovirus - Cytosol Explanation: Adenovirus - Cytosol is a mismatched pair because adenovirus is a DNA virus that replicates in the nucleus, similar to most DNA viruses.   Most DNA viruses replicate within the nucleus of the host cells, with a few exceptions, such as poxvirus, which replicates in the cytosol (Option A).   Examples of DNA viruses: Hepadna virus, Reovirus, Parvovirus (Option C), Adenovirus (Option B) and Papovavirus   Most RNA viruses replicate in the cytosol of the host cells except for orthomyxovirus and retroviruses(HIV) (Option D), which synthesise their RNA in the nucleus.

VIRAL REPLICATION Attachment: Receptor interaction between viral surface antigen and host cell surface antigens. HIV: Viral surface gp120 binds to CD 24 on host cells. Influenza: Viral hemagglutinin binds to glycoprotein receptors on respiratory epithelium Penetration: Viral particle enters the host cells via - Phagocytosis/viropexis (receptor mediated endocytosis occurs) Membrane fusion (some enveloped viruses enter via fusion of their membrane with the host cell membrane; thus, only the nucleocapsid enters). Injection of nucleic acid by bacteriophages. Uncoating: Host cell lysosomal enzymes separate the viral capsid and nucleic acid. Biosynthesis Nucleic acid replication DNA viruses replicate within the nucleus except for the Pox virus, which replicates in the cytosol. questions.question: A 6-month-old infant presents with a 1-week history of fever, irritability, decreased appetite, and lethargy. Examination reveals high temperature, moderate hepatomegaly, and purpura/petechiae on the trunk and extremities. CBC shows thrombocytopenia and leukopenia. ELISA detects antibodies for antigen PP65. What is the cause of the condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) HHV 5 Explanation: The presentation suggests cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, caused by Human Herpesvirus 5 (HHV-5), indicated by fever, hepatomegaly, petechiae/purpura, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, and the detection of antibodies to the specific CMV antigen PP65 via ELISA. HHV 2 (Option B), also known as Herpes simplex virus 2, primarily causes genital herpes.   While it can cause severe disease in newborns, especially during delivery (neonatal herpes), it does not typically present with the systemic symptoms described in this infant's presentation.   Like HHV 1, it is not associated with the PP65 antigen. HHV 4 (Option C) is the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), primarily associated with infectious mononucleosis and certain lymphoproliferative disorders.   It does not show antibodies against the PP65 antigen.

questions.question: A 24-year-old male wrestler presents with a painful rash on his forehead and neck, initially small red bumps that developed into fluid-filled blisters (shown in the image). He reports fever and malaise for the past few days. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Herpes gladiatorum Explanation: The scenario describes a wrestler with painful fluid-filled blisters and flu-like symptoms, which is diagnosed as Herpes gladiatorum, also known as Wrestler’s Herpes. Herpes gladiatorum:   A cutaneous lesion observed in infections caused by the Herpes simplex virus.   Transmission: Contact sports, like wrestling, due to skin-to-skin contact in athletes.   Feature: Painful, fluid-filled blisters on the skin, accompanied by symptoms like fever and malaise.   Treatment: Antiviral medications   Prevention: Good hygiene practices during sports. Herpetic whitlow (Option A) is another type of cutaneous lesion associated with HSV infection.   It commonly occurs on the fingers of doctors and healthcare workers who have been exposed to infected patients. Herpes zoster (Option C), or shingles, is caused by the Varicella zoster virus (HHV 3).   It occurs when the virus reactivates and travels along sensory nerves, producing zoster lesions in the affected skin area, often accompanied by neuritic pain. Eczema herpeticum (Option D) is another cutaneous lesion linked to HSV infection.   It presents as generalised clusters of vesicles on the affected area, often accompanied by widespread ulceration, and is typically seen in children with eczema.

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman at 20 weeks gestation reports a mild rash, fever, and flu-like symptoms after exposure to a child with a rash. Ultrasound shows cicatricial lesions, limb hypoplasia, microcephaly, and intrauterine growth restriction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Congenital varicella syndrome Explanation:   The scenario describes a pregnant woman at 20 weeks of gestation with flu-like symptoms, fever, and a rash, while the fetus shows limb hypoplasia, microcephaly, and cicatricial lesions, indicating a diagnosis of Congenital (or fetal) Varicella Syndrome. Congenital Varicella Syndrome: If a pregnant woman contracts the varicella-zoster virus during the first 20 weeks of gestation, the virus may be transmitted to the fetus through the placenta, leading to congenital (or fetal) varicella syndrome.   Clinical features (fetus): Cicatricial skin lesion Limb hypoplasia Microcephaly Cortical atrophy Chorioretinitis Some babies may carry latent infection without exhibiting any defects. Congenital rubella syndrome (Option A) occurs when a mother transmits rubella to her fetus, resulting in miscarriage or classic triad of cataract, patent ductus arteriosus and sensorineural hearing loss and also various complications such as hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenic purpura, myocarditis, and bone lesions. Congenital toxoplasmosis (Option C) occurs when non-immune mothers are infected with Toxoplasma gondii during pregnancy.   This can lead to stillbirths, chorioretinitis, intracranial calcifications, psychomotor disturbances, and conditions such as hydrocephaly or microcephaly.   The classic triad of neurological findings consists of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications. Congenital CMV infection (Option D) results from a cytomegalovirus infection during pregnancy and can lead to fetal death or cytomegalic inclusion disease in newborns, often characterised by hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, thrombocytopenic purpura, hemolytic anaemia, and a "blueberry muffin rash" with purplish-blue spots due to extramedullary hematopoiesis, where blood cell production occurs outside the bone marrow.   Survivors may experience mental retardation and developmental delays.

questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Glandular fever Explanation: The clinical presentation suggests an Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) or HHV 4 (human herpes virus type 4) infection, diagnosed as Infectious Mononucleosis (also known as Kissing Disease or Glandular Fever). Epstein-Barr virus (EBV):   Route of infection: Close contact, kissing, sexual intercourse, blood transfusion, bone marrow transplant.   Site of latency: B cells   Family: Herpesviridae (gamma (γ) or gammaherpesviruses)   Clinical conditions: Infectious mononucleosis EBV-associated malignancies: Burkitt's lymphoma, lymphomas in immunodeficient (AIDS and transplant recipients), nasopharyngeal carcinoma.   Infectious mononucleosis   EBV-associated malignancies: Burkitt's lymphoma, lymphomas in immunodeficient (AIDS and transplant recipients), nasopharyngeal carcinoma.   Pathogenesis: Polyclonal B cell activation   Infectious mononucleosis   EBV-associated malignancies: Burkitt's lymphoma, lymphomas in immunodeficient (AIDS and transplant recipients), nasopharyngeal carcinoma.   Infectious mononucleosis (Kissing disease or Glandular fever) Incubation period: 4-8 weeks Clinical features: Splenomegaly, hepatitis, encephalitis, fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, arthralgia, lethargy. Microscopy: Downey cells: Atypical lymphocytes (large, vacuolated) are observed. Appearance: Ballerina skirt appearance.   Incubation period: 4-8 weeks   Clinical features: Splenomegaly, hepatitis, encephalitis, fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, arthralgia, lethargy.   Microscopy: Downey cells: Atypical lymphocytes (large, vacuolated) are observed. Appearance: Ballerina skirt appearance.   Downey cells: Atypical lymphocytes (large, vacuolated) are observed.   Appearance: Ballerina skirt appearance.   Incubation period: 4-8 weeks   Clinical features: Splenomegaly, hepatitis, encephalitis, fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, arthralgia, lethargy. Influenza (Option A), commonly known as the flu, is a contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses.   It can affect people of all ages and is characterised by sudden onset of fever, body aches, and respiratory symptoms (hepatosplenomegaly and atypical lymphocytes are not characteristic of influenza). Toxoplasmosis (Option B) is an infection caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii.   It is one of the most prevalent parasitic infections in humans and presents with symptoms such as mild flu-like signs (fever, muscle aches), swollen lymph nodes, fatigue, and headaches (without atypical lymphocytes). CMV (Cytomegalovirus) infection (Option C) is often asymptomatic; however, in some cases, it can present with flu-like symptoms such as fever, fatigue, and sore throat.   Microscopy reveals the characteristic "owl-eye" appearance of the infected cells.

questions.question: A 21-year-old male presents with extreme fatigue, a severe sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes for two weeks, with similar recent symptoms in his partner. Examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly and cervical lymphadenopathy, and lab results showed a high percentage of atypical lymphocytes. All the following malignancies are associated with it except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Angiosarcoma Explanation:   The patient's presentation is consistent with infectious mononucleosis (kissing disease or glandular fever), likely caused by Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV).   Angiosarcoma is a rare malignancy of endothelial cells and is not associated with EBV infection. Malignancies associated with EBV: Types of malignancy Examples Carcinoma Gastric carcinoma (most common) (Option C) Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (Option D) Lymphoma Hodgkin’s lymphoma (most common lymphocyte depletion and mixed cellularity) Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma Burkitt’s lymphoma (Option B) DLBCL (diffuse large B cell lymphoma) Post-transplant lymphoma T or NK cell lymphoma Sarcoma Leiomyosarcoma

questions.question: A 22-year-old male college student comes in with a 1-week history of fever, significant fatigue, sore throat, and swollen cervical lymph nodes. Examination shows elevated temperature, bilateral tender lymphadenopathy, and tonsillar enlargement with exudate. His CBC reveals leukocytosis with atypical lymphocytes. How does the heterophile agglutination test aid in diagnosing his condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Antibodies react with sheep RBC Explanation:   The heterophile agglutination (Paul-Bunnell test) test, also known as the Monospot test, is used to diagnose infectious mononucleosis, typically caused by Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV).   It detects heterophile antibodies that react with antigens on non-human red blood cells, such as sheep or horse RBCs. Investigations for EBV Peripheral smear Initially, leukopenia is noted, often followed by leukocytosis as the condition progresses. The presence of atypical mononuclear cells (derived from cytotoxic T cells) exhibits basophilic vacuolated cytoplasm and kidney-shaped nuclei (Downey cells). Ballerina skirt appearance: Characteristic morphology where atypical lymphocytes have cytoplasm that extends and flares, resembling a ballerina’s skirt. {{caption_text}} Serology Heterophile antibody test (Non-specific antibody test)Paul-Bunnell test: Heterophile antibodies react with Sheep RBC. Monospot test: Heterophile antibodies react with Horse RBC. Specific antibody test (ELISA or Immunofluore scence)lgM antibody against Viral Capsid antigen (earliest antigen) (Option C). Antibody against the EB nuclear antigen (EBNA) (Option B). Antibodies against early antigens (Option A). Culture For Virus isolation Not commonly used. Other tests PCR Nucleic acid hybridisation test (Most sensitive & specific)

questions.question: A 7-year-old boy has been brought to the clinic with a painful blistering rash around his mouth for the past three days, accompanied by a low-grade fever and irritability. Examination reveals lesions as below and cervical lymphadenopathy. The mother mentions a history of recurrent cold sores. What is the most appropriate management for this child?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Acyclovir Explanation:   The child's presentation of a painful blistering rash around the mouth, low-grade fever, irritability, and a history of recurrent cold sores suggests an outbreak of Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.   Acyclovir is the first-line antiviral treatment for herpes simplex virus infections, including oral herpes in children.   It is ineffective against CMV because it targets thymidine kinase, an enzyme in herpes simplex virus (HSV) and varicella-zoster virus (VZV), but it is absent in CMV.   Valacyclovir and Famciclovir are also effective for managing HSV 1 and 2.   Foscarnet is used in conditions that are resistant to the above antivirals. Valganciclovir (Option A) is a prodrug of Ganciclovir.   It is mostly used to manage CMV, especially in the case of CMV retinitis. Ganciclovir (Option B) is the drug of choice to manage CMV and is also used to manage EBV; in case of resistance, Foscarnet can be used. Cidofovir (Option C) can be used to manage both CMV and HSV infections. It is effective against many acyclovir-resistant HSV and ganciclovir-resistant CMV cases.   However, it is nephrotoxic, so it should be used under caution.

questions.question: A 2-year-old child presents with a sudden high fever for 3 days, followed by a rose-coloured maculopapular rash that starts on the trunk and spreads to the face and extremities. The child is well-hydrated and active. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the diagnosis of this condition?

options.A: HHV-6 shows limited antigenic cross-reactivity with HHV-7.
options.B: HHV-6 can cause symptoms similar to infectious mononucleosis.
options.C: HHV 6 and 7 both bind to T- cells.
options.D: HHV-6 causes the above condition, and HHV-7 is not related to it.

questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) HHV-6 causes the above condition, and HHV-7 is not related to it. Explanation:   The child's sudden high fever, followed by a rose-coloured maculopapular rash, indicates roseola infantum, primarily caused by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6).   While HHV-6 causes the condition, HHV-7 is related and can cause similar illnesses.   HHV-6 shows some antigenic cross-reactivity with HHV-7, and both bind to T-cells via CD46 (Options A and C).   HHV-6 has 2 variants, i.e. A and B.   Both HHV 6 & 7 spreads through saliva. Conditions caused HHV 6 In children: Sixth disease/ Roseola/ Exanthem Subitum (sudden high fever followed by a distinctive rash) In adults: Infectious mononucleosis-like symptoms and focal encephalitis (Option B) In Immunodeficient - Pneumonia and Disseminated disease. HHV 7 Causes Sixth disease/ Roseola/ Exanthem Subitum in children

questions.question: A 35-year-old man with HIV presents with fever, weight loss, and reddish-purple raised skin lesions. options.A: HHV 8 can cause primary effusion lymphoma

This can also be transmitted through   Sexual contact   Vertical transmission   Blood transfusion   Organ transplants HHV 8 Investigations PCR Serological tests: Indirect immunofluorescence, Western blot and ELISA. questions.question: A 9-year-old boy presents with fever, malaise, and a bright red "slapped cheek" rash on his face, which later spreads to his trunk and extremities. Blood tests reveal mild anaemia. The clinical diagnosis of erythema infectiosum is made. What are the characteristics of the virus responsible for this condition?
questions.solution: orrect Answer: A) Non-enveloped single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) virus Explanation: The clinical scenario describes erythema infectiosum, a disease caused by parvovirus B19. Characteristics of Parvovirus B19:   Genome: Single-stranded DNA (ssDNA).   Envelope: Non-enveloped, making it resistant to environmental conditions.   Size: It is among the smallest DNA viruses.   Tropism: Targets erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow, causing the transient aplastic crisis in patients with hemolytic disorders. Enveloped ssDNA virus (Option B): No known ssDNA viruses are enveloped. Enveloped dsDNA virus (Option C) includes herpesviruses, which cause different clinical syndromes (e.g., herpes simplex, chickenpox). Non-enveloped dsDNA virus (Option D) includes adenoviruses, which typically cause respiratory or gastrointestinal infections, not erythema infectiosum.

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman with sickle cell disease presents with pallor, fatigue, and weakness. Her hemoglobin is significantly decreased, with a low reticulocyte count. She reports recent exposure to her child, who had a finding as shown in the image below. Given the virus's specific tropism, which maternal or fetal tissue is primarily affected in this scenario?

options.A: Fetal liver, targeting erythroid progenitor cells
options.B: Fetal bone marrow, affecting myeloid progenitor cells

questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Fetal liver, targeting erythroid progenitor cells Explanation:   This case suggests Parvovirus B19 infection due to recent exposure to a child with a “slapped cheek” rash and the patient’s anemia with low reticulocytes, indicating a transient aplastic crisis.   Parvovirus B19 specifically targets erythroid progenitor cells by binding to the P antigen, halting red blood cell production.   In the fetus, this viral tropism affects the fetal liver. Parvovirus {{caption_text}}Morphology Simplest animal viruses infecting humans, responsible for erythema infectiosum (fifth disease). Smallest viruses (18–26 nm in size). Non-enveloped with icosahedral symmetry. Only DNA viruses with single-stranded DNA. Dependent on host cell enzymes for replication. Pathogenesis Exclusively infects humans. Transmission: Primarily through the respiratory route. Blood transfusion. Transplacental transmission. Target Cells: Tropism for erythroid progenitor cells in adult bone marrow and fetal liver. (Option A) Receptor Binding: Binds to blood group P antigen on RBC surface. Effects: Leads to RBC destruction and inhibition of erythropoiesis, potentially causing anemia.   Parvovirus B19 targets erythroid progenitor cells, not myeloid progenitor cells (Option B), leading to anemia rather than affecting white blood cell function.   The virus does not specifically affect the fetal spleen (Option C); its primary pathology occurs in the bone marrow and fetal liver.   Parvovirus B19 does not target trophoblasts in the placenta (Option D); its main impact is on erythropoiesis in the fetal liver, not direct placental damage.

questions.question: A 14-year-old boy presents with a 5-day history of painful, itchy swelling and erythema of his hands and feet, following mild flu-like symptoms that resolved a few days ago. Examination reveals the following findings, as shown in the image below. What syndrome is this child exhibiting, and which pathogen is it associated with?

options.B: Papular-purpuric gloves and socks syndrome; Parvovirus B19
options.C: Hand, foot, and mouth disease; Coxsackievirus

questions.solution: Correct answer: Papular-purpuric gloves and socks syndrome; Parvovirus B19 Explanation: In this scenario, painful, itchy swelling and erythema of the hands and feet, along with B/L papular lesions on his palms and soles as shown in the figure, indicate papular-purpuric gloves and socks syndrome associated with Parvovirus B19.   This syndrome typically follows mild viral symptoms, aligning with the boy's recent flu-like illness.   Parvovirus B19 targets erythroid progenitor cells, leading to the characteristic rash. Clinical Manifestations of Parvovirus infections: ... (content truncated)Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease) (Option A ) Children: "Slapped cheek" facial rash. Adult women: Symmetrical polyarthropathy, often in hand and knee joints. Transient Aplastic Crisis: Severe acute anemia in patients with pre-existing hemolytic anemia. Pure Red Cell Aplasia: Chronic anemia in immunocompromised individuals due to persistent B19 infection. Non-Immune Hydrops Fetalis: Fatal fetal anemia and death; occurs via transplacental transmission (30% of cases) Highest risk in the second trimester. Papular-Purpuric Gloves and Socks Syndrome: Painful, itchy, and symmetric swelling and erythema of distal hands and feet; may mimic acute meningococcemia. (Option B) Laboratory Diagnosis PCR: Highly sensitive, detects viral DNA (VP1, VP2 genes) in serum, tissue, or respiratory secretions. ELISA: Detects IgM antibody (early indicator, elevated 2–3 months) and IgG against VP1 and VP2 antigens. Immunohistochemistry: Detects viral antigens in fetal tissues and bone marrow. Bone marrow cytology shows Giant pro-erythroblasts with multiple cytoplasmic projections that look like "dog ears" or "pseudopodia". marrow aspiration Giant pro-erythroblasts" data-author=""Yadav Kamlesh Pallav Gupta Manjula Murari Rohan Malik"" data-hash="10022" data-license="CC BY 3.0" data-source="https://www.rese archgate.net/figure/Bone-marrow-aspiration-showing-gia nt-proerythroblast-with-prominent-nucleoli-and_fig2_514 94153" data-tags="April2025" height="226" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/Bgvv335TrAMk ZUBfKCz11744457298.png" width="511" /> {{caption_text}}   Hand, foot, and mouth disease (Option C) typically features vesicular lesions on the palms and soles , and around mouth which do not match the boy’s papular lesions and swelling.   It is caused by Coxsackie A16 virus and enterovirus 71. Scarlet fever (Option D) is marked by a diffuse, sandpaper-like rash following a sore throat, inconsistent with the boy's symptoms.

questions.question: A 55-year-old kidney transplant recipient presents with worsening renal function. Urinalysis shows the following finding in the image below. PCR confirms the presence of viral DN

options.A: Which virus is most likely responsible for this patient’s

questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) BK virus Explanation: This case points to BK virus nephropathy, common in kidney transplant recipients, indicated by renal dysfunction and "decoy cells" with enlarged nuclei and ground glass appearance of cytoplasm with basophilic viral inclusions in the urine.   Decoy cells are infected renal tubular epithelial cells found in urine and are a sign of polyomavirus (PV) replication.   BK virus reactivates in immunocompromised hosts, and PCR confirmation of viral DNA aligns with its role in post-transplant nephropathy. Papovaviridae: Papovaviridae includes 2 main genera:   Polyomavirus: Contains simian vacuolating virus (SV40) & human polyomaviruses (JC and BK).   Papillomavirus Polyomavir us MCV Merkel cell polyomavirus. Causes merkel cell cancer. CK7+ & CK 20-ve. SV40 Simian vacuolating virus (SV40) Associated with mesothelioma. BK virus (Option C) {{caption_text}}BK virus is a polyomavirus with double-stranded DNA, typically causing: Nephropathy in kidney transplant recipients. The time period of nephropathy is after 6 months post-transplant. Hemorrhagic cystitis in hematopoietic stem cell transplant recipients. Infections in immunocompetent individuals are often asymptomatic. Cytologic examination of urine can reveal “decoy cells”. These characteristic cells have enlarged nuclei with a single, basophilic, intranuclear inclusion, which mimics cancer cells on pap smear. JC Virus (John Cun ningham) (Option A)Causes Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML Characterized by multifocal demyelination across the brain. Involves the deformation of astrocytes and oligodendrocytes. Primarily occurs in immunocompromised patients and patients taking natalizumab in multiple sclerosis treatment. Cytomegalovirus (Option B) causes systemic infections in transplant patients but doesn’t produce "decoy cells" or nephropathy.   The most common time period of CMV systemic infection is 1-6 months post-transplant. Epstein-Barr virus (Option D) is associated with lymphoproliferative disorders in immunocompromised hosts but does not typically cause nephropathy or produce decoy cells.

questions.question: A 30-year-old female is diagnosed with cervical dysplasia, and HPV testing reveals a high-risk strain. A histopathological examination of her cervical biopsy shows the following findings. Which viral protein is associated with the formation of these findings?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) E5 protein Explanation:   The E5 protein is responsible for the formation of perinuclear vacuoles in infected cells, as shown in the figure, leading to cytoplasmic "halos."   These halos indicate a cytopathic effect associated with E5, as it localizes to the membranes of the endoplasmic reticulum.   The nuclear changes accompanying these vacuoles are referred to as koilocytic atypia. HPV is a DNA virus belonging to the Papillomaviridae family. Tropism: Selectively infects epithelial cells of skin and mucous membranes. Morphology Non-enveloped virus, 50–55 nm in size. Icosahedral capsid containing circular double-stranded DNA (dsDNA). Viral Genome {{caption_text}}Early (E) Region: Includes E1-E7 genes coding for nonstructural proteins. E1 and E2 Proteins: Regulate viral DNA replication. (Option A) E4 Protein: Disrupts cytokeratins to facilitate the release of the virus. E5 Protein: contributes to the formation of perinuclear vacuoles, leading to cytoplasmic “halos.” (Option D) E6 Protein: Promotes degradation of the p53 tumor-suppressor protein. (Option B) E7 Protein: inhibits retinoblastoma protein, contributing to oncogenesis. (Option C) Late (L) Region: L1 and L2 genes code for structural capsid proteins. Types: Over 100 HPV types, classified by DNA sequences in the L1 region. L1 capsid protein is used for making vaccines. HPV Mechanism of Oncogenesis {{caption_text}} E6 Protein: Promotes degradation of p53, blocking apoptosis and inhibiting p53-driven activation of tumor suppressor gene p21. E7 Protein: Inhibits the retinoblastoma (RB) tumor suppressor gene through direct RB inhibition and by interfering with p53 and p21 functions. HPV infection alone is insufficient for malignancy; factors such as co-transfection with v-fos DNA, genetic mutations (e.g., mutated RAS gene), & environmental influences (e.g., smoking, microbial co-infections, dietary deficiencies, hormonal changes) enhance cancer risk.

Associated with serotypes 5 (Option A), 8, 9, 12, 17, 20, 36, and 47. Mucosal involvement Anogenital Warts ... (content truncated) Head and Neck Lesion s {{caption_text}} Benign: Recurrent laryngeal papillomas, especially in children (serotypes 6, 11). (Option B) ... (content truncated) Carcinoma CervixMainly squamous cell carcinoma linked to high-risk serotypes like 16, 18, 31, 33, and others.
