questions.question: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the clinic for her HPV vaccination with the nine-valent HPV vaccine (Gardasil 9). Which of the following HPV types does this vaccine protect against?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58 Explanation: The nine-valent HPV vaccine (Gardasil 9) provides protection against nine HPV types, including high-risk types linked to cervical cancer (16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58) and low-risk types associated with genital warts (6, 11). Laboratory Diagnosis of HPV {{caption_text}} resinoid nucleus" data-author="Jr, Marián & Mezencev, Roman & kašpírková, Jana & Kacerovská, Denisa & Kazakov, Dmitry & Ondic, Ondrej. " data-hash="10053" data-license="CC BY 4.0" data-source="https://www.rese archgate.net/figure/Koilocyte-like-change-in-the-superfici al-part-of-dysplastic-epithelium-characterized-by_fig6_30 4723215" data-tags="April2025" height="283" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/PEWE8HzNywt jDAZnyPMJ1744460350.png" width="307" /> {{caption_text}}Molecular Methods: PCR (gold standard) and hybrid capture assays detect HPV DNA and identify types by targeting E6 and E7 genes. Lesion Detection: Most HPV lesions are visible; 5% acetic acid enhances lesion visibility. Cytologic Evidence: Detected via Papanicolaou (Pap) smears from cervical or anal scrapings show perinuclear cytoplasmic vacuolization termed koilocytosis. Histopathological staining of biopsy samples shows koilocytes with resinoid nuclei. Prevention (HPV Vaccine): Subunit Vaccine: Virus-like particles with HPV L1 proteins produced via DNA recombinant technology. Bivalent Vaccine (Cervarix) Covers high-risk types 16 and 18; administered as a single IM dose. Quadrivalent Vaccine Includes HPV types 6, 11, 16, and 18 Nine-Valent Vaccine (Gardasil 9)Covers 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58. (Option B) Doses: IM at 9-14 months, with 2 doses (6–12 months apart). After age 15, 3 doses (0, 2, and 6 months). Recommended up to age 26 if unvaccinated; better immune response if administered before age 14.

questions.question: A 28-year-old male traveller returns from Central Africa with symptoms of fever and mild skin rashes. On examination, he has lymphadenopathy. He reports having direct contact with wild animals during his trip. Which of the following viruses causes these symptoms?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Monkeypox virus Explanation:   The patient has monkeypox as per his symptoms of fever, skin rashes, and, most importantly lymphadenopathy after a visit and contact with wild animals.   The monkeypox virus causes monkeypox disease, and the clinical symptom of lymphadenopathy differentiates it from other pox virus infections and chickenpox. Poxviruses Poxviruses are the largest viruses that infect vertebrates. Morphology {{caption_text}}Poxviruses measure approximately 400 nm in length and 230 nm in diameter, making them visible under a light microscope. Poxviruses are typically brick-shaped or ellipsoid. They possess an envelope consisting of two lipoprotein membranes (outer and inner), and the outer membrane features ridges. The envelope encases a core, along with two structures of unknown function known as lateral bodies. The core or nucleocapsid is biconcave and shaped like a dumbbell. Poxviruses contain a single linear double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) genome. They are unique among DNA viruses for replicating in the cytoplasm. Human-Important poxviruses Variola is the causative agent of smallpox, the first disease to be eradicated globally. Vaccinia: Used as a vaccine for smallpox. Molluscum contagiosum Virus: Causes warty lesions known as molluscum contagiosum. Genera classification Orthopoxvirus: Smallpox, monkeypox, vaccinia. Molluscipoxvirus: Molluscum contagiosum. Parapoxvirus: Milker’s nodules, bovine papular stomatitis viruses, etc. Capripoxvirus: Sheeppox, goatpox, lumpy skin disease, etc. Avipoxvirus: Fowlpox, pigeon pox, etc. Leporipoxvirus: Myxoma, hare fibroma, etc. Suipoxvirus: Swinepox virus. Yatapoxvirus: Tanapox, Yabapox viruses. Monkeypox infections The monkeypox virus belongs to the Orthopoxvirus genus. Monkeypox is a rare zoonotic infection first recognized in captive monkeys in 1958. Transmission Infection likely occurs through direct contact with wild animals. The exact primary reservoir host remains unidentified, but species such as squirrels, rabbits, and rodents can be infected. Clinical features {{caption_text}}Symptoms resemble those of smallpox but are generally milder. Fever and rash. Lymphadenopathy is a prominent feature in most cases, unlike in smallpox or chickenpox. Complications Respiratory distress Secondary bacterial infections Vaccination The vaccinia vaccine can offer protection against monkeypox or lessen its severity. Human-to-Human transmission Transmission between humans is considered limited. Estimates suggest that only about 15% of close contacts of infected individuals become infected. Variola (Option A):   This virus causes smallpox, characterized by highly contagious and severe rashes, which is a disease eradicated in 1980.   It is caused by two strains of the virus, variola major and minor. Lymphadenopathy is not a sign of this disease. Vaccinia (Option B):   This virus is used in the development of vaccines for smallpox and is even effective in preventing monkeypox.   This is an artificially made virus and does not have any pathogenicity in humans. Varicella (Option D):   This is a human herpes virus that causes chickenpox, a viral infection that has symptoms of fever, malaise, and a rash.   Skin rashes are characteristic of the disease that develop from maculopapules to vesicles to scabs as the disease progresses.

questions.question: A 6-year-old child is brought to the physician as he developed lesions on the body, as below. Which of the following statements would be false about this condition?

options.A: These are caused by molluscum contagiosum virus
options.B: The lesions can be seen all over the body
options.C: This is transmitted through direct and indirect contact

questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) The lesions can be seen all over the body Explanation: The lesions given in the image are of the disease molluscum contagiosum, which is a viral disease caused by a poxvirus and presents with dome-shaped, pink, pearly wart-like lesions that are not found in the palms and soles of the body. Molluscum contagiosum Molluscum contagiosum virus is an obligate human poxvirus known for producing characteristic skin lesions. (Option A) Clinical manifestations {{caption_text}} Lesions: Dome-shaped, pink, pearly wart-like lesions (2–5 mm in size) with a dimple at the center. Lesions can appear singly or in clusters, located anywhere on the body except on the palms and soles. ... (content truncated) Transmission Primarily affects children, transmitted through direct and indirect contact (e.g., barbers, shared towels, swimming pools). (Option C) Rare instances of sexual transmission have been reported in young adults. ... (content truncated)Molluscum bodies: Characteristic intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions were observed in skin scrapings stained with histopathological stains. Confirmation methods: Electron microscopy PCR Cultivation: The virus cannot be propagated in tissue culture, embryonated eggs, or animals. Treatment Surgical removal of the lesions by ablation (by cryotherapy or laser therapy) is the mainstay of treatment. Cidofovir has been shown to have some efficacy.

questions.question: Smallpox was the first infectious disease to be eradicated globally. All the following factors helped eradicate smallpox except.
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Cross-infection from animal pox viruses Explanation: Cross-infection from animal pox viruses is not a factor that helped in the eradication of smallpox even though they produce similar and milder illnesses. Smallpox virus Smallpox was the first infectious disease eradicated globally, characterized by highly contagious and severe rashes. The disease was caused by two strains: variola major and variola minor. Transmission The virus enters through the mucous membranes of the upper respiratory tract via aerosol transmission. ... (content truncated)Incubation period: Typically lasts 12 days (ranging from 7 to 17 days) before the appearance of rashes. Rash characteristics: Unique rashes that are distinguishable from chickenpox. Deep-seated rashes that appear simultaneously in affected areas with a slow evolution. Centrifugal distribution: rashes initially affect the palms, soles, and extensor surfaces. The fever subsides with the appearance of the rash. Exanthem progression: the disease featured a single crop of centrifugal exanthems that progressed through several stages: Macular stage: Flat, discolored lesions. Papular stage: Raised bumps. Vesicular stage: Fluid-filled blisters. Pustular stage: Pus-filled lesions. Laboratory Diagnosis Direct detection: Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies known as Paschen bodies can be identified in rash scrapings. Electron microscopy reveals a brick-shaped appearance with a biconcave DNA core. Egg inoculation: Characteristic pock formation observed on the chorioallantoic membrane (CAM) of chick embryos. Eradication of smallpox The World Health Organization declared the eradication of smallpox nearly three years after the last recorded case, on May 8, 1980. Factors that helped the eradication Variola had no animal reservoirs. (Option C) Patients were the only source, and no carriers existed (subclinical disease). (Option A) Characteristic rashes made identification straightforward. Asymptomatic cases did not spread the disease. Global Eradication Program: Launched by WHO in 1967, leading to eradication in about 10 years through international cooperation. Effective vaccination: (Option B) Utilized a freeze-dried form of the live vaccinia vaccine for better stability. Administered via a simple and cost-effective bifurcated needle using the multiple puncture technique.

questions.question: A researcher is studying the vaccinia virus. She notices certain characteristics in the virus that enable it to be used for developing vaccines. In the context of vaccine development, what is a significant advantage of using the vaccinia virus as a vector?

options.A: It has a high pathogenicity, making it suitable for inducing strong immune responses.
options.B: Vaccinia virus can accommodate a substantial amount of foreign DNA.
options.C: It is an entirely natural virus found commonly in the human population.
options.D: The vaccinia virus is only effective against a limited range of diseases.

questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Vaccinia virus can accommodate a substantial amount of foreign DNA. Explanation: Vaccinia is an artificial virus that is non-pathogenic to humans and can accommodate a substantial amount of foreign DNA (~25,000 foreign base pairs), allowing for the insertion of multiple vaccine antigens and, hence, a very good choice for use as a vaccine. questions.question: A 14-year-old child is brought by her mother with complaints of redness of the eyes with watery discharge. She also complains of a sore throat and fever and gives a history of being in a swimming pool at school. Which serotype of the virus causing this condition is responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) 3, 7, and 14 Explanation: The diagnosis here is pharyngoconjunctival fever, also known as swimming pool conjunctivitis, which presents with ocular and throat symptoms with fever, and it is caused by adenovirus serotypes 3, 7, and 14. Adenovirus Adenoviruses are non-enveloped DNA viruses characterized by icosahedral symmetry. They feature fiber proteins extending from each vertex, creating a distinctive appearance reminiscent of a space vehicle. Morphology Adenoviruses range from 70 to 75 nm in diameter. It is composed of 252 capsomers forming an icosahedron. Capsomer Types: Hexons and Pentons. Each penton includes: A penton base anchored in the capsid. A fiber projection consisting of a rod-like portion with a knob at the end. Clinical manifestations While many serotypes can cause disease, types 1–7 are the most prevalent. Respiratory infections Upper respiratory tract infections: Common in children Primarily caused by serotypes 1, 2, and 5. (Option A) In adolescents, serotypes 3, 4, and 7 are responsible for mild infections. Pneumonia: Types 3, 7, and 21 account for 10-20% of childhood pneumonia cases. (Option D) Serotype 14 is linked to severe pneumonia in healthy young adults. Acute respiratory disease: Occur as outbreaks, especially in military recruits. Associated with types 4, 7, and occasionally type 3. Transplant recipients: Serotypes 34 and 35 are frequently isolated from these patients. Ocular Infections Pharyngoconjunctival fever: Outbreaks typically occur in children's summer camps. Often referred to as swimming pool conjunctivitis. Associated with serotypes 3, 7, and 14. Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis: Known as shipyard eye. It is highly contagious in adults. Caused by types 8, 19, and 37. (Option B) Gastrointestinal Infections Infantile gastroenteritis: Serotypes 40 and 41 are responsible for 5-15% of viral gastroenteritis cases in young children. Urinary Tract Infections Acute hemorrhagic cystitis: Primarily affects children, especially boys. Caused by serotypes 11 and 21.

questions.question: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with jaundice, fatigue, and nausea after returning from a trip to a rural area in India. Laboratory findings reveal elevated serum bilirubin, ALT, and AST. Which of the following can be used for a definitive detection of the causative agent?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) HEV PCR for viral RNA Explanation: The symptoms of the patient correlate with the diagnosis of hepatitis E, which can definitively be detected using a polymerase chain reaction to detect the genome (RNA) of the virus. Hepatitis E Virus (HEV) Epidemiology:   Hepatitis E virus is a zoonotic pathogen that can infect several animals, including monkeys, cats, pigs, and dogs.   Most non-A, non-B (NANB) hepatitis cases are transmitted through fecal contamination of drinking water (referred to as enterically transmitted NANB or E-NANB).   Epidemics are common and hence are also called epidemic NANB.   In India, HEV infection is responsible for the majority of sporadic acute hepatitis cases and epidemic hepatitis, accounting for 30-60% of occurrences.   Young adults aged 20 to 40 are more commonly affected by HEV infection than children are by HAV infection.   Transmission:   Infection sources include fecally contaminated water and the environment.   The secondary attack rate (transmission from infected persons to their close contacts) among household contacts is low (2-3%), compared to 10-20% for hepatitis A. Morphology:   HEV is a spherical, non-enveloped virus measuring 32-34 nm in diameter and featuring a single-stranded RNA genome.   The virion surface has indentations and spikes, and the virus is labile.   It has a specific antigen, HEV-Ag.   It is morphologically similar to Caliciviruses, such as the Norwalk virus, which is classified provisionally in the Hepeviridae family. Clinical features:   Incubation period: Ranges from 2 to 9 weeks, averaging around six weeks.   Ranges from 2 to 9 weeks, averaging around six weeks.   Affected population: Primarily young to middle-aged adults (ages 15-40).   Primarily young to middle-aged adults (ages 15-40).   Severity: Generally mild and self-limited, with a low case fatality rate of about 1%.   Generally mild and self-limited, with a low case fatality rate of about 1%. Generally mild and self-limited, with a low case fatality rate of about 1%.   Higher risk, with a 20-40% case fatality rate in the last trimester.   Fulminant hepatitis can occur at a significantly higher risk, with a rate of around 20%. Laboratory diagnosis:   HEV RNA can be identified in stool and serum using reverse transcriptase PCR, even before clinical symptoms appear.   Serum Antibody Detection by ELISA: IgM anti-HEV: Appears in serum simultaneously with elevated liver enzyme levels, indicating an acute infection. IgG anti-HEV: Replaces IgM within 2 to 4 weeks after symptoms resolve and can persist for years, indicating recovery or a past infection. ELISA kits are available for detecting IgG and IgM antibodies using recombinant and synthetic peptide antigens. questions.question: A 32-year-old male presents to the clinic with fatigue, jaundice, and elevated liver enzymes. He reports recent unprotected sexual encounters and has a history of intravenous drug use. During further investigation of his blood sample, a specific particle associated with this viral infection is identified under the electron microscope. Which of the following structures, when transmitted, is capable of leading to infection in another person?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Dane particles Explanation:   Dane particles are the complete virions of the Hepatitis B virus, measuring approximately 42 nm.   Dane particles contain the viral genome and are essential for establishing infection.   They consist of a double-shelled structure that includes both surface antigens (Small HbsAg and Medium HbsAg) and are capable of transmitting Hepatitis B from one individual to another, leading to infection. Hepatitis B virus (HBV) Characteristics   Family: Hepadnaviridae   Infectivity: Highly infectious; HBV is 50-100 times more infectious than HIV.   Impact: Can result in both acute and chronic liver disease, potentially leading to cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Morphology There are four particle types associated with Hepatitis B, visible under electron microscopy: Particle Type Size (nm) Genome Presenc eInfectiou sComposition Dane Particles (Option D)42 Yes Yes Complete virions (Genome + HBsAg) Spherical Particles (Option A)22 No No Surface proteins (Small HBsAg) Tubular Particles (Option B)22 No No Surface proteins (Medium HBsAg) Filamentous Particles (Option C)22 No No Surface proteins (HBsAg) Genotypes HBV includes 10 recognized genotypes, labeled A through J:   Genotype C: Common in Asia; associated with an increased risk of cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.   Genotype D: Common in India.

questions.question: In the genome of the hepatitis B virus, which region codes for the marker indicating high viral replication during infection?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) C gene Explanation:   High levels of HBV replication are associated with the presence of HBeAg, which is derived from the pre-core region of the C gene.   The presence of HBeAg in the serum indicates active viral replication and correlates with higher levels of viral DNA, making it a significant marker of infectivity. Replication Process of Hepatitis B Virus Attachment and Entry:   HBV attaches to hepatocytes using the sodium taurocholate co-transporting polypeptide (NTCP) receptor.   The virus enters the cell via endocytosis. ↓ Uncoating and Nuclear Transport:   Post-entry, the viral capsid is transported to the nucleus.   The relaxed circular, partially double-stranded DNA (rcDNA) is released and repaired by host enzymes to form covalently closed circular DNA (cccDNA), which serves as the transcription template. Transcription and Translation:   cccDNA is transcribed by host RNA polymerase II, producing viral RNAs, including pregenomic RNA (pgRNA) and subgenomic RNAs encoding HBV proteins (surface antigen, core protein, polymerase, and X protein). Genome Genes Gene Product Function/Description S (Surfac e) (Option A)Surface Antigen (HBsAg) Encodes the surface antigen, essential for viral entry and immune response induction. It is commonly detected as a marker in serological testing. C (Core) Core Antigen (HBcAg) Forms the viral nucleocapsid and plays a role in genome packaging and immune evasion. HBeAg Secretory form of the core antigen, aids in immune tolerance, and is associated with viral replication and infectivity levels. P (Polym erase) (Option D)Viral Polymerase Functions in reverse transcription, crucial for converting RNA intermediate back to DNA for viral replication. X (Option B)Regulatory Protein (HBx) Involved in viral replication regulation; may play a role in oncogenesis by affecting cell growth and survival pathways.   These RNAs move to the cytoplasm for translation, resulting in viral protein production. Reverse Transcription:   pgRNA is encapsidated within new capsids.   Within the capsid, HBV polymerase reverse transcribes pgRNA into partially double-stranded DNA, a unique feature for HBV. Assembly and Release:   DNA-containing capsids are enveloped with surface antigens and exit the cell via exocytosis or direct virion release.   Some capsids return to the nucleus to maintain cccDNA, enabling chronic infection. Mode of Transmission Highly Infectious, easily spreads through bodily fluids.   Blood Contact: Direct blood contact transmits HBV.   Sexual Contact: Unprotected sex is a key transmission route.   Perinatal: Mother-to-child transmission during birth.   Needle Sharing: High risk via shared needles (IV drug use).   Occupational Exposure: Healthcare workers at risk from bodily fluids.   Other Fluids: Also transmits through saliva and semen.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with hepatomegaly and mild jaundice. A liver biopsy shows the following appearance. What does this appearance of hepatocytes indicate?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Chronic hepatitis B infection Explanation: The liver biopsy shows hepatocytes with a "ground-glass" appearance. This appearance is specifically associated with chronic hepatitis B due to the accumulation of viral proteins in the endoplasmic reticulum of hepatocytes. This finding is a key histopathological feature indicative of chronic hepatitis B infection. Autoimmune hepatitis (Option C) is characterized by plasma cell infiltration, interface hepatitis, and emperipolesis, but it lacks the ground-glass appearance typical of chronic hepatitis B. Rosette formation may be present but is not a defining feature.

questions.question: A 32-year-old man presents with fever, jaundice, and dark urine. He is unvaccinated for hepatitis, and liver enzymes are elevated. A healthcare worker uses a detergent-based disinfectant to clean the room. Which of the following viruses is most likely to survive the cleaning process due to its resistance to detergents and solvents?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Hepatitis A Explanation: Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is a non-enveloped RNA virus, which makes it more resistant to inactivation by detergents and solvents compared to the enveloped viruses Hepatitis B, C, and D. Primarily transmitted through blood transfusions, shared needles, and less commonly through sexual contact or from mother to child. Diagnosis is through PCR testing of HGV RNA.   Specific antiviral treatment isn’t necessary due to its generally benign course.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about Hepatitis A is incorrect?

options.A: It belongs to the family Hepadnaviridae.
options.B: The virus can be cultured in primate diploid cell lines.
options.C: Epidemiology is similar to that of poliovirus.
options.D: Outbreaks are more common during the summer months.

questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) It belongs to the family Hepadnaviridae. Explanation:   Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is classified under the family Picornaviridae, not Hepadnaviridae, which is the family associated with the Hepatitis B virus.   Hepatitis A shares a similar epidemiology with poliomyelitis, as both viral infections are transmitted through the fecal-oral route. Hepatitis A Virus (HAV) Family:   Picornaviridae family (Option A)   Genus: Hepatovirus   Also known as Enterovirus-72   Single serotype and six genotypes (I, II, III affecting humans) Genotype Common Locations I Worldwide (most prevalent genotype) II Found in specific regions (less common) IIIa Predominant in India and some Asian countries Viral Morphology:   Small, non-enveloped virus   Icosahedral symmetry   Single-stranded, positive-sense RNA genome (+ssRNA)   Encodes four capsid proteins (VP1–VP4) Transmission:   Fecal-oral route, especially in areas with poor sanitation   Spreads through direct contact, contaminated food or water, fomites, or person-to-person contact with inadequate hygiene   Rare transmission through blood transfusion and sexual contact   In India, over 90% of individuals are seropositive by age 10, indicating widespread early exposure Epidemiology:   Similarities with poliovirus (fecal-oral transmission) (Option C)   Seasonal trends, peaking during warmer months due to increased exposure to contaminated food (Option D) Cultivability: Can be cultivated in specific cell cultures, such as human or primate diploid cell lines (unlike most hepatitis viruses) (Option B)

questions.question: A 9-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a 2-week history of fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, and jaundice. He recently attended a picnic with school friends. Laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes (AST and ALT) and elevated bilirubin levels. During the follow-up visit, which serological marker would you expect to be markedly raised in the convalescent phase of the viral infection?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) IgG anti-viral Explanation: In the convalescent phase, IgG antibodies are produced as part of the immune response, indicating that the body has cleared the virus and is developing long-term immunity. Hepatitis A: Clinical Presentation and Investigation Clinical Presentation Hepatitis A is a viral infection caused by the Hepatitis A virus (HAV) and is primarily transmitted via the fecal-oral route, often through contaminated food or water. Incubation Period: 15 to 50 days (average 28 days). Symptoms:   Prodromal Phase: Initial symptoms may include fatigue, malaise, low-grade fever, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal discomfort, typically lasting a few days.   Mild Hepatitis: Progression may lead to jaundice, dark urine, and pale stools due to impaired bilirubin excretion.   Icterus (Jaundice): Occurs in ~70% of patients.   Hepatomegaly   Other Symptoms: pruritus and arthralgia may occur. Recovery: Slow spontaneous recovery typically occurs within 1 to 2 months; complete resolution is common. Rare Complications: Cholestatic jaundice and fulminant hepatitis, which occurs in <0.1% of patients Investigations Serological Markers:   IgM Anti-HAV: Indicates recent infection; detectable within the first week of illness and lasts for several months.   IgG Anti-HAV: Indicates past infection or vaccination; provides lifelong immunity and is detectable for years. Detection of HAV particles:   HAV appears in stool from –2 to +2 weeks of jaundice.   It can also be detected in the liver, bile, and blood by immunoelectron microscopy. Liver Function Tests (LFTs):   ALT and AST: Elevated   Alkaline Phosphatase: May be mildly elevated, especially in cholestatic cases. Bilirubin Levels: Elevated total bilirubin (conjugated and unconjugated). Serology for Other Hepatitis Viruses: To rule out co-infections with Hepatitis B and C

questions.question: All of the following statements regarding the prophylactic vaccine for Hepatitis A are true, except.

options.A: The vaccine is an inactivated vaccine
options.B: Two doses are recommended at an interval of six months.
options.D: It is recommended for individuals under one year of age.

questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) It is recommended for individuals under one year of age. Explanation: The Hepatitis A vaccine is generally recommended for children starting at age 1 (12 months), not for those under one year of age. Hepatitis A Vaccine Type of Vaccine: Inactivated (killed) form Indications: Routine Vaccination for Children: Recommended for all children aged 1 year (typically between 12-23 months). High-Risk Groups:   Travelers to regions with high rates of HAV infection.   Individuals with chronic liver disease or clotting factor disorders.   People who use injection or non-injection illicit drugs. Outbreak Control: Used to help control HAV outbreaks within communities. Two types of vaccines are available for human use: Age for Vaccination Children: The recommended starting age is 1 year (12-23 months). Immunogenicity and Efficacy Effectiveness:   Provides 95% protection after the first dose.   Near-complete protection is achieved after the second dose. Duration of Immunity: Offers long-lasting immunity, with many individuals maintaining protective antibody levels for decades post-vaccination. Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) For Unvaccinated Individuals Exposed to HAV:   Within 2 weeks of exposure: A single dose of the Hepatitis A vaccine or immunoglobulin (IG) is recommended.   Preference for IG: Immunoglobulin may be preferred for infants (<12 months), older adults, and individuals with weakened immune systems.

questions.question: A 28-year-old patient presents for follow-up after a Hepatitis B infection. Laboratory results indicate that HBsAg is negative, HBeAg is negative, Anti-HBc is positive for IgG, and Anti-HBs are positive. What is the most likely interpretation of these findings?

options.D: Chronic Hepatitis B infection, low infectivity

questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Recovery from Hepatitis B infection Explanation: The presence of Anti-HBc IgG and Anti-HBs, along with negative HBsAg and HBeAg, indicates that the patient has recovered from Hepatitis B infection. Stages and Associated Markers of Hepatitis B Virus (HBV): HBsAg HBeAg Anti-HBc Anti-HBs Anti-HBe Interpretation + + IgM Acute HBV infection Highly infectious (Option A) + + IgG - Chronic HBV infection, highly infectious IgG -/+ Chronic HBV infection, low infectivity (Option D) - IgG -/+ -/+ Recovery (Option B) - IgM - - Window period Post-vaccination (Option C) Window Period: The period between the disappearance of HBsAg and the appearance of Anti-HBs is known as the "window period". During this time, other viral serologies may also be undetectable. Only marker detected in this period is Anti-HBc IgM.

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient with chronic hepatitis B presents with worsening liver function tests. Laboratory analysis reveals negative HBeAg, although other HBV markers are still positive. The HBV DNA load is >2000 copies/mL. Which of the following mutations is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Precore mutants Explanation: Precore mutants abolish HBeAg production and are often associated with more severe chronic hepatitis, leading to rapid progression to cirrhosis. Although the virus continues to replicate, it fails to produce functional HBeAg in this condition. Hepatitis B Virus Mutants:   Mutation occurs in the precore region (abolishes HBeAg production) or the basal core promoter region (downregulates HBeAg production).   Often diagnosed late in infected patients.   Associated with more severe chronic hepatitis that progresses rapidly to cirrhosis.   Patients do not produce HBeAg, although other HBV markers are present.   Mutation occurs in the common "a" determinant in the S gene of HBsAg, which prevents neutralization by anti-HBsAg antibodies.   Situations where escape mutants are observed: Infants born to HBeAg-positive mothers. Liver transplant recipients who received combined immunization with anti-HBV immunoglobulin and vaccine.   Infants born to HBeAg-positive mothers.   Liver transplant recipients who received combined immunization with anti-HBV immunoglobulin and vaccine.   Clinical Implication: If escape mutants become more prevalent, they may pose challenges for hepatitis B prophylaxis.   Infants born to HBeAg-positive mothers.   Liver transplant recipients who received combined immunization with anti-HBV immunoglobulin and vaccine.   Occurs in the YMDD locus within the HBV reverse transcriptase region of the polymerase gene.   Clinical Implication: HBV-infected patients on lamivudine therapy may develop resistance due to this mutation. Antigenic shift (Option D): This specifically refers to significant changes in influenza A virus antigens, not applicable to Hepatitis B and HBeAg production.

questions.question: A newborn is delivered to a mother with chronic Hepatitis B who tests positive for HBeAg. What is the most appropriate prevention and estimated risk of perinatal transmission to the newborn?

options.C: HBIG and hepatitis B vaccine; 70–90% risk
options.D: HBIG and hepatitis B vaccine; 10–20% risk

questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) HBIG and hepatitis B vaccine; 70–90% risk Explanation: In newborns of HBeAg-positive mothers, the perinatal transmission risk is 70–90%. Immediate administration of HBIG and the hepatitis B vaccine series is recommended to reduce this risk. Prevention of Perinatal Transmission: Babies Born to Carrier Mothers:   0.5 ml of HBIG was given IM immediately after birth.   Followed by the full vaccine course at a different anatomical site, starting within 12 hours of birth.   95% of infected newborns become chronic carriers.   Breastfeeding is not contraindicated. Antigen in Mothers Risk of Perinatal Transmission HBeAg-positive 70–90% (Option C) HBeAg-negative/HBeAb-negative 25% (Option A) HBeAg-negative/anti-HBe-positive 12% (Option B) Hepatitis B Vaccine:   Recombinant subunit vaccine.   Prepared in baker’s yeast via DNA recombinant technology by cloning the S gene.   Route of Administration: Intramuscular injection in the deltoid region (anterolateral thigh for infants).   Dosage: 10–20 µg per dose (Half dose for children under 10 years).   Schedule: For Adults: Three doses at 0, 1, and 6 months. National Immunization Schedule: Given at 6, 10, and 14 weeks along with the DPT vaccine.   For Adults: Three doses at 0, 1, and 6 months. questions.question: A 34-year-old man with a history of IV drug use presents with fatigue, nausea, and mild jaundice. He reports a history of similar symptoms about 5 years ago, which resolved spontaneously. Laboratory testing shows elevated liver enzymes, and an ELISA test is positive for anti-HCV antibodies. Which of the following tests would be most appropriate to confirm an active HCV infection in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) RT-PCR for HCV RNA Explanation:   RT-PCR for HCV RNA is the gold standard for confirming active HCV infection.   While an ELISA test detects antibodies, it does not differentiate between past and active infections.   The presence of HCV RNA indicates ongoing viral replication and active infection.   The core antigen assay, though helpful for initial diagnosis and monitoring, is less sensitive than RT-PCR. Hepatitis C Virus (HCV) Classification HCV belongs to the Flaviviridae family, genus Hepacivirus. Structure and Genome ... (content truncated) Transmission Primarily bloodborne: Transfusions, organ transplants, needle-sharing. Vertical transmission (~6%) & rarely sexual transmission. Not spread by breast milk, food, or casual contact. Clinical Manifestation Incubation: 15–160 days (average 50 days). Asymptomatic in over 75% of cases. Acute hepatitis in ~20%: usually mild or anicteric Chronic Progression Chronic Disease: 75–85% of cases progress to chronic disease. Chronic Hepatitis: 60–70% of chronic cases. Cirrhosis: 5–20% of cases with chronic infection. Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC): 1–5% of cases; HCV accounts for ~25% of liver cancers. Extrahepatic ManifestationsImmune complex deposition can cause: Mixed cryoglobulinemia Glomerulonephritis Arthritis and joint pain. (Option C) Biopsy (Option B) is the gold standard for staging; Fibroscan (Option D) is a non-invasive alternative for assessing liver fibrosis. Treatment Goals: Prevent complications (e.g., cirrhosis, liver cancer) and achieve sustained viral response (SVR). Sofosbuvir/velpatasvir is effective against all genotypes. Duration: Typically 12–24 weeks, depending on genotype and liver status.

questions.question: During an outbreak investigation in Kerala, India, several patients presented with fever and encephalitis. questions.question: A 6-year-old boy presents with bilateral painful swelling in the region of his parotid glands that began 2 days ago. His mother notes that the pain worsens when he drinks orange juice. He had a fever of 101.2°F (38.4°C) before the swelling appeared. The patient's vaccination status is unknown. During examination, bilateral parotid enlargement is noted. Which of the following is the most specific diagnostic test to confirm the suspected infection in this patient? {{caption_text}}
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) RT-PCR from buccal swab Explanation:   The case presents classic symptoms of mumps: bilateral parotitis with pain that increases with citrus juice consumption (stimulation of salivary glands), along with fever as a prodromal symptom.   RT-PCR from a buccal swab is the most specific diagnostic test for confirming acute mumps infection, especially when collected early in the course of illness. Diagnosis Methods RT-PCR Buccal swab Most specific test Collect within first 3 days Antigen ELISA method Used for rapid screening Clinical Features Bilateral parotitis Pain increases with citrus juices Fever and malaise Culture Only in cell lines Vaccine Details- MMR Recommended Strain- Mumps Jeryl Lynn Strain Measles Strain Edmonston/Zagreb Rubella Strain RA 27/3 Type MMR-V (with varicella) Serum IgG antibody test (Option A): IgG antibodies indicate past infection or immunity rather than a current, acute infection. It is less specific for diagnosing an active mumps infection since it cannot distinguish between recent and past exposure to the virus. Viral culture from parotid secretions (Option B): Although a viral culture from parotid secretions can confirm mumps, it is less sensitive than RT-PCR and requires more time, which makes it less practical for timely diagnosis. Physical examination findings alone (Option D): Clinical signs like parotid swelling are suggestive but not confirmatory of mumps, as other conditions (such as bacterial parotitis) can also present similarly.

questions.question: A 15-year-old boy presents with a 3-day history of fever, headache, and bilateral parotid gland swelling. He reports no recent vaccinations. Physical examination reveals painful, swollen parotid glands and lab tests show elevated serum amylase. Which complication is most likely to develop if the condition progresses?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Orchitis Explanation:   The diagnosis of mumps is supported by the patient's presentation of bilateral parotitis, fever, and elevated serum amylase levels, along with a lack of recent vaccinations.   The most likely complication is orchitis, as it occurs in 20-30% of post-pubertal males with mumps and is more common than other potential complications such as encephalitis or pancreatitis. Mumps: It is a viral infection primarily affecting the parotid glands, with the mumps virus being the most common cause of parotid gland enlargement in children. Severe cases can lead to complications such as orchitis and aseptic meningitis. Epidemiology:   Mumps is endemic worldwide, peaks in winter and spring, and is often associated with unvaccinated individuals in overcrowded areas.   Approximately 500,000 cases are reported globally each year. Immunization has significantly reduced the incidence.   Primarily affects children aged 5–9 years. However, adults without immunity can also contract the disease, with potentially more severe outcomes.   Lifelong immunity usually follows either natural infection or vaccination, with a high secondary attack rate of 86% in close contacts. Transmission: Respiratory RouteSpread occurs through respiratory droplets, saliva, and fomites contaminated by the virus. Incubation PeriodAbout 19 days, with a range from 7 to 23 days. Infectivity Patients are contagious from 1 week before symptoms to 1 week after. The peak infective period is 1–2 days before symptoms begin. Source Both clinical and subclinical cases are infectious, with subclinical cases (30–40% of infections) helping sustain transmission. Reservoir Humans are the only known reservoir, with no carrier state identified. Clinical Features: Up to 50% of infected individuals show mild or no symptoms. Parotitis The most common specific feature, presenting in 70–90% of cases, is usually bilateral parotid swelling. Orchitis/Epididymo-o rchitisSeen in 15–30% of postpubertal males, usually unilateral; infertility is rare due to unilateral involvement. Aseptic Meningitis Occurs in less than 10% of cases, typically self-limiting, but can cause permanent deafness if cranial nerves are affected. Oophoritis Found in about 5% of infected women. Pancreatitis Affects approximately 4% of cases, leading to diabetes in rare cases. Atypical Presentatio nSome patients may present with aseptic meningitis without parotitis (in 10% of cases). Encephalitis (Option B) is rare, affecting less than 0.3% of mumps cases, mainly in younger children. Hearing loss (Option C) can occur but is extremely rare (1 in 20,000 cases). Pancreatitis (Option D) is possible but less common in adolescents compared to orchitis.

questions.question: A 9-month-old infant presents with high fever, cough, conjunctivitis, rash over the buccal mucosa, and a spreading maculopapular rash. What is the most appropriate next step in management? {{caption_text}}

options.D: Educate on supportive care and schedule the vaccine at 12 months

questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Administer immunoglobulin therapy Explanation:   The infant is symptomatic and unvaccinated; immunoglobulin within 6 days of exposure can reduce measles severity.   Vaccination is ineffective post-exposure, and there is no specific antiviral therapy.   Deferring until 12 months without prophylaxis increases risk. Diagnosis of Measles:   Preferred samples include nasopharyngeal swab, conjunctival swab, blood, respiratory secretions, and urine.   Detectable by using direct immunofluorescence with anti-nucleoprotein antibodies applied to infected cells.   Highly specific for diagnosing acute measles infections.   Monkey or human kidney cells are the standard cell lines used.   Viral growth is characterized by the presence of Warthin-Finkeldey cells—multinucleated giant cells containing intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions.   Shell vial culture is a quicker alternative, allowing early detection within 2-3 days.   The presence of measles-specific IgM in serum or oral fluid, or a four-fold rise in IgG titer between acute and convalescent-phase sera is diagnostic.   Anti-measles antibody levels in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) are diagnostic for subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE).   Reverse-transcription PCR can detect measles RNA (e.g., nucleoprotein gene) with high sensitivity and specificity.   Useful for tracking measles strains and conducting epidemiological studies.   Detectable RNA persists longer than the virus itself (10–14 days post-rash). Vaccination:   Live attenuated vaccine: Strains used: Schwartz, Edmonston-Zagreb, Moraten strains. Prepared in chick embryo cell lines.   Strains used: Schwartz, Edmonston-Zagreb, Moraten strains.   Prepared in chick embryo cell lines.   Strains used: Schwartz, Edmonston-Zagreb, Moraten strains.   Prepared in chick embryo cell lines.   Available as MR (measles-rubella), MMR (measles, mumps, rubella), and MMR-V (measles, mumps, rubella, varicella) vaccines.   Stored at –20°C due to its thermolabile nature.   India’s Immunization Schedule: First dose of MR at 9-12 months, accompanied by vitamin A supplementation. Second dose at 16-24 months.   First dose of MR at 9-12 months, accompanied by vitamin A supplementation.   Second dose at 16-24 months.   Post-Exposure Prophylaxis: If exposed, administering a measles vaccine within three days can prevent the disease in children 9-12 months old.   First dose of MR at 9-12 months, accompanied by vitamin A supplementation.   Second dose at 16-24 months.   Severe allergic reactions to prior MMR doses, severe immunodeficiency, pregnancy, and active tuberculosis. Administer the measles vaccine (Option A): Vaccination is preventive and does not provide therapeutic benefits once the infection is established. Additionally, live vaccines like MMR are typically not administered during an active infection due to the risk of exacerbating symptoms. Prescribe antiviral therapy (Option B): There is currently no specific antiviral treatment for measles. Management of measles is generally supportive, including hydration, antipyretics, and in some cases, high-dose vitamin A supplementation to reduce complications. Educate on supportive care and schedule the vaccine at 12 months (Option D):   While supportive care education is essential, deferring intervention until 12 months is inadequate for this high-risk infant.   Waiting without immunoglobulin administration increases the risk of complications from measles in a young, unvaccinated infant. Immediate post-exposure prophylaxis is warranted given the high risk associated with active measles in this age group.

questions.question: A 3-year-old unvaccinated child presents with high fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and a maculopapular rash that began on the face and has spread to the trunk and limbs. Oral examination reveals small, white lesions on the buccal mucosa. Which complication is most likely to develop in the acute phase of this illness?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Pneumonia Explanation:   Pneumonia is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in acute measles and is the most likely immediate complication in this case, especially in an unvaccinated child.   Measles is an acute, highly contagious viral infection caused by the measles virus, a member of the Paramyxoviridae family.   It primarily affects children and is transmitted through respiratory droplets or small-particle aerosols. Clinical Stages of Measles: Stage Duration Symptoms Incubation Period10 days (up to 21 days)Asymptomatic phase; the virus multiplies in the respiratory tract, followed by primary and secondary viremia. Prodromal Stage4 days Fever (day 10), Koplik’s spots (day 12), non-specific symptoms (cough, coryza, conjunctivitis). Eruptive Stage4 days post feverThe maculopapular rash appears first behind the ears, then spreads to the face, trunk, and limbs, fading in the same order. Post-measle s StageVariable Characterized by weight loss, weakness, and a risk of progressing to chronic conditions. Complications of Measles: A. Secondary Bacterial Infections   Immune suppression following measles increases susceptibility to bacterial infections.   Otitis media and bronchopneumonia are the most frequent bacterial complications.   Worsening of underlying tuberculosis with a possible false-negative Mantoux test. B. Complications Due to Measles Virus Itself   Giant-cell pneumonitis (Hecht’s pneumonia), primarily in immunocompromised and HIV-infected individuals.   Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (croup).   Diarrhea leading to malnutrition and vitamin A deficiency. C. Central Nervous System (CNS) Complications   Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE): A rare but severe late complication characterized by progressive CNS deterioration.   Other CNS complications include post-measles encephalomyelitis and measles inclusion body encephalitis. Acute encephalitis (Option A): Occurs in approximately 1 in 1,000 cases, often presenting later with neurological symptoms, not during the acute phase. Otitis media (Option B): It is common but typically less severe than pneumonia in terms of immediate risk. SSPE (Option C): It is a delayed complication, developing years after initial infection, thus not relevant to the acute phase.

questions.question: A patient comes to the clinic with symptoms of a viral infection. The physician is reviewing potential viruses based on their classification into myxovirus families. Which of the following viruses is NOT a member of the Paramyxoviridae family?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Influenza virus Explanation: The influenza virus belongs to the Orthomyxoviridae Family, which is distinct from Paramyxoviridae. questions.question: A 30-year-old healthcare worker presents with sudden onset fever, chills, sore throat, and muscle aches. She reports exposure to multiple patients with similar symptoms. The physician suspects influenza and requests a diagnostic test for confirmation. A nasopharyngeal swab is collected, and a Hemagglutination Inhibition (HI) test is performed. The results show a significant increase in antibody titers in the second sample compared to the first sample, taken 10 days apart. Which of the following best explains the findings and indicates a confirmed diagnosis of influenza?

options.A: The HI test shows no change in antibody titers between the first and second samples.
options.B: The HI test shows a fourfold increase in antibody titers between the first and second
options.C: The HI test shows a twofold decrease in antibody titers between the first and second
options.D: The HI test shows a single positive result with no subsequent titer testing.

questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) The HI test shows a fourfold increase in antibody titers between the first and second samples. Explanation:   The Hemagglutination Inhibition (HI) test is a specific serological test used to detect antibodies against influenza viruses. This test measures the ability of patient antibodies to inhibit the agglutination (clumping) of red blood cells by the influenza virus.   For a confirmed influenza infection, a fourfold or greater rise in antibody titers between acute (initial) and convalescent (second) serum samples taken 7–14 days apart is indicative of an active or recent infection. The increase in titers reflects the body’s immune response to the infection. Lab Diagnosis of Influenza: The laboratory diagnosis of influenza involves various methods for detecting the virus or its antibodies. These methods include:   Ideal specimens include nasopharyngeal swabs, nasal aspirates, or lavage fluids.   Swabs with synthetic tips (polyester or Dacron) are recommended. Specimens are placed in viral transport media, stored at 4°C if processed within 4 days, and at -70°C if stored longer.   Influenza virus can be inoculated in embryonated eggs. Growth detection occurs through hemadsorption or hemagglutination.   Primary monkey kidney cell lines are also used to grow influenza viruses for detection.   This rapid method involves staining viral antigens on epithelial cells with fluorescent antibodies. However, it has lower sensitivity than virus isolation.   Reverse Transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR): Highly sensitive and specific, detecting influenza RNA quickly.   Real-Time RT-PCR: The preferred diagnostic method due to its quantitative capability and ability to detect multiple seasonal strains, including A/H1N1, A/H3N2, and influenza B.   Hemagglutination Inhibition Test (HAI): Previously used for influenza, HAI measures specific antibodies by detecting their ability to inhibit virus-induced hemagglutination.   Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay (ELISA) and Neutralization Test: ELISA is commonly used to detect serum antibodies against influenza antigens, particularly for epidemiological studies. Hemagglutination Inhibition (HAI) Test: The HAI test is a serological method used primarily in epidemiology to detect antibodies against influenza viruses.   Principle: Influenza viruses possess hemagglutinin (HA) proteins, allowing them to agglutinate red blood cells (RBCs). Specific antibodies in a patient’s serum can inhibit this agglutination. The test measures these antibodies’ ability to prevent hemagglutination.   Procedure: Step 1: Diluted serum samples are added to standardized influenza virus suspensions. Step 2: Red blood cells are added to the mixture. Step 3: If antibodies are present, they bind to the HA antigens, preventing them from agglutinating the RBCs. Lack of agglutination indicates a positive HAI result, suggesting prior exposure or immunity.   Step 1: Diluted serum samples are added to standardized influenza virus suspensions. In cases of acute influenza infection, we would expect to see a significant increase in titers due to the active immune response. The HI test shows a twofold decrease in antibody titers between the first and second samples (Option C): A decrease in titers is generally not seen in acute infection and suggests either a resolving past infection or a laboratory error. This does not confirm active or recent influenza infection, as we would expect a rise in antibody levels if the patient is actively fighting the virus. The HI test shows a single positive result with no subsequent titer testing (Option D): A single positive titer cannot confirm a recent infection, as it does not provide a baseline for comparison. A single sample only indicates previous exposure or vaccination and cannot distinguish between current and past infections without paired testing.

questions.question: Which statement correctly describes antigenic drift and antigenic shift in influenza viruses?

options.A: Drift causes pandemics; shift causes minor epidemics.
options.B: Drift involves minor mutations; shift involves genetic reassortment.
options.C: Shift occurs in Influenza A and B; drift occurs only in Influenza A.
options.D: Drift produces a new strain; shift evades immune recognition.

questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Drift involves minor mutations; shift involves genetic re-assortment. Explanation: Antigenic drift involves minor changes due to point mutations, while antigenic shift is an abrupt change due to genetic re-assortment. Antigenic Drift Antigenic Shift Minor change due to point mutations in HA/NA genes, altering amino acid sequences and helping the virus partially evade immune recognition. (Option D) Requires two or more mutations for significant impact. Occurs in both influenza A and B viruses. (Option C) Leads to outbreaks and minor epidemics, occurring every 2–3 years. (Option A)An abrupt, major change in HA/NA genes due to genetic reassortment between influenza viruses infecting the same host. Produces a new virus strain, making prior antibodies ineffective. (Option D) Occurs only in influenza A virus. (Option C) Causes pandemics and major epidemics, with shifts happening every 10–20 years (e.g., the H1N1 pandemic of 2009). (Option A)

Physical examination findings alone (Option D): Clinical signs like parotid swelling are suggestive but not confirmatory of mumps, as other conditions (such as bacterial parotitis) can also present similarly.

questions.question: A medical student is studying viral classifications and comes across various RNA virus families. The student needs to identify misconceptions regarding the properties of these viruses. Which of the following statements is FALSE?

options.D: Rhabdovirus and Myxovirus are examples of negative-sense RNA viruses.

questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Bunyavirus has segmented RNA with 7 segments. Explanation: Bunyavirus has 3 segments of RNA, not 7. All other statements about the respective virus families and their properties are true. Some examples of: Positive sense Negative sense Picornaviridae Flaviviridae Togaviridae Hepeviridae Coronaviridae (Option A ruled out)M: Myxovirus R: Rhabdovirus (Option D ruled out) F: Filovirus A: Arenavirus B: Bunyavirus Segmented RNA - BIRA   Bunyavirus- 3 segments   Orthomyxovirus (Influenza)- 7-8 segments (Option C ruled out)   Reovirus- 10-12 segments   Arenavirus- 2 segments

questions.question: During an outbreak investigation in a labor colony, health officials are tracking a viral infection. The causative virus has these characteristics: exclusively human reservoir, fecal-oral transmission, and three distinct serotypes. The outbreak is showing these features: predominantly affects unvaccinated children, begins with fever and headache, and in some cases progresses to acute flaccid paralysis. The investigation team is discussing viral characteristics. Which of the following statements about this virus is INCORRECT?

options.A: Virus can be isolated from feces for up to 6 weeks after symptom onset
options.C: Type 1 is the least common cause of epidemics
options.D: Virus shedding begins 2 days before symptom onset

questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Type 1 is the least common cause of epidemics Explanation: Type 1 poliovirus is the most common and causes most epidemics. Poliovirus Types and Strains Type 1 (Brunhilde, Mahoney): Most common, causes epidemics Type 2 (Lansing, MEF1): Endemic infections (Option B) Type 3 (Leon, Saukett): Can cause epidemics Viral Antigens D antigen: Found in whole virion, type-specific, protective C antigen: Found in empty virus, not protective No common group antigen Heat converts D to C antigen (56°C) Transmission Factors Route: Primarily fecal-oral Source: Human feces, throat secretions Reservoir: Only humans Environmental survival: 6 months in sewage Resistant to: pH 3, ether, detergents Time Course Incubation: Range 4-28 days (average 10) Communicable period: -2 to +5 days from symptoms Fecal shedding: Up to 6 weeks (Option A) Initial symptoms: 1-5 days Asymptomatic period: 2-3 days Major illness onset: 3-4 days after minor illness Clinical-Epidemiological Aspects Subclinical:Clinical = 1000:1 or 100:1 Risk enhancers: Pregnancy, tonsillectomy, injections Cross-immunity: Between 1&2, 2&3; minimal 1&3 Peak season: Late winter and early spring No carrier state exists Viral shedding in feces continues for several weeks: 80% in first week, 50% till third week, 25% till sixth week (Option A) Type 2 typically causes endemic infections rather than epidemics (Option B) Infectivity begins 2 days before symptom onset and continues until 5 days after (Option D)

questions.question: A 4-year-old unvaccinated child presents with a biphasic illness. The initial phase included fever, headache, and sore throat lasting 5 days, followed by 2 days of improvement. Now the child has returned with high fever, neck stiffness, and weakness in the right leg. The CSF analysis shows aseptic meningitis. About the pathogenesis of this viral infection, which of the following sequences is correct?

options.A: Direct neural invasion → Viremia → CNS symptoms → Muscular weakness
options.B: Primary viremia → RES (reticuloendothelial system) multiplication → Secondary
options.C: Respiratory infection → Direct neural spread → CNS invasion → Secondary viremia
options.D: Primary viremia → Direct CNS invasion → Muscular weakness → Secondary viremia

questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Primary viremia → RES multiplication → Secondary viremia → CNS invasion → Anterior horn cell destruction Explanation: The clinical presentation is indicative of Poliomyelitis. The correct sequence of pathogenesis of Poliomyelitis is represented below, which follows the virus's natural progression: Poliomyelitis- Pathogenesis and Clinical Features Pathogenesis Stages 1. Entry: Oral route 2. Initial replication: Nasopharynx and GI tract 3. Primary viremia: Virus enters bloodstream 4. RES multiplication: In lymphoid tissues 5. Secondary viremia: More extensive spread 6. CNS invasion: Via bloodstream or neural route 7. Anterior horn cell destruction: Causes paralysis Clinical Presentations Inapparent Infection (90-95%): - Asymptomatic - Only seroconversion Abortive Poliomyelitis (4-8%): - Fever - Headache - Sore throat - Malaise - Duration: 1-5 days Non-paralytic (1-2%): - Aseptic meningitis - Stiff neck - Spinal rigidity Paralytic (0.1-1%): - Asymmetric paralysis - Muscle weakness - Respiratory involvement possible CNS Changes Chromatolysis of Nissl bodies Nuclear degeneration Cell lysis Inflammatory response Anterior horn predominantly affected Recovery Patterns Recovery begins: 2-3 weeks after paralysis Maximum recovery: Within 6 months Residual paralysis: May persist Death rate: 5-10% (respiratory involvement) Muscle atrophy: Common in affected limbs

questions.question: A 5-year-old child presents to the clinic with fever, headache, and neck stiffness. Two days later, he developed weakness in his left leg, with loss of reflexes but no sensation changes. A cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis shows mild pleocytosis and a slight increase in protein levels. What is the most likely diagnosis, and which test should be done first?

options.A: Guillain-Barré Syndrome; perform nerve conduction studies.
options.B: Nonparalytic poliovirus infection; obtain a throat swab for viral PCR.
options.C: Viral meningitis; order a PCR for enterovirus on CSF.
options.D: Paralytic poliomyelitis; obtain stool and throat samples for poliovirus PCR.

questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Paralytic poliomyelitis; obtain stool and throat samples for poliovirus PCR. Explanation:   Paralytic polio may begin with flu-like symptoms and progresses to asymmetric limb weakness and loss of reflexes without sensory loss.   Testing for poliovirus in stool and throat samples is preferred, as poliovirus can often be isolated early in the illness.   In this child’s case, the asymmetric limb weakness and reflex loss, coupled with the mild CSF findings, align most closely with paralytic polio.   Spinal: Limb paralysis.   Bulbar: Difficulty breathing, and swallowing.   Bulbospinal: Combination of both.   Often asymmetrical muscle weakness and loss of reflexes, with respiratory failure in severe cases.   Clinical Examination: Neurological assessment for muscle weakness and paralysis.   Laboratory Testing: Stool/Throat Samples: Virus isolation. CSF Analysis: Detects inflammation. PCR: Detects poliovirus RNA. Serology: Identifies antibodies if virus isolation is unsuccessful.   Stool/Throat Samples: Virus isolation.   CSF Analysis: Detects inflammation.   PCR: Detects poliovirus RNA.   Serology: Identifies antibodies if virus isolation is unsuccessful.   Imaging (MRI): For severe cases to assess nerve involvement.   Stool/Throat Samples: Virus isolation.   CSF Analysis: Detects inflammation.   PCR: Detects poliovirus RNA.   Serology: Identifies antibodies if virus isolation is unsuccessful. Vaccination   Two types of vaccines are available. OPV (Sabin) IPV (Salk) Type Live attenuated virus Killed formalised virus Route Oral ID (preferred) or SC or IM Dose 2 drops or as stated on the label Intradermally, 0.1ml (fractional IPV or fIPV) Schedule 1st dose: 6 weeks 2nd dose: 10 weeks 3rd dose: 14 weeks Booster dose: 16-24 months1st dose: 6 weeks 2nd dose: 14 weeks 3rd dose: 9 completed months Immunity provided Humoral + Intestinal Humoral Prevents Paralysis Intestinal re-infectionParalysis Storage & transport Requires sub-zero temperatures Less stringent conditions Shelf life Short Longer Guillain-Barré Syndrome; perform nerve conduction studies (Option A), is incorrect as while Guillain-Barré also causes weakness and loss of reflexes, it is typically symmetric (both sides of the body are affected equally) and often follows a respiratory or gastrointestinal illness. Diagnosis involves nerve conduction studies and lumbar puncture for CSF analysis, but thischild’s symptoms and asymmetry make polio more likely. Nonparalytic poliovirus infection; obtaining a throat swab for viral PCR (Option B) is incorrect as paralytic polio causes fever, headache, and neck stiffness without progressing to muscle weakness. A PCR for polio in throat swabs is correct, but this doesn’t fully explain the new weakness. Viral meningitis; order a PCR for enterovirus on CSF (Option C), is incorrect as viral meningitis often presents with fever, headache, and neck stiffness, and enterovirus is a common cause. However, it does not typically cause focal (one-sided) muscle weakness or reflex loss.

questions.question: You’re seeing a 6-year-old patient who’s had a fever, sore throat, and painful sores in the mouth for the past few days. He now has small red spots and blisters on his palms and soles. During the exam, as shown, you notice vesicles on the soft palate and pinkish lesions on his hands and feet. Given these symptoms, what’s the most likely diagnosis and causative agent?

options.B: Coxsackie A; Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease
options.D: Coxsackie B; Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease

questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Coxsackie A; Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease Explanation: With this child’s fever, mouth sores, and characteristic rash on the hands and feet, Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease caused by Coxsackie A is the most fitting answer. Coxsackie virus: Types and clinical manifestations Coxsackie Virus TypeAssociated Conditions Clinical Manifestations Coxsackie A Primarily skin and mucosal infectionsHand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD): Fever, painful red spots/blisters on hands, feet, and inside the mouth; may spread to elbows, knees, or buttocks. (Option B) (Option D ruled out) Herpangina: Sudden high fever, painful ulcers/vesicles on soft palate, uvula, and tonsils; sore throat, headache, difficulty swallowing. (Option C ruled out) Coxsackie B Primarily systemic infectionsPleurodynia (Bornholm Disease): Sudden, severe, stabbing chest or abdominal pain; intermittent, lasting days, with fever and muscle tenderness. (Option A ruled out) Myocarditis and Pericarditis: Chest pain, fatigue, palpitations, irregular heartbeat; severe cases may lead to heart failure. Pancreatitis (rare): Inflammation of the pancreas. Neonatal Sepsis (rare): Severe infection in newborns, sepsis-like symptoms, potential multi-organ failure.

questions.question: A 2-year-old child presents with fever, headache, and neck stiffness. A physical exam shows a mild skin rash, but no other remarkable findings. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis suggests aseptic meningitis. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent, and what is another common manifestation associated with this virus type?

options.B: Coxsackie B virus; Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD)

questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) ECHO virus; Upper Respiratory Infections Explanation: ECHO virus is a frequent cause of aseptic meningitis, particularly in children. It can also cause mild skin rashes, respiratory infections, and other less severe symptoms, making this the best answer for the presentation described. Enterovirus and ECHO virus: Viru sTransmis sionCommon Infections Severe Manifestations Ente rovir usFecal-or al, respir atoryHand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD): Usually caused by Enterovirus A (e.g., EV-A71). Aseptic Meningitis: Fever, headache, neck stiffness, photophobia; multiple Enterovirus types. Herpangina: Sudden fever, painful throat ulcers; Enterovirus A. Acute Hemorrhagic Conjunctivitis: Red eyes with hemorrhage; Enterovirus D.Myocarditis and Pericarditis: Heart inflammation, and chest pain, caused by Enterovirus B. Acute Flaccid Myelitis (AFM): Neurological condition causing limb weakness, often Enterovirus D68. Neonatal Sepsis-like Illness: Severe illness in newborns, fever, irritability, potential organ failure. EC HO Viru sFecal-or alAseptic Meningitis: Fever, headache, neck stiffness; most common ECHO virus manifestation. Exanthems: Non-specific rashes, often in children. Upper Respiratory Infections: Cough, sore throat, mild fever. Gastroenteritis: Vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain.Myocarditis and Pericarditis: Can lead to chest pain, and palpitations. While Enterovirus (especially EV-D68) can cause AFM, this rare and severe presentation is not as common in the age group described and is usually associated with paralysis rather than a mild rash and meningitis. Coxsackie B virus; HFMD (Option B), is incorrect as Coxsackie B is known for causing myocarditis and pericarditis, not HFMD, which is typically associated with Coxsackie A. HFMD also commonly presents with mouth sores, which are not seen here. Poliovirus; Myocarditis (Option D) is incorrect as Poliovirus can cause flaccid paralysis but is not known to cause myocarditis. Additionally, polio is now rare due to vaccination and does not fit the presentation of fever with aseptic meningitis.

questions.question: A 25-year-old patient with a history of asthma comes to your clinic with complaints of a runny nose, sore throat, mild cough, and a low-grade fever that started a few days ago. On examination, you note nasal congestion but no wheezing or serious respiratory distress. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms, and what’s the underlying mechanism?

options.A: Rhinovirus infection, attaching to ICAM-1 receptors in the nasal lining and triggering
options.B: Influenza virus infection causes a systemic cytokine storm by binding to respiratory
options.C: Adenovirus infection binds to lower respiratory tract cells, leading to cell damage and
options.D: Streptococcus pneumoniae infection colonizes the throat and releases toxins that

questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Rhinovirus infection, attaching to ICAM-1 receptors in the nasal lining and triggering inflammation. Explanation:   Rhinovirus, a common cold culprit, binds to ICAM-1 receptors in the upper respiratory tract, particularly in the nose.   This process triggers cytokines, which cause congestion, a sore throat, and mild fever.   His asthma might make him a little more sensitive, but rhinovirus usually stays in the upper airways, rarely moving deeper. Rhinovirus classification: Family Picornaviridae, over 100 serotypes in three species (A, B, and C), with type C often causing more severe symptoms.   Transmission: Spread by respiratory droplets and contact with contaminated surfaces.   Attachment: Binds to ICAM-1 receptors on upper respiratory epithelial cells, where it replicates, causing cell damage.   Immune Response: Infected cells release cytokines, causing inflammation and typical cold symptoms.   Temperature Sensitivity: Thrives at 33-35°C, usually limited to the upper respiratory tract. Influenza virus infection causes a systemic cytokine storm by binding to respiratory epithelial cells (Option B), is incorrect as Influenza, although viral, causes more severe symptoms like high fever, body aches, and fatigue. The patient is not experiencing the intense symptoms flu often brings. Adenovirus infection, binding to cells in the lower respiratory tract, leading to cell damage and high fever (Option C), is incorrect as Adenovirus can also cause respiratory symptoms but typically involves more intense fever and possibly conjunctivitis (eye irritation). This patient's symptoms do not fit that picture. Streptococcus pneumoniae infection colonizes the throat and releases toxins that cause severe pain and fever (Option D): This is incorrect as this bacterium is behind conditions like pneumonia and sometimes throat infections, but it is much more aggressive. Fever tends to be high, and there would likely be sharp pain or significant chest symptoms, which does not align with this patient’s profile.

questions.question: A 30-year-old wildlife researcher, who received a full pre-exposure rabies vaccination series two years ago, is bitten by a stray dog in a rural area with known rabies cases. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

options.B: Give a booster dose of rabies vaccine on Days 0 and 3, without Rabies Immunoglobulin
options.C: No additional vaccination or treatment is needed, as the patient completed the
options.D: Administer a single booster dose of rabies vaccine with Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG)

questions.question: Carlos, a 40-year-old father and avid hiker, arrives at the emergency department after being bitten by a stray dog on his forearm while out on a rural trail. The bite is deep enough that it has broken the skin, causing some bleeding. Carlos mentions he's never received a rabies vaccination before and is anxious about the possibility of infection. What is the most appropriate next step in managing Carlos’s injury?

options.A: Clean the wound and reassure Carlos that no further treatment is necessary.
options.B: Clean the wound and administer a series of rabies vaccines on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14,
options.C: Thoroughly wash the wound, administer rabies vaccines on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14, and
options.D: Give Carlos a single dose of rabies vaccine and Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) for rapid

questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Thoroughly wash the wound, administer rabies vaccines on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14, and provide Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) around the wound site. Explanation:   Carlos’s injury is classified as a Category III exposure because the bite broke the skin and caused bleeding.   For Category III exposures, particularly in unvaccinated individuals, treatment requires thorough wound cleaning, a full series of rabies vaccinations, and Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) around the wound to provide immediate passive immunity.
