questions.question: Which of the following statements is accurate regarding antigenic drift?

options.A: There is a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure
options.B: Causes a sudden increase in the number of cases
options.C: The new antigens formed are unrelated to the previous antigens
options.D: Antibodies to the predecessor viruses do not neutralize the new variants

questions.solution: Correct Option A - There is a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure:   Antigenic drift is a phenomenon that occurs in influenza viruses. It involves a gradual sequential change in the antigenic structure of the virus due to mutations in the genes that code for its surface proteins.   These surface proteins, hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) are responsible for the recognition and binding of the virus to host cells and the release of newly formed virus particles from infected cells, respectively.   The accumulation of these mutations in the HA and NA genes over time can lead to the emergence of new strains. Incorrect Options: Option B - Causes a sudden increase in the number of cases: This is inaccurate because antigenic drift is less likely to cause major epidemics and pandemics. Option C - The new antigens formed are unrelated to the previous antigens: The new antigens formed due to antigenic drift are related to the previous antigens, so they react with antisera to the predecessor virus strains to varying degrees. Option D - Antibodies to the predecessor viruses do not neutralize the new variants: Antibodies to the predecessor viruses still provide some degree of cross-protection against the new variants, but the degree of protection may vary depending on the degree of antigenic similaritybetween the old and new strains.

questions.question: Which of the following organism is represented by the given form of replication ?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Influenza Virus:   The correct choice for the given form of replication is the Influenza virus.   Influenza virus is an RNA virus that belongs to the Orthomyxoviridae family. Its replication process involves several distinct steps: Attachment: The spikes of hemagglutinin bind to sialic acid found on the surface of the host cell’s membrane. Entry: The virus enters the host cell by endocytosis, which involves the engulfment of the virus particle by the cell membrane and the formation of a vesicle called an endosome. Fusion: The viral envelope fuses with the endosomal membrane, and the M2 ion channel allows entry of H+ ions - H+ influx, resulting in uncoating and releasing the viral genetic material into the host cell's cytoplasm. Replication: The viral RNA serves as a template for the synthesis of new viral RNA segments (turning negative sense RNA into positive sense RNA), as well as viral proteins. The viral RNA polymerase, which is carried by the virus, is responsible for replicating and transcribing the viral RNA. Assembly: Newly synthesized viral RNA segments and proteins are assembled into new virus particles within the host cell. Budding: The assembled virus particles bud from the host cell's plasma membrane, acquiring an envelope derived from the host cell membrane. This process allows the virus to be released by neuraminidase and potentially infect other cells. questions.question: Choose the correct statement regarding CMV.

options.A: Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene
options.B: CMV can be cultured in vitro in any mammalian cell
options.C: Commonest manifestation of CMV associated disease is watery diarrhea
options.D: UL54 mutated CMV strains do not show cross resistance to Foscarnet

questions.solution: Correct Option A - Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene:   Ganciclovir is a nucleoside DNA polymerase inhibitor an antiviral drug commonly used for the treatment of CMV infections. Resistance to ganciclovir can occur due to mutations in the UL97 and UL54 gene of CMV.   Ganciclovir is converted by viral phosphotransferase encoded by the CMV UL97 gene to form ganciclovir triphosphate that inhibits CMV DNA polymerase. Mutations in the UL97 gene can result in reduced phosphorylation of ganciclovir, leading to decreased efficacy ofthe drug and the development of resistance. Incorrect Options: Option B - CMV can be cultured in vitro in any mammalian cell: Human fibroblasts are the most specific and ideal cell lines for the isolation of the cytomegalovirus. Option C - The commonest manifestation of CMV-associated disease is watery diarrhea: CMV is the most common infection associated with congenital defects. In Immunocompetent individuals, after transplantation, it causes mononucleosis-like disease, and in immunocompromised individuals (HIV/transplantation), it causes, most commonly, CMV retinitis. Option D - UL54 mutated CMV strains do not show cross-resistance to Foscarnet: UL54 refers to the DNA polymerase gene of CMV, which is the target of antiviral drugs like ganciclovir and foscarnet, and mutation in this gene can lead to resistance against ganciclovir, foscarnet, and cidofovir.

questions.question: Which of the following investigative procedures does not require the use of real-time PCR to determine viral load?

options.A: Person with hepatitis B on tenofovir therapy
options.B: Detection of HSV causing temporal encephalitis
options.C: BK virus in patient of allograft renal transplant
options.D: CMV in patient of liver transplant

questions.solution: Correct Option B - Detection of HSV Causing Temporal Encephalitis:   Real-time PCR is used for the quantification, hence real-time PCR is not preferred for detection of HSV causing temporal encephalitis, instead conventional PCR is preferred for the detection of the HSV DNA in cerebrospinal fluid. It can also differentiate between HSV 1 and HSV 2. Monitoring viral load is not routinely performed. Incorrect Options: Option A - Person with Hepatitis B on Tenofovir Therapy: In individuals with hepatitis B receiving tenofovir therapy, monitoring the viral load using real-time PCR is essential. It helps determine the response to treatment, assess viral suppression, and evaluate the risk of drug resistance. Option C - BK Virus in a Patient with Allograft Renal Transplant: BK virus infection can occur in patients who have undergone renal transplantation. Monitoring the viral load using real-time PCR in urine or blood samples is important to detect and manage BK virus-associated complications, such as nephropathy. Option D - CMV in a Patient with Liver Transplant: Cytomegalovirus infection is a significant concern in patients undergone solid organ transplantation. Real-time PCR for CMV viral load in blood is commonly performed in these patients to monitor for active infection, guide antiviraltherapy, and assess response to treatment.

questions.question: Northern blotting is used for detection of which of the following ?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - RNA:   Northern blotting is a laboratory technique used to study gene expression by detecting and analyzing mRNA. It involves the separation of RNA molecules based on their size using gel electrophoresis, followed by their transfer onto a solid support membrane (usually nylon or nitrocellulose). The transferred RNA molecules are then immobilized on the membrane.   To detect specific RNA molecules, the membrane is hybridized with a labeled nucleic acid probe that is complementary to the target RNA sequence of interest. The probe binds specifically to its complementary RNA sequence on the membrane, allowing the detection and visualization of the target RNA molecule. Incorrect Options: Option A - DNA: Southern blotting is used for the detection of DNA molecules. Option C - Proteins: Western blotting, immunohistochemistry, or enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) are commonly used for protein detection and analysis. Option D - None: Northern blotting is specifically used for the detection of RNA molecules.

questions.question: Which type of infection is more likely to occur following the transfusion of Solvent/Detergent (SD) plasma, given its ability to destroy lipid-enveloped viruses?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Hepatitis A Virus (HAV):   Hepatitis A virus (HAV) infection is likely to occur with transfusion of solvent/detergent (SD) plasma. Solvent/detergent treatment is a method used to inactivate lipid-enveloped viruses in plasma products. It involves the use of organic solvents and detergents to disrupt the lipid envelope of viruses, rendering them non-infectious. This treatment method is effective against lipid-enveloped viruses.   Non-enveloped DNA viruses - parvovirus, adenovirus and papovavirus   Non-enveloped RNA viruses - picornavirus, reovirus, calicivirus, hepatitis A virus, and hepatitis E virus. Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are incorrect. These are enveloped viruses that can be destroyed by the solvent/detergent method.

questions.question: During the period between 1 to 4 months following renal transplantation, which pathogen is most commonly responsible for infecting renal transplant recipients?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Cytomegalovirus:   Cytomegalovirus (CMV), is the predominant pathogen to infect renal (solid organ) transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following transplantation because of reactivation of the virus in immunocompromised individuals.   The immunosuppressive medications taken by transplant recipients increase their susceptibility to CMV infection, which can lead to significant morbidity and complications in the early post-transplant period. questions.question: Viral infection mimicking erythroblastosis fetalis is:
questions.solution: Correct Option D - Parvovirus B19: Parvovirus B19 infection is known to cause a condition called “fifth disease” or erythema infectiosum. In some cases, Parvovirus B19 can lead to a transient aplastic crisis in a patient with an underlying hemolytic condition and hydrops fetalis, which mimics erythroblastosis fetalis. The virus infects erythroid progenitor cells, leading to temporary suppression of red blood cell production. Parvovirus B19 is, therefore, a viral infection that mimics erythroblastosis fetalis. Incorrect Options: Option A - HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus): HSV infection is primarily associated with oral or genital ulcers, and it does not typically mimic erythroblastosis fetalis. Option B - Epstein-Barr Virus: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is the causative agent of infectious mononucleosis. Although EBV can cause abnormal liver function and anemia, it does not specifically mimic erythroblastosis fetalis. Option C - Picornavirus: Picornaviruses are a large family of viruses that include common viruses such as rhinoviruses and enteroviruses. While certain picornaviruses can cause mild respiratory or gastrointestinal symptoms, they do not mimic erythroblastosis fetalis.

After the entry of the virus inside the cell, three types of proteins, i.e., alpha, beta, and gamma, are formed via transcription and replication, which are pathognomonic of the herpes virus.   It has two cycles: Lytic cycle: Immediate-early genes are expressed first, initiating the lytic life cycle of the virus, leading to the production of infectious virions and lysis of the host cell. questions.question: A 24-year-old male patient presented to the outpatient department with cervical lymphadenopathy. As a part of the evaluation, the Paul-Bunnell test was done. What is the principle of this test?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Heterophile Antibodies:   The principle of the Paul-Bunnell test, also known as the Monospot test is done for Infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus, is based on the detection of heterophile antibodies.   Heterophile antibodies are a type of antibody that can react with multiple antigens, including those that are not specific to the infecting pathogen.   In the Paul-Bunnell test, sheep or horse red blood cells (RBCs) that have been coated with antigens obtained from the EBV-infected cells are combined with the patient's serum.   The coated RBCs will agglutinate (clump together), suggesting a positive reaction if the patient has heterophile antibodies specific to the EBV. Incorrect Options: Option A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.question: Which of the following viruses cannot integrate with the human genome to initiate carcinogenesis?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - HAV:   Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is an RNA virus that causes acute liver infection but does not integrate into the host genome or cause cancer. Unlike other hepatitis viruses (such as HBV and HCV), HAV does not have a chronic phase and is not associated with hepatocellular carcinoma. Incorrect Options: Option A - HPV: Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is a DNA virus that primarily presents with cutaneous and mucosal lesions. High-risk HPV types, such as HPV-16 and HPV-18, are strongly associated with the development of cervical, anal, vulvar, vaginal, penile, and oropharyngeal cancers. E6 and E7 viral oncoproteins are expressed by high-risk HPV types and can inactivate the p53 and RB proteins, respectively, leading to uncontrolled cell growth and increased risk of malignancy. Option B - SV 40: Simian vacuolating virus 40 is a Polyomavirus associated with mesothelioma. Large T antigen and small T antigen are the two viral oncoproteins that are expressed by SV 40 and can inactivate p53, RB, and PP2A, leading to malignancy. Option D - EBV: Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) is a herpesvirus that infects B lymphocytes and epithelial cells. EBV is associated with the development of several malignancies, including Burkitt's lymphoma, Hodgkin's lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, and some gastric cancers. LMP 1 viral oncoproteins are expressed by EBV and can inactivate TRAFs (tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated factor), leading to malignancy.

questions.question: Reinfection with which of the following virus can lead to more severe disease with complications?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Dengue:   Dengue is caused by four different serotypes of the dengue virus (DEN-1, DEN-2, DEN-3, and DEN-4). If a person is infected with one serotype and later gets infected with a different serotype, they are at a higher risk of developing severe dengue, also known as dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) or dengue shock syndrome (DSS). This phenomenon is known asantibody-dependent enhancement (ADE).   ADE occurs when the antibodies produced during the first infection bind to the virus particles of the second serotype but fail to neutralize them effectively. ADE was shown to enhance viral entry into immune cells via their Fc γ receptors, which promotes viral replication, leading to increased viremia and pro-inflammatory responses. Incorrect Options: Option B - Rabies: Rabies is a viral infection transmitted through the bite or scratch of an infected animal. Once the symptoms of rabies develop, it is almost always fatal. Option C - Measles: Measles is a highly contagious viral infection. Although reinfection with measles is possible, it does not typically lead to more severe disease or complications. However, being unvaccinated or having a compromised immune system can increase the risk of severe measles and its complications. Option D - Mumps: Mumps is a viral infection that primarily affects the parotid gland and salivary glands, leading to swelling and pain. Reinfection with mumps is rare, as most people develop long-lasting immunity after recovering from the initial infection.

It is usually reliable from the early days of infection, making it a suitable option on day 3. Option D- Xenodiagnosis using Culture in Aedes Mosquito:   Xenodiagnosis involves allowing Aedes mosquitoes to feed on the patient's blood and then testing the mosquitoes for the presence of the virus. This technique is generally not performed, but can be done in the early stage of infection.

questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) To promote the identification of Cryptococcus neoformans through melanin production Explanation: Bird seed agar is used to identify Cryptococcus neoformans, as this species produces melanin on the medium, resulting in a characteristic dark brown or black colour. Other Cultures in Mycology: Czapek-Dox Medium:   Used for isolating and cultivating a wide range of fungi, particularly nutrient-demanding species.   Chemically defined, allowing for precise study of fungal physiology and metabolism. Bird Seed Agar:   Specifically designed for isolating and identifying Cryptococcus neoformans & gatti. (Options A&B ruled out)   Contains Niger seeds, which facilitate melanin production in Cryptococcus neoformans, leading to brown to black pigmented colonies. (Option D ruled out) Corn Meal Agar:   Stimulates sporulation and reveals morphological characteristics of fungi, especially yeasts like Candida albicans and Candida dubinensis.   Simple medium made from corn meal extract; Tween 80 can be added to enhance chlamydospore production for identification. Note: Non-specific media, like blood agar, can be adapted for fungal use with antibacterials. Incubation Temperatures: Cultures are incubated at 22°C (room temperature) and 37°C to observe growth patterns and aid in species differentiation. Fungal Culture Techniques: Technique Purpose Macroscopic Clues Growth rate, texture, and colour help in identifying fungal species. Microscopic Analysis Reveals fungal morphology through mounts and stains, detailing hyphae, conidia. Importance of Fungal Cultures: Aspect Description Definitive Diagnosis Confirms fungal species responsible for infection, guiding specific treatments. Species Differentiation Distinguishes species by growth and microscopic traits, aiding in understanding fungi's role. Antifungal Susceptibility TestingDetermines fungal sensitivity to antifungals, guiding effective therapy.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of using potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation in clinical specimens?

options.A: Enhance the visibility of fungi by staining
options.B: Digest keratin and reveal fungal structures

questions.solution: Answer: B) Digest keratin and reveal fungal structures Explanation: KOH preparation dissolves keratin, allowing fungal elements to be clearly visible under the microscope. questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with cough, nasal discomfort and weight loss. He has a travel history to South America in the past. On examination, he is found to have ulcerative granulomas on his nasal and buccal mucosa. A microscopic examination of the lesion is shown below. Which is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Answer: C) Paracoccidioides Explanation: Based on the travel history, clinical manifestation and characteristic mariner’s or pilot’s wheel appearance on microscopy, the most probable diagnosis is Paracoccidioidomycosis. It is caused by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis. Paracoccidioidomy cosis Causative agent Thermally dimorphic fungus Paracoccidioides brasiliensis. (Option C) Epidemiology Confined to South America, it is called South American blastomycosis. Route of transmiss ionInhalation of spores Clinical features Chronic granulomatous disease of the skin, mucosa, lymph nodes and internal organs. Primary pulmonary infection spreads by the hematogenous route to the mucosa of the nose, mouth, gastrointestinal tract, skin and lymphatics. Ulcerative granulomas of the buccal, and nasal mucosa. Diagnosis ... (content truncated) Treatment Itraconazole is the drug of choice Histoplasma (Option A): It causes histoplasmosis, especially in immunocompromised patients. It can cause pulmonary and systemic infections. Microscopy shows small intra- and extracellular yeast cells. This option is incorrect. Blastomyces (Option B): It causes blastomycosis. It primarily causes pulmonary symptoms and may disseminate to the skin, bones, and other organs. The yeast form of Blastomyces is typically large, thick-walled, and appears as single broad-based buds. This option is incorrect. Cryptococcus (Option D): It causes cryptococcosis, primarily in immunocompromised individuals. It commonly presents as a pulmonary or central nervous system infection, but mucosal involvement is rare. The yeast cells of Cryptococcus are typically round or oval, single-celled, and surrounded by a thick capsule, with no multiple budding patterns. This option is incorrect.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male with a history of AIDS presents to the clinic with persistent fever, significant weight loss over the past month, and cough that has worsened over the last two weeks. He resides in a rural area of Southeast Asia, where he frequently encounters bamboo rats. On physical examination, he has cervical lymphadenopathy and hepatomegaly. A sputum sample is collected for microbiological examination. An image is shown below. Which of the following is characteristic of the colony that is likely to grow in culture from this patient’s sputum sample?

options.B: Green, granular colonies with a distinctive red pigment
options.D: Creamy white, smooth colonies and with a yeasty odour

questions.solution: Answer: B) Green, granular colonies with a distinctive red pigment Explanation: Given the patient's symptoms, history of exposure to bamboo rats, and immunocompromised status due to AIDS, microscopy showing septate hyphae with branched conidiophores, the likely pathogen is Talaromyces marneffei. This fungus produces green, granular colonies with a distinctive red pigment that diffuses into the agar when cultured on Sabouraud agar, which is a characteristic feature of this organism. Penicillium marneffei Characteristics Currently, the name is changed to Talaromyces marneffei. Thermally dimorphic fungus Causes Talaromycosis (Penicilliosis) Epidemiology Common in Southeast Asia, southern China, and northeastern India. High incidence in AIDS and immunocompromised patients. Reservoir Bamboo rat Route of transmission Inhalation of fungal spores No person-to-person transmission Clinical manifestation sIt affects the reticuloendothelial system, causing lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, and splenomegaly. Lung involvement is common. Increased risk of dissemination in AIDS and immunocompromised individuals. Specimens for DiagnosisBone marrow, blood, sputum, lymph nodes, skin lesions Diagnosis ... (content truncated) Treatment Amphotericin B (IV for two weeks), followed by Itraconazole. Others: Voriconazole, Posaconazole. White, cottony, mycelial growth (Option A): It is typically associated with Histoplasma capsulatum. This option is incorrect. Smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies (Option C): It is typically associated with Cryptococcus neoformans. This option is incorrect. Creamy white, smooth colonies and with a yeasty odour (Option D): It is typically associated with Candida albicans. This option is incorrect.

questions.question: What microscopic features are not observed when examining cultures of Histoplasma capsulatum?
questions.solution: Answer: D) Intracellular yeast cells Explanation: Intracellular yeast cells are seen in stained tissue samples or body fluids during microscopic examination and not in cultures. questions.question: A 35-year-old male from a tropical region presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and a soft, fleshy nasal mass. Histopathological examination reveals thick-walled sporangia filled with endospores and hyperplastic tissue without eosinophilic infiltration. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is correct?

options.A: It affects the mucosal membrane of the nose only.
options.B: The recommended course of primary treatment is Dapsone
options.C: The causative agent cannot be cultured in vitro
options.D: It is not associated with contaminated water exposure

questions.solution: Answer: C) The causative agent cannot be cultured in vitro. Explanation: Rhinosporidium seeberi is a eukaryotic pathogen that exhibits characteristics of both fungi and protozoa, making it difficult to culture in laboratory settings. questions.question: A biopsy from a cutaneous lesion in a patient with suspected sporotrichosis is examined under a microscope. Which of the following findings would strongly support the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Answer: C) Cigar-shaped yeast cells Explanation: Sporothrix schenckii in the yeast phase is often described as cigar-shaped, which helps differentiate it from other fungi. Sporotrichosis Causative agent Dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii. Epidemiology Common in gardeners, forest workers, and manual labourers. Route of transmission Minor trauma or thorn prick. Clinical features Chronic infection affects cutaneous, subcutaneous, and lymphatic tissue. Lesions form at sites of minor trauma or thorn pricks, starting as nodules. ... Thick-walled spherules filled with endospores (Option A): It is characteristic of Coccidioides immitis, the causative agent of coccidioidomycosis. This option is incorrect. Mariner’s wheel-shaped yeast cells (Option B): It is characteristic of Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, which causes paracoccidioidomycosis. This option is incorrect. Broad-based budding yeast cells (Option D): It is characteristic of Blastomyces dermatitidis, the causative organism of blastomycosis. This option is incorrect.

questions.question: Which of the following statements best describes the typical transmission route of Coccidioides immitis?

options.D: Insect bite from an endemic vector

questions.solution: Answer: B) Inhalation of dust containing arthrospores Explanation: Coccidioides immitis is transmitted through the inhalation of dust containing fungal arthrospores, especially in arid, dusty environments. Coccidioidomycos is Causative agent Thermally dimorphic fungus Coccidioides immitis. Route of transmis sionInhalation of dust containing fungal arthrospores. (Option B) Clinical features Self-limited, flu-like fever ("valley fever" or "desert rheumatism"). Primary pulmonary infection. Severe cases: Less than 1% develop chronic disseminated disease (coccidioidal granuloma), which can be fatal. Diagnosis In tissue: Spherules with a thick, doubly refractile wall, filled with endospores. Culture: Mycelial phase with hyphae that fragment into arthrospores. Arthrospores are infective. Skin test: Positive delayed hypersensitivity with " coccidioidin." Treatment Mild cases: Fluconazole or itraconazole. Severe cases: Amphotericin B.

questions.question: A 50-year-old immunocompromised patient presents with cough, fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. She reports having recently cleaned out an old barn where she encountered large amounts of bird droppings. Upon examination, she has mild tachycardia and her lungs exhibit scattered crackles on auscultation. A chest X-ray shows patchy infiltrates and several calcified nodules. Histopathology and (LPCB) mount of colonies grown in culture are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution: Answer: B) Amphotericin-B by itraconazole Explanation:   Based on the patient’s history, histopathology showing intramacrophagic yeast form and (LPCB) mount showing numerous hyaline hyphae with few tuberculate macroconidia (arrows) and many smooth-walled oval microconidia are pointing towards a diagnosis of disseminated histoplasmosis.   The recommended treatment for disseminated histoplasmosis, especially in immunocompromised patients, is Amphotericin-B. After stabilization, itraconazole is prescribed usually for a year to prevent recurrence and manage the infection. Histoplasmosis Causative Agent Histoplasma capsulatum; thermally dimorphic fungus. H. capsulatum var. capsulatum: Causes classical histoplasmosis. H. capsulatum var. duboisii: Causes African histoplasmosis. Epidemiology Endemic to central and eastern USA; also found in Africa. Route of transmission Thrives in soil, decaying trees, and bird droppings. Inhalation of fungal spores. Clinical manifestations Classical histoplasmosis is often asymptomatic. Calcified lesions. Pulmonary disease mimics tuberculosis. Disseminated histoplasmosis can occur. Infection of the reticuloendothelial system causes: Lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, fever, and anaemia Skin and mucous membrane: Granulomatous and ulcerative lesions. African Histoplasmosis: It primarily affects the skin, subcutaneous tissues, and bones Lungs are rarely involved, and disseminated cases are infrequent Specimens for DiagnosisBlood, urine, bone marrow, lesions Diagnosis ... (content truncated) Treatment Amphotericin-B for two to four weeks followed by a year of itraconazole (Option A ruled out) Fluconazole (Option C): It is usually reserved for less severe infections or maintenance therapy after initial treatment with more potent antifungals like amphotericin-B. This option is incorrect. Surgical resection (Option D): It may be considered for localized infections or complications like abscesses, but it is not appropriate as a primary treatment strategy for disseminated histoplasmosis.

questions.question: A 40-year-old male from North America presents with cough, fever, and weight loss. Chest imaging shows focal consolidation in the lungs, and he has developed ulcerative skin lesions on his face as shown below. A skin biopsy is performed, and the sample is sent for GMS staining. An image of the GMS stain is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Answer: A) Blastomycosis Explanation: Blastomycosis is caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis, a dimorphic fungus commonly found in North America. It often presents with respiratory symptoms (cough, fever, weight loss) and may disseminate to the skin, forming ulcerative lesions. Microscopically, the spherical yeast cells with a thick double-contoured black-coloured wall and a broad-based bud, visible with GMS staining, are classic for blastomycosis, making this the most likely diagnosis. Blastomycosis Causative Agent: Blastomyces dermatitidis, a thermally dimorphic fungus. Epidemiology Primarily found in North America; cases are also reported in Africa and Delhi, India. Route of transmis sionInhalation of fungal spores from contaminated soil. Clinical manifesta tions Acute or chronic infection, characterised by the formation of suppurative and granulomatous lesions with a marked preference for lungs and skin. Primary Lung Infection: Mimics tuberculosis or histoplasmosis; symptoms vary from asymptomatic to severe with focal consolidation, miliary lesions, or abscesses. Disseminated Disease: Spreads through the bloodstream, forming multiple abscesses; high fatality rate. Cutaneous Disease: Begins as a papule, forming large, ulcerative lesions, often on the face or other exposed skin. Diagnosis Microscopy: Large, thick double-contoured wall, spherical yeast with a single broad-based bud. Grocott's methenamine silver (GMS) stain: Black staining of fungal cell walls. Treatment Itraconazole: For mild to moderate cases. Amphotericin B: For severe and life-threatening cases. Chromoblastomycosis (Option B): It is a chronic fungal infection, that typically presents as warty, nodular skin lesions, not as ulcerative lesions. It is commonly found in tropical regions and is not associated with lung involvement or systemic symptoms like weight loss. Microscopic examination shows sclerotic bodies. This option is incorrect. Mycotic Mycetoma (Option C): It is caused by the fungi Madurella mycetomatis. It presents as a chronic infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissue, and sometimes bone, usually in the feet. It manifests as nodules that can develop into draining sinuses and does not typically form warty lesions or display sclerotic bodies in microscopy. This option is incorrect. Sporotrichosis (Option D): It is caused by Sporothrix schenckii, often occurs after a traumatic implantation and typically presents with nodular lesions that can ulcerate, forming a lymphatic spread pattern. Microscopy of sporotrichosis shows cigar-shaped yeast cells instead. This option is incorrect.

questions.question: Dimorphic fungi can evade the host immune system primarily through which of the following mechanisms?

options.B: Conversion to a yeast form in the host

questions.solution: Answer: B) Conversion to a yeast form in the host Explanation: In the environment, dimorphic fungi exist in mold form but convert to yeast form in the host (at 37°C). The yeast form is typically more resistant to phagocytosis and immune responses, allowing the fungi to survive and multiply in the host. Dimorphic Fungus Have the ability to convert between two specific morphologic forms, yeast and hyphae. questions.question: A 45-year-old male agricultural worker from a rural area presents with an extensive slowly growing, warty, nodular lesion on his lower leg as shown in the image below. The lesion is dark, and rough, and resembles the surface of cauliflower. He recalls injuring his leg on a thorn while working barefoot in the fields several months ago. A KOH mount of the skin specimen is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Answer: B) Chromoblastomycosis Explanation: Chromoblastomycosis is a fungal infection often seen in individuals from tropical regions who have sustained trauma, such as an injury from a thorn. It commonly presents as slowly growing, warty, nodular lesions resembling cauliflower. The presence of sclerotic bodies (round, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septate) in KOH mounts is characteristic, making it the most likely diagnosis in this case. Chromoblastomycosis (Also known as verrucous dermatitis) Epidemiology It is the most common form of chromomycosis. Common among barefoot agricultural workers and woodcutters. Tropical region. Causative agents Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Fonsecaea compacta, Exophiala dermatitidis, Phialophora, Cladophialophora. Route of transmission Infecting fungi enter the skin by traumatic implantation. Clinical manifestation Warty, cutaneous nodular lesions (resemble the florets of cauliflower). Usually confined to subcutaneous tissue of the feet and lower legs Slow-developing lesions around the site of implantation. questions.question: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the Splendore–Hoeppli phenomenon?

options.A: It is exclusively seen in functional infections
options.B: It is never associated with parasitic infestations
options.C: It can occur in both infectious and noninfectious conditions
options.D: It does not involve any immune cells

questions.solution: Answer: C) It can occur in both infectious and noninfectious conditions. Explanation: The Splendore–Hoeppli phenomenon is seen in a variety of conditions, both infectious (fungal, bacterial, or parasitic infections) and noninfectious (Hypereosinophilic syndrome and allergic conjunctival granulomas). Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon   Splendore–Hoeppli phenomenon (asteroid bodies) involves microorganisms or inert substances surrounded by radiating eosinophilic material   Microscopically, it appears as strongly eosinophilic, amorphous material with star-like or club-shaped formations. Bacterial infections Botryomycosis, nocardiosis actinomycosis. Parasitic infestations Orbital pythiosis, strongyloidiasis, schistosomiasis cutaneous larva migrans. Noninfective pathologies Hypereosinophilic syndrome allergic conjunctival granulomas.

questions.solution: Answer: B) Piedraia hortae Explanation: Piedraia hortae is the causative agent of black piedra, characterized by dark nodules on scalp hair and the presence of branched hyphae and arthrospores upon microscopic examination. Treatment Antifungal shampoos or systemic antifungals; treatment efficacy may be compromised by nodules' compact nature. questions.question: A 32-year-old HIV-positive male presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of worsening shortness of breath, dry cough, and fever. He reports significant weight loss over the past month and has a CD4 count of 150 cells/mm³. HRCT Thorax shows ground-glass opacities. A bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) is performed, and a histological examination shows organisms with a characteristic appearance, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Pneumocystis Carinii pneumonia (PCP) Explanation: Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia (PCP), now known as Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, is a common opportunistic infection in immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with HIV/AIDS. Pneumocystis jirovecii Morphology Trophozoite - thin-walled, irregularly shaped, 1-5 µm in size Precyst - an intermediate stage of the sexual phase, 5-8 µm in size Cyst - thick-walled, spherical, containing up to 8 intracystic bodies and up to 8 µm in size Risk factors HIV: CD4 < 200 Primary immunodeficiency states Transplant recipients Hematological malignancies Clinical features transmitted by respiratory droplets and is asymptomatic in immunocompetent individuals. In immunocompromised patients, life-threatening pneumonia develops. PCP - Pneumocystis Carinii pneumonia Dyspnoea Dry cough Fever Weight loss B/L interstitial pneumonia Diagnosis ... (content truncated) Treatment The cornerstone for both prevention and treatment is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Alternative therapies have been used in AIDS patients; they include pentamidine, trimethoprim-dapsone, clindamycin-primaquine, atovaquone, and trimetrexate. Bacterial pneumonia (Option A): Is caused by various bacteria (e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus) and typically presents with symptoms such as productive cough, high fever, and localized crackles on auscultation. Chest X-rays often show lobar consolidation rather than the diffuse ground-glass opacities characteristic of PCP. Tuberculosis (TB) (Option B): Is a chronic infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It usually presents with a persistent cough, night sweats, weight loss, and hemoptysis. Fungal pneumonia (Option D): Can be caused by various fungi, such as Histoplasma, Coccidioides, or Cryptococcus. These infections typically present differently from PCP, often with more localized symptoms and findings on imaging

questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Rhizopus Arrhizus Explanation: Rhizopus Arrhizus, also known as R. oryzae, is the most common causative organism of mucormycosis, especially in diabetic patients. questions.question: Which of the following statements about Cryptococcus are correct? i. It is a mould type of fungi ii. Polypeptide capsule provides significant protection against phagocytosis. iii. Exposure to bird droppings can increase the likelihood of infection. iv. Cryptococcus neoformans is the principle pathogenic species v. Cryptococcus gattii is associated with B, C serotypes.
questions.solution: Correct answer: C) iii, iv and v only Explanation: Cryptococcus Spp. Cryptococcus is a true yeast. (Statement i) Capsule Polysaccharide capsule - helps in serotyping and protection against phagocytosis . (Statement ii) Serotypes A, D, AD serotypes - Cryptococcus variety neoformans (Statement iv) B, C serotypes -Cryptococcus variety gattii (Statement v) Virulence factors Polysaccharide Capsule: The primary virulence factor. It helps the pathogen evade phagocytosis and suppresses the host’s local immune responses, enabling the organism to survive and spread. Melanin Production: Cryptococcus produces melanin via the enzyme phenol oxidase, which contributes to its virulence by protecting the pathogen from oxidative stress and immune defenses. Enzyme Production: The fungus secretes several enzymes, including: Phospholipase: Aids in tissue invasion and damage. Urease: Helps the fungus survive in the host environment by neutralizing acidic conditions, enhancing its ability to colonize and spread. Risk of infection Immunocompromised States: HIV/AIDS, cancer, organ transplant recipients, those on immunosuppressive therapies, extremes of age are at higher risk. Geographic Location: Exposure to environments where Cryptococcus gattii is endemic, such as tropical and subtropical regions Environmental Exposure: Exposure to bird droppings or decaying wood can increase the likelihood of infection, especially with C. neoformans. (Statement iii)

questions.question: A 50-year-old male with a history of poorly controlled diabetes presents with white patches on the tongue and inner cheeks. On examination, the lesions can be scraped off, revealing a red, inflamed base. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct answer: B) Oral candidiasis Explanation: The diagnosis is Oral candidiasis/ Moniliasis, indicated by the presence of white patches that can be scraped off and the patient's risk factors, including poorly controlled diabetes. Oral candidiasis Oral candidiasis, commonly known as thrush, is an infection caused by an overgrowth of Candida albicans, a type of yeast. Presentation Presence of white patches that can be scraped off, leaving behind a red inflamed base {{caption_text}} Risk factors Diabetes: Poorly controlled diabetes creates a favorable environment for Candida growth due to elevated blood sugar levels. Neutropenia Immunosuppression: HIV/AIDS, cancer, or immunosuppressive medications increase susceptibility. Use of inhaled corticosteroids Antibiotic Use: Broad-spectrum antibiotics can disrupt normal oral flora, allowing Candida to overgrow. Poor Oral Hygiene: Leads to an increase in fungal colonization. Dry Mouth: Conditions that lead to reduced saliva production can promote candidiasis. Treatment Antifungal medications, such as nystatin or fluconazole, along with addressing any underlying risk factors. C. krusei- Resistant to azoles Oral leukoplakia (Option A) presents as white patches that cannot be scraped off and may indicate precancerous changes. Lichen planus (Option C) presents with white, lacy patches and ulcerations in the mouth. The lesions are typically painful and not easily scraped off. Herpes simplex stomatitis (Option D) caused by HSV, presents as gingivostomatitis or pharyngitis, with painful vesicles on the buccal mucosa. Recurrent infections often lead to herpes labialis. Other lesions can include ulcerative stomatitis, tonsillitis, and eyelid vesicles. Many cases are asymptomatic but may predispose to secondary bacterial infections.

questions.solution: Correct answer: D) It primarily affects immunocompromised individuals Explanation: Cryptococcus gattii is known for causing infections primarily in immunocompetent individuals, which distinguishes it from Cryptococcus neoformans, which mainly affects immunocompromised patients.   Commonly found in tropical and subtropical regions, particularly around eucalyptus trees (Options A and C)   It corresponds to the serotypes B and C (Option B)   C. gattii can cause severe respiratory illnesses and can disseminate to the CNS, leading to cryptococcal meningitis.   Diagnosis is typically made through microscopy, culture, serological tests for cryptococcal antigen, and imaging studies for lung lesions.   Treatment usually involves antifungal medications, such as amphotericin B and fluconazole, depending on the severity of the infection.

questions.question: A 40-year-old female presents to the clinic with a persistent cough, shortness of breath, and chest pain for the past month. She is currently on immunosuppressive therapy for an autoimmune condition. A chest CT reveals a solitary pulmonary nodule in the right upper lobe. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct answer: C) Pulmonary cryptococcosis Explanation: Pulmonary cryptococcosis is the most likely diagnosis due to the patient’s immunocompromised state and the solitary pulmonary nodule on imaging. Clinical features of cryptococcosis Respiratory system Cryptococcus typically enters the body via inhalation and can cause pulmonary infection/pneumonitis - primary site of infection Patients may present with cough, pleuritic chest pain, and respiratory distress. Imaging shows a solitary pulmonary nodule Dissemination of pulmonary infection leads to involvement of other organs Central Nervous System Meningitis: Characterized by severe headaches, fever, altered mental status, sensory and memory loss, cranial nerve paresis and loss of vision It is the most serious type of cryptococcal infection Skin Cutaneous Cryptococcosis: Causes skin lesions, particularly in immunocompromised patients. Associated with C.neoformans var neoformans (serotype D) Other Organs Liver, spleen, and bones may be involved in disseminated infections Bacterial pneumonia (Option A) typically presents with acute symptoms like high fever and productive cough, and Imaging usually shows diffuse infiltrates or lobar consolidation, not a solitary nodule Pulmonary tuberculosis (Option B) often involves systemic symptoms (weight loss, night sweats) and typically presents as multiple nodules or cavitary lesions on imaging Lung abscess (Option D) presents with localized symptoms and is associated with bacterial infections. Imaging typically reveals a cavity filled with pus, not a solitary nodule.

Gram stain (Option A) is used to classify bacteria into Gram-positive or Gram-negative, and it does not visualize the capsule of Cryptococcus. questions.question: In patients with diabetic ketoacidosis, which type of fungus is frequently linked to orbital cellulitis?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Rhizopus:   Rhizopus is a genus of fungi, and the species most commonly associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis is Rhizopus.   This fungal infection is known as rhinocerebral mucormycosis.   Rhizopus can invade the sinuses and orbit, leading to orbital cellulitis. questions.question: A 30-year-old patient presents with a skin infection characterized by itching, redness, and scaling. Microscopic examination of a skin sample reveals a pencil-shaped appearance. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism responsible for this skin infection?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Trichophyton   Trichophyton species are dermatophytic fungi that commonly cause fungal skin infections known as dermatophytoses or ringworm. These infections are characterized by itching, redness, and scaling of the skin. The term "pencil-shaped appearance" refers to the appearance of the fungal hyphae under the microscope, where the hyphae have a tapered, narrow appearance resembling a pencil. Trichophyton species can cause various types of dermatophytoses, including tinea corporis (ringworm of the body), tinea cruris (jock itch), tinea pedis (athlete's foot), and others. Incorrect Options: Option B - Microsporum: Microsporum species are another group of dermatophytic fungi that can cause fungal skin infections. They also lead to symptoms like itching, redness, and scaling. However, unlike the "pencil-shaped appearance" mentioned in the question, Microsporum species are known for their characteristic appearance under the microscope, where they produce large, multicellular, club-shaped structures called macroconidia. Therefore, this is not the correct answer in this case. Option C - Epidermophyton: Epidermophyton species are also dermatophytic fungi responsible for causing fungal skin infections. They can cause similar symptoms as described in the question, but the "pencil-shaped appearance" is not typically associated with Epidermophyton species. Instead, they produce smooth, thin-walled, and irregularly branched hyphae. Therefore, this is not the correct answer in this case. Option D - None of the above: This option is not the correct answer because the presentation of itching, redness, scaling, and the specific "pencil-shaped appearance" of hyphae in the skin sample is indicative of a dermatophytic fungal infection, and the most likely causative organism among the given options is Trichophyton.

questions.question: A 46-year-old farmer present with a traumatic ulcer in the eye. Microscopic examination reveals septate hyphae at an acute angle. Which of the following will be the causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Aspergillosis   Aspergillus is a fungus that can cause various infections collectively referred to as aspergillosis. The hyphae of Aspergillus are septate, meaning they have cross-walls that divide the hyphae into distinct segments. These septate hyphae often branch at acute angles, forming a characteristic "V" or "Y" shape. This description matches the findings in the question. Incorrect Options: Option A - Mucor: Mucor is a type of fungus that can cause mucormycosis, also known as zygomycosis. The hyphae of Mucor are wide, ribbon-like, and non-septate (aseptate). In other words, they lack cross-walls or septa. Option C -Candida: Candida is a yeast that can cause candidiasis. Yeasts typically do not form septate hyphae. Instead, they form pseudohyphae, which are chains of elongated yeast cells. These pseudohyphae do not show the acute-angle branching seen in the question's description. Option D - Rhizopus: Rhizopus is another type of fungus that can cause mucormycosis. Similar to Mucor, the hyphae of Rhizopus are wide, ribbon-like, and aseptate. They lack the cross-walls seen in septate hyphae.

questions.question: Which disease is commonly referred to as "Desert Rheumatism"?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Coccidomycosis:   Coccidioidomycosis, also known as "Valley fever" or "Desert rheumatism," is a fungal infection caused by Coccidioides immitis. It is commonly found in desert regions and can cause joint pain, hence the name "Desert Rheumatism." Incorrect Options:   Options B, C, and D are not referred to as Desert Rheumatism.

questions.question: Which organism is associated with broad-based budding?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Blastomyces:   Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungus that shows broad-based budding. Incorrect Options: Option A - Sporothrix schenckii: Sporothrix schenckii appears as rosettes of conidia on microscopy. Option C - Talaromyces marneffei: Talaromyces marneffei appear as brush/broom conidia on microscopy. Option D - Paracoccidioidomycosis: Paracoccidioidomycosis is characterized by a "pilot's wheel" or "Mickey Mouse" appearance of the yeast form.

questions.question: A central line infection is noted in an ICU patient, and staining shows a gram-positive oval-shaped organism that reproduces by budding. Identify the organism:
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Candida:   Candida species are yeast-like fungi that reproduce by budding and can cause central line infections, especially in immunocompromised patients. Incorrect Options: Option A - Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus are gram-positive cocci in clusters, not oval-shaped. Option C - Staphylococcus epidermidis: Staphylococcus epidermidis are gram-positive cocci in clusters, not oval-shaped. Option D - Escherichia coli: Escherichia coli are gram-negative rods.

questions.question: A 39-year-old patient with HIV and a CD4 count of 139 cells/µL presents with altered sensorium and impaired consciousness. CSF examination using an India ink preparation reveals a positive result. Which organism is most likely responsible?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A) Cryptococcus neoformans Explanation: A patient with HIV and a CD4 count of 139 cells/µL, altered sensorium, and a positive India ink preparation of CSF points toward Cryptococcus neoformans, a common cause of opportunistic meningitis in immunocompromised individuals. Clinical Features of Cryptococcosis Respiratory System Cryptococcus typically enters the body via inhalation and can cause pulmonary infection / pneumonitis - primary site of infection Patients may present with cough, pleuritic chest pain, and respiratory distress. Imaging shows a solitary pulmonary nodule Dissemination of pulmonary infection leads to the involvement of other organs Central Nervous System Meningitis: Characterized by severe headaches, fever, altered mental status, sensory and memory loss, cranial nerve paresis and loss of vision It is the most serious type of cryptococcal infection Skin Cutaneous Cryptococcosis: Causes skin lesions, particularly in immunocompromised patients. Associated with C.neoformans var neoformans (serotype D) Other Organs Liver, spleen, and bones maybe involved in disseminated infections Diagnosis of Cryptococcosis Microscopy India ink: Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans Culture Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies. ... (content truncated) Antigen detection tests Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutination test Treatment Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine Maintenance Therapy with Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status. Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes. Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk.

questions.question: Which of the following microorganisms is likely responsible for causing bilateral infiltrates in an HIV-positive patient?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Pneumocystis Jiroveci infection:   In AIDS-positive patients with CD count less than 200 with perihilar infiltrates, nonproductive 4 cough (7-10 days):Pneumocystis Jiroveci   In the later part of the illness,Chest X ray shows bilateral perihilar diffuse infiltrates Incorrect Options: Option A, B, D:   Cryptococcus, Histoplasmosis and Aspergillus infection are not associated with bilateral peri hilar infiltrates

questions.question: A person came with the H/o thorn prick a week ago. A few days later, he developed ulcers along lymphatic drainage. Choose the correct organism.
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Sporothrix schenckii Explanation: The patient’s history of a thorn prick followed by ulcerative lesions along lymphatic drainage suggests sporotrichosis, a subcutaneous fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii. Sporotrichosis Causative agent Dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii. Epidemiology Common in gardeners, forest workers, and manual labourers. Route of Transmission Minor trauma or thorn prick. Clinical features Chronic infection affects cutaneous, subcutaneous, and lymphatic tissue. Lesions form at sites of minor trauma or thorn pricks, starting as nodules. ... Coccidioides immitis (Option A) causes valley fever (coccidioidomycosis), primarily a respiratory illness, not associated with lymphatic ulcer spread. Aspergillus flavus (Option B) causes invasive aspergillosis, primarily affecting immunocompromised individuals. It does not cause lymphatic ulcers following trauma. Instead, it is associated with lung infections and aflatoxin production (hepatotoxicity). Trichophyton rubrum (Option D) is a dermatophyte that causes superficial fungal infections such as tinea, onychomycosis, and athlete’s foot, not deep tissue involvement with lymphatic spread.

questions.question: Which among the following is a subcutaneous fungal agent ?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Sporothrix Schenckii:   Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that causes sporotrichosis, a subcutaneous fungal infection. Sporotrichosis typically presents as nodules or ulcers along the lymphatic channels and is commonly acquired through traumatic inoculation of the fungus, such as by thorns or splinters. Incorrect Options: Option A - Cryptococcus Neoformans: Cryptococcus neoformans is a fungal pathogen primarily associated with respiratory and central nervous system infections in immunocompromised individuals. It is classified as an opportunistic infection. Option B - Histoplasma Capsulatum: It is a dimorphic fungus that causes histoplasmosis. Histoplasmosis is an intracellular infection of the reticuloendothelial system. It is classified under systemic mycoses. Option D - Talaromyces Marneffei: It is a dimorphic fungus that causes opportunistic infections in an individual infected with AIDS. It causes a disseminated infection with multiple organ involvement. It is classified as an opportunistic infection.

questions.solution: Correct Option D - Histoplasma Capsulatum:   Dimorphic fungi exist as molds in the environment at 25°C and as yeasts in human tissues at 37°C.   Several medically important fungi are thermally dimorphic, such as: Histoplasma capsulatum Blastomyces dermatitidis Coccidioides immitis Paracoccidioides brasiliensis Penicillium marneffei Sporothrix schenckii. questions.question: Which of the following conditions cannot be diagnosed using the β 1-3 glucan assay?
questions.solution: Correct Option D - Mucormycosis:   β-1,3-D Glucan is a polysaccharide cell wall component of fungi. Beta 1,3 D glucan assay is commonly used for diagnosis of Candida and Aspergillus. Other organisms showing positive β -1,3-D Glucan assay are Pneumocystis jirrovecii pneumonia, Histoplasma, Fusarium, Scedosparium, and dermatophytes. Organisms with negative β-1,3-D Glucan assay are Cryptococcus, mucorales (rhizopus and mucor), and Blastomyces dermatitidis. questions.question: A truck driver with diabetes visits you complaining of cough and difficulty breathing. Pneumonia has been diagnosed, and histopathological examination indicates the presence of nonseptate hyphae branching at wide angles, as demonstrated below. What is the probable cause of this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Mucor:   The histopathological finding showing aseptate hyphae branching at wide angles and suggests a fungal infection with the order Mucorales.   The most common genus of Mucorales causing infection is Rhizopus, but the presence of diabetes and the clinical presentation of pneumonia suggests that the causative agent is more likely to be Mucor.   The aseptate hyphae of mucor branches at an angle of 90° or more and have a broad ribbon shape.   Mucor infections are known as Zygomycosis, and they can cause a range of infections, including pneumonia, sinusitis, and cutaneous infections.   Mucorales are opportunistic fungi that cause disease in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with poorly controlled diabetes. Incorrect Options: Option A - Cryptococcus neoformans: Cryptococcus neoformans is a capsulated yeast that causes cryptococcal meningitis in immunocompromised individuals. Option C - Candida: Candida is a genus of yeasts that can cause a range of infections involving skin, mucosa, and organs. Option D - Aspergillus: Aspergillosis is caused by aspergillus, a septate fungi branching at less than 45°, commonly seen in patients on prolonged steroid use.

questions.question: A COVID patient presented with fever, nasal congestion, and unilateral headache. Later, he developed facial pain and numbness, along with blackish lesion. On SDA, cotton wooly growth is seen. H&E staining shows non-septate hyphae at the right angle/obtuse angle. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Mucormycosis:   The most probable diagnosis based on the given symptoms, findings, and H&E staining is Mucormycosis caused by mucor.   Mucormycosis is predominant in COVID-19 patients because of the usage of steroids presenting with a black lesion.   Mucor on SDA agar shows cotton wooly growth, giving an appearance of salt &pepper.   Mucor shows aseptate hyphae branching at 90° or an obtuse angle (>90°) on H&E staining. Incorrect Options: Option A - Aspergillosis: Aspergillosis is a fungal infection caused by Aspergillus. Aspergillus is a septate fungus showing acute angle (< 45°.) dichotomous branching. It is commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals presenting with aspergilloma in pre-existing cavitary lesions (tuberculosis) in the lung, allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA). The growth on the SDA agar is species-dependent, A. fumigatus (smoky-green colony), A. niger (Black colonies), A. flavus (yellow-green colonies). Option B - Bacterial orbital cellulitis: Bacterial orbital cellulitis is a bacterial infection that affects the soft tissues surrounding the eye. It can cause symptoms such as fever, nasal congestion, and facial pain. It will not show hyphae and SDA agar is not used for the culture. Option D - Cavernous sinus thrombosis: Cavernous sinus thrombosis is a rare condition characterized by the formation of a blood clot within the cavernous sinus, a large vein at the base of the skull. It can cause symptoms such as headache with or without vomiting, papilledema, and visual problems, focal deficits, seizures, stupor, or coma.

questions.question: Which of the following is the probable cause in a case of tinea capitis where white powdery colonies were obtained from the hair specimen and the hair perforation test was positive on the isolate?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Trichophyton Mentagrophytes:   Tinea capitis is a scalp infection characterized by scaly patches produced on the scalp, in which hair shafts are broken off right above the skin caused by Trichophyton spp, and some Microsporum spp.. The positive hair perforation test and white powder colonies obtained in culture from the specimen of hair is suggestive of Trichophyton mentagrophytes as a causative organism.   Hair perforation test is positive only for T. mentagrophytes and M. canis.   Macroscopic appearance of other trichophyton species are: Dermatophytes Macroscopic appearance on culture T. rubrum Velvety, red pigment on reverse T. mentagrophytes White to tan powdery and waxy T. schoenleinii Smooth, waxy T. violaceum Slow-growing, waxy Violet pigment on reverse Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.question: Which of the subsequent microorganisms leads to illness after being introduced into the skin through trauma?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Sporothrix Schenckii:   The organism that commonly causes disease following traumatic inoculation into the skin is Sporothrix schenckii.   Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that causes a condition known as sporotrichosis or rose gardener's disease.   It is found in soil and vegetation, particularly in environments associated with decaying plant matter.   Traumatic inoculation occurs when the fungus enters the skin through thorns, splinters, or other puncture wounds, leading to localized infections. Incorrect Options: Option B - Blastomyces Dermatitidis: Blastomyces dermatitidis is the causative agent of blastomycosis. While it primarily affects the lungs through inhalation of spores, it is not commonly associated with traumatic inoculation. Option C - Coccidioides Immitis: Coccidioides immitis is responsible for causing coccidioidomycosis or Valley fever. It is primarily acquired through inhalation of fungal spores from contaminated soil, rather than traumatic inoculation. Option D - Paracoccidioides Brasiliensis: Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is the causative agent of paracoccidioidomycosis, a systemic fungal infection. It is typically acquired through inhalation of fungal spores and is not commonly associated with traumatic inoculation.

questions.question: A 54-year-old farmer from Ohio presents to a physician with a chronic cough. A chest x-ray demonstrates a cavitary lesion with hilar lymphadenopathy. Biopsy of the lymph node and staining with lactophenol cotton blue demonstrates the following characteristics as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Histoplasmosis:   The clinical presentation of cough, lymphadenopathy, cavitary lesion, and biopsy of a lymph node shows tuberculate macroconidia, which is a mold form of the fungus, as shown in the image, is suggestive of pulmonary histoplasmosis, also known as Cave's disease/Ohio disease, Mississippi disease & darling disease.   Histoplasmosis is an intracellular infection of the reticuloendothelial system caused by the thermally dimorphic fungus Histoplasma capsulatum associated with farmers and individuals who are exposed to bird or bat droppings   It presents with a mild flu-like illness and pulmonary infiltrates in the chest X-ray with hilar or mediastinal lymphadenopathy. Incorrect Options: Option B - Coccidioidomycosis: It is also known as Valley fever and is caused by the fungus Coccidioides immitis or Coccidioides posadasii. Pulmonary coccidioidomycosis presents with pneumonia, cavities, pleural effusion, or nodule formation. On microscopic examination, barrel-shaped arthrospores are characteristic of the infection. Option C - Cryptococcus: It is a yeast-like fungus that can cause pulmonary infections, particularly in individuals with compromised immune systems. Halo around the organism on negative staining is characteristic of this fungus. Option D - Blastomycosis: It is caused by the fungus Blastomyces dermatitidis and is commonly found in regions with moist soil, such as the Mississippi and Ohio River valleys. While it can cause lung involvement, mycelial form containing hyphae with small pear-shaped conidia are characteristic of this fungi.

questions.question: A chronic asthmatic patient who is on inhaled steroids presents with a history of burning sensation on eating hot or spicy food, and the following findings are seen. What is the most possible diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Candidiasis:   The most possible diagnosis in this case is oral thrush, aka oropharyngeal candidiasis.   Immunocompromised states (on steroid or immunosuppressive drugs, post-transplantation, malignancy, HIV-infected people) are predisposed to candida infection.   Oral thrush is a common finding seen in patients suffering from Candida albicans. It is characterized by the presence of a white, adherent, painless patch in the oral cavity, as shown in the image. Incorrect Options: Option B - Burning mouth syndrome: Burning mouth syndrome is a condition characterized by a burning or scalding sensation in the mouth, often without any visible abnormalities. It is not typically associated with white patches or lesions. Option C - Geographical tongue: Geographical tongue, also known as benign migratory glossitis, is a benign chronic relapsing recurring inflammatory condition of the oral cavity of unknown etiology. Option D - Oral lichen planus: Oral lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory condition that can affect the oral mucosa and skin. It is seen clinically as reticular, papular, plaque-like, erosive, atrophic, or bullous types.

questions.question: A patient presents with a mobile, warm-to-touch nodule in the neck. The anaerobic culture of the biopsy material from this swelling showed colonies, as shown in the image, which had gram-positive branching rods on staining. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Penicillin:   Actinomyces israelii is an anaerobic bacteria that are normally present in the mouth, intestine, and vagina and is responsible for causing actinomycosis.   A. israelii, when culture on solid media (brain-heart infusion agar), produces small 'spidery colonies' in 48-72 hours that become heaped up, white, and irregular or smooth, large colonies in 10 days, as shown in the image. Penicillin is the drug of choice to treat the infection. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are not the drug of choice for treating actinomyces infection.

questions.question: The below slide represents a gomori methenamine silver stained slide with acute angle branching and septate hyphae. What is the organism?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Aspergillus:   Aspergillus when stained with GMS stain shows acute angle dichotomous branching (<45°, two branches) with septate hyphae. Incorrect Options: Option A- Blastomycosis: On GMS stain shows a black outline with a classic figure of 8 appearance. Option B- Candida: Under microscope shows both buds and pseudohyphae Option D- Mucor: Is the opposite of Aspergillus, shows obtuse angle branching and aseptate hyphae.

questions.question: A 24-year-old woman presents with hypopigmented macules and confluent patches over the chest. Skin scraping and KOH preparation show an abundance of yeast-like cells and short branch filaments like a ‘Spaghetti and meatball appearance’ as shown in the image below. What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Malassezia:   The clinical presentation and KOH mount is sugggestive of Pytriasis versicolor caused by malassezia furufur.   It is a chronic recurrent condition involving the superficial layer (stratum corneum) of the skin characterized by flat-round scaly patches of hypo- to hyperpigmentation of the skin in areas rich in sebaceous glands commonly involved, such as the neck, chest, or upper arms.   Malassezia is recognized by the detection of characteristic unipolar budding yeasts and accompanied by short hyphae, thus the so-called spaghetti and meatballs appearance.   Other manifestation of malassezia are dermatitis, seborrheic dermatitis, and Malassezia folliculitis. Incorrect Options: Option B - Trichophyton: Trichophyton is a genus of fungi, which includes the parasitic varieties that cause tinea, including athlete's foot, ringworm, jock itch, and similar infections of the nail, beard, skin, and scalp. Trichophyton is white and cottony on the surface, and the underside is usually red. Microscopically pencil-shaped or cigar-shaped macronidia are sen. Option C - Chlamydospores: Chlamydospores are produced by candida and represent enlarged, thick-walled vegetative cells with varied forms and condensed cytoplasm that forms within hyphae or at hyphal tips. Chlamydospores cause diseases like Aspergillosis, Blastomycosis, Coccidioidomycosis, and Histoplasmosis. Option D - Candida: Candida is normally found in mouth, skin, and intestines. In immunocompromised individuals they are repsonsible for causing candidiasis including vaginal yeast infection, diaper rash, and oral thrush. On miscroscpic examination it reveals pseudihyphae.

questions.question: Which of the following medium can be utilized to determine the probable species of the causative agent in a female patient presenting with symptoms of thick curdy white vaginal secretions and microscopic examination of vaginal scraping shows budding yeast and pseudohyphae?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - CHROM Agar:   Thick white vaginal secretions and microscopic examination showing pseudohyphae and yeast-like organisms are suggestive candidiasis.   CHROM agar is a differential medium that can differentiate between different species of Candida based on their ability to metabolize specific sugars.   Candida albicans, the most common cause of candidiasis, produces colonies that are typically pink or purple on CHROM agar, while other species of Candida produce different-colored colonies.   After incubation for 1–4 days on CHROMagar, colonies of C. albicans are green C. tropicalis is blue C. glabrata is dark purple C. parapsilosis, C. lusitaniae, C. guilliermondii, and C. krusei acquire a pinkish hue.
