Incorrect Options: Option A - Bird seed Agar: It is a selective medium used to grow Cryptococcus neoformans, a fungus that causes cryptococcosis, a potentially fatal infection of the central nervous system. Option B - Brain Heart Infusion Agar: Brain heart infusion agar is a nutrient-rich medium used to grow fastidious microorganisms like Bacteroides and actinomyces israelii. Option D - Sabouraud Dextrose Agar: Sabouraud dextrose agar is a general-purpose medium used to grow a variety of fungi. While it is commonly used to isolate Candida species, it is not differential and cannot differentiate between different species of Candida.

questions.question: A patient with cervical lymphadenopathy and is found to be retropositive. A fungal culture depicts a velvety growth with red diffusible pigment on the underside, as shown below. Which is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Talaromyces Marneffei:   Talaromyces marneffei is a dimorphic fungus causing an opportunistic infection characterized by fever, weight loss, dyspnea, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and warty lesions mimicking that of molluscum contagiosum.   When grown on culture media, the mold forms a red diffusible pigment, as shown in the image. Incorrect Options: Option B - Blastomyces: Blastomyces is a dimorphic fungus that typically causes pulmonary most commonly and verrucous or ulcerative type of skin lesions, and osteomyelitis. It is characterized by the figure of 8 appearance on staining. Option C - Aspergillus: Aspergillus is a common fungal pathogen that typically causes invasive pulmonary disease in immunocompromised patients. When grown on SDA, agar colonies have a velvety to powdery surface and are characteristically colored: A.fumigatus - dark green, A.niger - black, and A.flavus-yellow-green. Option D - Pneumocystis Jirovecii: Pneumocystis jirovecii is a fungal organism that commonly causes pneumonia in immunocompromised patients, but it does not grow in culture and is not associated with cervical lymphadenopathy or red diffusible pigment.

questions.question: A farmer presents with a swollen foot and multiple sinuses as shown in the below image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Mycetoma:   The swollen foot and multiple discharging sinuses are highly suggestive of Mycetoma aka madura foot.   Mycetoma is a chronic granulomatous infection of the subcutaneous tissues and bones that can cause a swollen foot and multiple sinuses.   It is of two types Eumycetoma is caused by fungi such as Madurella mycetomatis. Actinomycetoma caused by Actinomadura, Nocardia, and streptomyces.   Eumycetoma is caused by fungi such as Madurella mycetomatis.   Actinomycetoma caused by Actinomadura, Nocardia, and streptomyces.   Eumycetoma is caused by fungi such as Madurella mycetomatis.   Actinomycetoma caused by Actinomadura, Nocardia, and streptomyces. Incorrect Options: Option B - Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma is a type of malignant skin cancer that usually appears as a firm, red nodule or a flat lesion with a scaly, crusty surface. Option C - Nocardia: Nocardia is a type of bacteria that can cause cutaneous infections like actinomycetoma immunocompetent and involves the lungs and brain in immunocompromised individuals. Option D - Sporotrichosis: Sporotrichosis is a fungal infection that usually affects the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It can cause nodules, ulcers, and lymphangitis.

questions.question: What is the most probable diagnosis for a farmer who has a wart-like skin growth on his foot and histopathology of the growth is shown in the below image?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Chromoblastomycosis:   The histopathological image shows a characteristic "copper penny" appearance of sclerotic bodies, and warty growth on the foot of a farmer is consistent with the diagnosis of chromoblastomycosis, aka verrucous dermatitis (cauliflower-like wart).   Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic fungal infection caused by dematiaceous pigmented fungi Phialophora verrucosa, Fonsecaea pedrosoi, commonly affecting the skin of the feet and legs of farmers and agricultural workers. Incorrect Options: Option A - Sporotrichosis: Sporotrichosis is a subcutaneous fungal infection caused by the dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii. It typically presents as a painless nodule or ulcer at the site of inoculation, which can progress to form a chain of subcutaneous nodules or abscesses along lymphatic channels. Histopathological examination shows suppurative granulomas with asteroid bodies. Option B - Mycetoma: Mycetoma is a chronic bacterial or fungal infection that typically affects the subcutaneous tissue of the feet or hands. It presents as a painless swelling of the sinus tract with multiple discharging sinuses and granules. Option D - Phaeohyphomycosis: It is a rare fungal infection caused by dematiaceous fungi such as Exophiala and Cladophialophora, which can affect various tissues, including the skin and subcutaneous tissue but do not form sclerotic bodies.

questions.question: Which of the following dimorphic fungi causes subcutaneous mycosis?
questions.solution: Correct option A - Sporothrix Schenckii:   Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that causes chronic infection of the cutaneous, subcutaneous, and lymphatic tissue. It is frequently encountered in gardeners after a prick of a thorn of a plant which becomes the port of entry for the fungus. Incorrect Options: Option B - Histoplasma Capsulatum: It is a dimorphic fungus that causes histoplasmosis. Histoplasmosis is an intracellular infection of the reticuloendothelial system. It is classified under systemic mycoses. Option C - Blastomyces Dermatitidis: It is a dimorphic fungus that causes blastomycosis. Blastomycosis is a suppurative and granulomatous condition that is predominantly present in the lungs. It is classified under systemic mycoses. Option D - Penicillium Marneffei: It is a dimorphic fungus that causes opportunistic infections in an individual infected with AIDS. It causes a disseminated infection with multiple organ involvement. It is classified as an opportunistic infection.

questions.question: A patient presented with complaints of persistent dry cough, fever, and weight loss. He was diagnosed as HIV positive 6 months back and is poorly adherent to his medications. Gomori methamine silver staining of BAL reveals a crushed ping pong ball appearance. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Option D - Pneumocystis Jirovecii:   Pneumocystis jirovecii is a fungal organism that commonly causes Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia (PCP) in immunocompromised individuals, including those with HIV infection.   It presents with persistent dry cough, fever, and weight loss.   Gomori methenamine silver staining of the bronchoalveolar lavage shows a black crushed ping-pong appearance against the green background. Incorrect Options: Option A - Paracoccidioides Brasiliensis: Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is a dimorphic fungus that causes paracoccidioidomycosis, a systemic fungal infection. It typically presents with respiratory symptoms such as cough, fever, skin and mucosal lesions and cervical lymphadenoapthy.Histopathology staining reveals Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance. Option B - Histoplasma Capsulatum: Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus that causes histoplasmosis, an infection primarily affecting the lungs. On gomori methenamine silver staining of the specimens (sputum) reveals tiny oval yeast cells with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response. Option C - Coccidioides Immitis: Coccidioides immitis is a dimorphic fungus that causes coccidioidomycosis, commonly known as Valley fever. While respiratory symptoms and weight loss can occur in coccidioidomycosis, the Gomori methamine silver staining specimens demonstrates spherules which are large sac like structures, have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

questions.question: Identify the pathognomonic structure in the slide given below.
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Sclerotic Body:   This is a micrograph of chromoblastomycosis caused by Phialophora verrucosa and Fonsecaea pedrosoi, showing the sclerotic bodies aka copper penny bodies, or muriform bodies.   The fungi produce thick-walled, single, or multicellular clusters called sclerotic or muriform bodies. There is remarkable pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia of the epidermis. Incorrect Options: Option B - Budding Yeast: Budding yeast is Saccharomyces cerevisiae, which forms a bud from the mother cell during reproduction. Option C - Negri Body: Negri bodies are pathognomonic inclusion bodies, eosinophilic, found in the cytoplasm of nerve cells in patients affected with the rabies virus. Option D - Asteroid Body: Asteroid bodies are found in sporotrichosis and sarcoidosis; these are extracellular eosinophilic bodies and are located within abscesses.

questions.question: A forest worker developed skin lesions over the forearm, which initially started as macules but then became nodules. Histology of the nodule shows the following findings. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

options.A: Infection does not involve underlying fascia, tendons and muscle
options.B: Infection can spread and involve underlying subcutaneous tissue, tendon, muscle or
options.C: Angioinvasion can occur in patients of hematological malignancies
options.D: These bodies are fungi engulfed by macrophages

questions.solution: Correct Option A - Infection does not involve underlying fascia, tendons, and muscle:   A forest worker has a history of trauma while working in the forest, which then appears as macules and later on becomes nodules, causing a Verrucous lesion (a warty lesion on the skin) and the image revealing pathognomonic finding of Medlar bodies/sclerotic bodies is suggestive of chromoblastomycosis caused by dematiaceous fungi like Fonsecaea pedrosi, F.compacta, and exophiala.   The infection manifests only as a cutaneous or subcutaneous infection and does not involve deeper structures, such as tendons, muscles, fascia, and osteoarticular sites. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect. These statements are incorrect about chromoblastomycosis.

questions.question: The cell wall depicted below is most likely to belong to which of the following organisms?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Aspergillus Fumigatus:   Aspergillus fumigatus is a fungus which differ from bacteria by having rigid cell walls containing chitin, mannan and polysaccharides. Cytoplasmic membrane contains sterols. Incorrect Options: Option B - Mycobacterium Tuberculosis: M. tuberculosis is an acid fast bacilli, cell wall is made up of peptidoglycan (murein layer), arabinogalactan layer, mycolic acid layer and outer peptidoglycolipids layer. Option C - Mycoplasma Pneumoniae: Mycoplasmas have no cell walls, and they are placed in a separate class known as Mollicutes. Option D - Rhinosporidum Seeberi: Rhinosporidium seeberi is an aquatic protist, which do not have rigid cell wall, on biopsy and shows endospores typical of fungus, but it is not a fungus as it is not cultured on SDA.

questions.question: A man has undergone renal transplant and is taking immunosuppressant drug. On biopsy there was presence of budding cells with pseudohyphae. Identify the organism?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Candida:   Immunosuppressant drugs are commonly prescribed to prevent organ rejection after transplantation and treat autoimmune diseases like rheumatoid arthritis or lupus. These drugs can weaken the immune response, reducing the body's ability to fight off infections.   Candidiasis can manifest as oral thrush (white patches in the mouth and throat), vaginal yeast infections, or invasive candidiasis affecting the bloodstream, organs, or other body sites.   In Candida, the bud remains attached to the mother cell, elongates, and undergoes repeated budding to form chains of elongated cells known as pseudohyphae. Incorrect Options: Option B - Aspergillus: Aspergillus has a filamentous growth form consisting of acute branching dichotomous hyphae. Hyphae are thin, thread-like structures that make up the fungal body. Option C - Pneumocystis Jirovecii: Pneumocystis primarily affects individuals with weakened immune systems and causes pneumonia-like symptoms. Microscopy shows crushed ping pong ball appearance. Option D - Histoplasma Capsulatum: Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus showing both hyphal and yeast forms, causing Histoplasmosis, which is an intracellular infection of the reticuloendothelial system.

questions.question: A 35-year-old HIV-positive patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Oral Candidiasis:   The likely diagnosis for a 35-year-old HIV-positive patient with mucosal lesions in the mouth and the presence of budding yeasts and pseudohyphae on microscopy is oral candidiasis.   Oral candidiasis, also known as oral thrush, is a fungal infection caused by the overgrowth of Candida species, particularly Candida albicans, in the oral cavity.   It is common in individuals with compromised immune systems, such as those with HIV/AIDS.   Microscopic examination of a sample from the mucosal lesions would reveal the presence of budding yeasts (small circular structures) and pseudohyphae (elongated structures with constrictions or constrictions between the budding cells). This characteristic appearance confirms the diagnosis of oral candidiasis. Incorrect Options: Option B - Hairy Leukoplakia: Hairy leukoplakia is a condition caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and is commonly seen in individuals with HIV infection. It presents as white, corrugated lesions on the lateral borders of the tongue. Option C - Lichen Planus: Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory condition that can affect the skin and mucous membranes, including the mouth. It typically presents as white, lacy patches or plaques. Option D - Diphtheria: Diphtheria is a bacterial infection caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. It primarily affects the throat and can lead to the formation of grayish-white pseudomembranes.

questions.question: Which medication is preferred for treating invasive pulmonary aspergillosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Voriconazole:   The drug of choice for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis is Voriconazole.   Voriconazole exhibits potent antifungal activity, good tissue penetration, and a broad spectrum of activity against various Aspergillus species.   Voriconazole, a second-generation triazole antifungal agent, inhibits ergosterol synthesis by inhibiting cytochrome P 450, which is essential for fungal cell membrane integrity. Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are incorrect. These are not the drugs of choice to treat invasive aspergillosis.

questions.question: A man presents with the following lesion after traumatic inoculation. Identify the causative organism.
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Sporothrix Schenckii:   Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that causes a condition known as sporotrichosis or rose gardener's disease. It is commonly found in soil and vegetation and can infect humans and animals through traumatic introduction into the skin, such as via thorns or splinters.   Sporotrichosis typically presents as a localized skin infection characterized by a painless, nodular lesion that can ulcerate and progress along lymphatic channels as shown in the image.   These lesions or bumps are pink or purple and often appear on the finger or hand. The infection can spread to other parts of the body through the lymphatic system. Incorrect Options: Option A - Mycobacterium Scrofulaceum: Mycobacterium scrofulaceum is a nontuberculous mycobacterium and is not commonly associated with traumatic skin lesions. Option C - Madurella Mycetomatis: Madurella mycetomatis is a fungus that causes a chronic granulomatous infection known as mycetoma, characterized by swelling and draining sinuses, typically affecting the extremities. Option D - Phialophora Verrucosa: Phialophora verrucosa is a dematiaceous fungus associated with chromoblastomycosis, a chronic subcutaneous fungal infection characterized by slowly developing granulomatous lesions.

questions.question: Which one of these options is classified as a dematiaceous fungus?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Cladosporium:   The term dematiaceous refers to the presence of melanin, which gives these fungi characteristic dark coloration.   Cladosporium is melanin-producing fungi. Hence, it is a dematiaceous fungus.   Cladosporium is a common environmental mold found in soil, plants, and decaying organic matter. It is one of the recognized fungal agents that can cause chromoblastomycosis.   Other dematiaceous fungi are P. verrucosa, F. pedrosoi, Fonsecaea compacta, and Rhinocladiella aquaspersa. Incorrect Options: Option A - Mucor Species: Mucor species belong to the group of zygomycetes; it is not dematiaceous fungi. Option B - Aspergillus Niger: Aspergillus niger is an ascomycete fungus known to cause aspergillosis. Option C - Blastomyces Dermatitidis: Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungus known to cause the disease blastomycosis.

questions.question: A patient presented with fever, dyspnea, palpitations, and tachycardia. The echocardiography revealed vegetation in the septal leaflets. Tissue sections from them reveal the following findings as shown in the image. What is the most likely implicated agent?

options.A: Pigmented septate hyphae at 90 degrees, Mucormycosis
options.B: Right angle branching septate hyphae, Fusarium
options.D: Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

questions.solution: Correct Option D - Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus:   The clinical presentation of fever, dyspnea, palpitations, and tachycardia, along with echocardiographic findings of vegetation in the septal leaflets, suggests infective endocarditis.   The histopathological findings show uniform, dichotomous branching at acute angles and septate hyphae of Aspergillus in tissue stained with Gomori methenamine silver is consistent with Aspergillus.   Aspergillus can manifest as cardiac aspergillosis manifesting as endocarditis and percarditis. Incorrect Options: Option A - Pigmented septate hyphae at 90 degrees, Mucormycosis: Mucormycosis is caused by mucor, characterized by aseptate hyphae branching at 90° or more than 90° and is not associated with endocarditis. Option B - Right angle branching septate hyphae, Fusarium: Fusarium is a filamentous characterized by hyaline septate hyphae bearing round microconidia, sickle-shaped large macroconidia, and chlamydospores fungi. It is more commonly associated with endophthalmitis and keratitis. Option C - Acute angle branching hyphae, Rhizopus: Rhizopus is characterized by broad aseptate hyphae, from which sporangiophore arises and then ends at sporangium, and root-like growth from hyphae called rhizoid. It commonly manifests as Rhino-oculo-cerebral disease or may involve the lungs.

questions.question: The following test is positive for identification of …………….
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Candida Albicans:   The given image shows the positive germ tube test, aka Reynolds Braude phenomenon.   The germ tube test is a laboratory diagnostic test used to identify Candida albicans. This test is based on the ability of Candida albicans to produce germ tubes, which are elongated outgrowths from yeast cells when mixed with human serum and incubated for 2 hours.   Another species of candida which shows a positive germ tube test is C. dubliniensis. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect. These species of candida do not show positive germ tube tests.

questions.question: A patient presented with wart-like lesions on exposed areas of the skin, such as the legs or forearms. Histopathology of the wart revealed findings as shown in the image. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Option B - Chromoblastomycosis:   The histopathological image shows a characteristic "copper penny" appearance of sclerotic bodies, and warty growth on the foot is consistent with the diagnosis of chromoblastomycosis, aka verrucous dermatitis (cauliflower-like wart).   Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic fungal infection caused by dematiaceous pigmented fungi Phialophora verrucosa, Fonsecaea pedrosoi, commonly affecting the skin of the feet and legs of farmers and agricultural workers. Incorrect Options: Option A - Histoplasmosis: Histoplasmosis is caused by dimorphic fungus Histoplasma capsulatum. It is characterized by tuberculate macronidia on LPCB (Lactophenol cotton blue) wet mount and commonly affects respiratory symptoms (Tuberculosis like clinical features are seen). Option C - Coccidioidomycosis: Coccidioidomycosis is caused by the fungus Coccidioides immitis or Coccidioides posadasii. The microscopic examination typically shows barrel-shaped arthrospores on LPCB. Option D - Candida Albicans: Candida albicans is a yeast-like fungus that can cause various types of infections, including oral thrush and vaginal yeast infections. On microscopic examination, it shows pseudohyphae.

questions.question: Stain used to demonstrate fungal elements are?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Methenamine Silver:   Gomori methenamine silver stain is commonly used to visualize fungal elements in histopathological specimens. It stains the fungal hyphae in black color, allowing for their identification under a microscope. Incorrect Options: Option A - Acid-Fast Stain: It is used to detect acid-fast bacteria such as Mycobacterium species and coccidian parasites, not fungal elements. Option B - Gabbet's Stain: It is also known as kinyoun stain, used for demonstrating the coccidian parasites (isosopora, cyclospora, and cryptosporidium). Option D - Leifson & Ryu's Stain: This stain is used to demonstrate the flagella.

questions.question: A previously healthy 15-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with fever, severe headache, vomiting, and rapidly progressing confusion. He was diagnosed with meningitis, and his parents report he recently went swimming during a camping trip. Despite treatment, his condition worsens rapidly. Which of the following organisms is most likely causing this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Naegleria fowleri Explanation: The clinical history described is most likely suggestive of primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM), which is caused by Naegleria fowleri. Naegleria fowleri: Naegleria is a free-living amoeba commonly found in warm freshwater environments. In nature, it exists in two forms: cysts and trophozoites.   Cyst: Round   Trophozoite: Can occur in two forms – amoeboid and flagellated forms. Life cycle:   Infective form: Trophozoite.   Mode of transmission: Nasal contamination occurs during swimming in fresh, hot water bodies like ponds, rivers, swimming pools, or lakes.   CNS invasion: Invades nasal mucosa → Cribriform plate → Olfactory nerve → Brain → Primary Amoebic Meningoencephalitis. Primary Amoebic Meningoencephalitis   Causative organism: Naegleria fowleri   Occurs in healthy children or young adults with a recent history of swimming in fresh, hot water.   Initial symptoms include altered taste and smell (due to involvement of the olfactory nerve), followed by nausea, vomiting, high fever, and meningeal signs such as a stiff neck and positive Kernig’s sign.   Secondary symptoms include confusion, hallucinations, lack of attention, ataxia, and seizures.   Death occurs within 7–14 days after exposure.   Diagnosis: CSF analysis: Thick, purulent CSF with pus cells, elevated protein and reduced sugar level (mimic bacterial meningitis). CSF microscopy: Detection of characteristic trophozoites in CSF (confirmatory). Culture: NNA (Non-Nutrient Agar) - lawn cultured with Escherichia coli. questions.question: A 28-year-old male returns to his rural village after spending time in a forested area known for sandfly infestations. He presents to the clinic with a painless ulcer on his forearm that has gradually increased in size over the past month, as shown in the image below. The ulcer has raised, indurated borders and a necrotic base. The patient has no fever or systemic symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Cutaneous leishmaniasis: Most commonly caused by L.Tropica. Mode of transmission:   The most common mode of infection is through the bite of sandflies.   Infection may be transmitted from man to man or animal to man by direct inoculation or amastigotes. Incubation period: The incubation period varies from 2 to 8 months. Pathology:   Amastigote forms are found in histiocytes and endothelial cells.   There is an inflammatory granulomatous reaction with infiltration of lymphocyte and plasma cells.   Early lesions are papular, followed by ulceration necrosis. Papules and ulcers are the main pathological lesions. They heal over months to years, leaving scars. Clinical features: L. tropica causes old-world cutaneous leishmaniasis. Three distinct patterns of old-world CL have been recognised.   Causing painless dry ulcerating lesions, leading to disfiguring scars. The most important vector is P. sergenti. - It is seen mainly in children in endemic areas and is called as oriental sore or Delhi boil.   Causes moist ulcers which are inflamed, often multiple, caused by L. major.   Lesions due to L. major heal more rapidly than L. tropica. P. papatasi is the most important vector.   The nonulcerative and often diffuse lesions caused by L. aethiopica Laboratory diagnosis:   Microscopy: Smear is made from the material obtained from the indurated edge of nodule or sore and stained by Giemsa or Leishman stain.   Amastigotes are found in large numbers inside the macrophages.   A definitive diagnosis is made by demonstrating amastigote in the smear collected from the lesion.   Culture: Promastigote forms can be isolated by culture of the aspirate material in NNN medium.   Montenegro skin test (MST) Treatment:   The specific treatment of CL is the same as VL.   Antimony-resistant diffuse CL can be treated with pentamidine.   Topical treatment consists of a paste of 10% charcoal in sulfuric acid or liquid nitrogen. Mucocutaneous Leishmaniasis (Option B) :   Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis is a more severe form of leishmaniasis that usually follows cutaneous leishmaniasis.   L. braziliensis complex causes both mucocutaneous leishmaniasis (espundia) and "CL''.   It involves the nose, mouth and larynx.   The patient experiences a nodule at the site of the sand fly bite with symptoms consistent with oriental sore.   Subsequent mucocutaneous involvement leads to nodules inside the nose, perforation of the nasal septum, and enlargement of the nose and lips (espundia)   The absence of any mucosal involvement in this patient, along with the focus on skin ulcers, suggests that this is not the correct diagnosis. Leishmaniasis Recidivans (Option C) :   Leishmaniasis recidivans is a type of lesion seen in persons with a high degree of cell-mediated immunity to the parasite.   The lesions are chronic with alternating periods of activity and healing, characterised by a central scar with peripheral activity.   The lesions resemble those of lupus or tuberculoid leprosy.   Parasites are very scanty in the lesions.   The Leishmanin test is strongly positive.   Chemotherapy is not very useful.   Better results follow the local application of heat.   However, in this case, the patient presents with an acute, new ulcer rather than a recurrence of a previous lesion, making this option less likely. Tuberculous Ulcer (Option D): A tuberculous ulcer is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis and usually presents as a chronic, painless ulcer, which may occur in patients with systemic tuberculosis. While it can present similarly to cutaneous leishmaniasis, the clinical history (recent travel to an endemic area and the appearance of the ulcer) strongly supports a diagnosis of cutaneous leishmaniasis rather than a tuberculous ulcer.

questions.question: A 30-year-old female, previously treated for visceral leishmaniasis six months ago, now presents with multiple erythematous, hypopigmented, slightly scaly papules and plaques on her face, neck, and arms. The lesions are painless, gradually increasing in number, and there are no associated systemic symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis is a non ulcerative lesion of the skin seen in India, Nepal, Bangladesh and Sudan. The lesions are of three types: Diagnosis of post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis:   The nodular lesions are biopsied, and amastigote forms are demonstrated in stained sections.   The biopsy material can be cultured, or animal inoculation can be done.   Immunodiagnosis has no role in the diagnosis of PKDL. Treatment of post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis:   Liposomal amphotericin-8 (AmBisome) 2.5 mg/ kg/ day for 20 days or   sodium stibogluconate (SSG) 20 mg/ kg/day for 40- 60 days is given. Leprosy (Option B) : Leprosy, caused by Mycobacterium leprae, presents with skin lesions, peripheral nerve damage, and is characterized by numbness and weakness. Although some skin manifestations can resemble those of PKDL, the systemic symptoms and characteristic nerve involvement help differentiate it. Cutaneous Leishmaniasis (Option C): Cutaneous leishmaniasis presents with ulcerative lesions or nodules, typically following a sandfly bite. Unlike PKDL, these lesions do not usually appear months to years after visceral leishmaniasis treatment and are associated with the presence of Leishmania parasites in the skin. Psoriasis (Option D): Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition characterised by red, scaly patches and is often itchy. While it can present with similar erythematous plaques, the patient's history of recent visceral leishmaniasis and the specific characteristics of her lesions (hypopigmented and non-itchy) make psoriasis an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

questions.question: A 10-year-old male with a three-month history of fever, weight loss, fatigue, night sweats, and abdominal distention, along with splenomegaly, anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia, recently returned from rural India, where he was exposed to the vector given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: The given image of the vector is a sandfly. The patient has a persistent fever, significant weight loss, splenomegaly, anaemia, and leukopenia, and has a history of exposure in an endemic area with exposure to sandflies, making Kala Azar the most likely diagnosis, also known as Visceral leishmaniasis. Clinical features of kala-azar:   Onset: Insidious.   The clinical illness begins with high-grade fever which may be remittent with twice daily spikes or intermittent or less commonly continuous.   Night sweats   Splenomegaly starts early and is progressive and massive. It is usually soft and nontender.   Hepatomegaly is moderate.   Lymphadenopathy is common in most endemic areas except the Indian subcontinent.   Skin becomes dry, rough and darkly pigmented (hence, the name kala-azar).   The hair becomes thin and brittle.   Cachexia with marked anaemia, emaciation and weight loss is seen.   Hematological abnormalities: Anemia is most always present and is usually severe leukopenia , thrombocytopenia is associated with epistaxis, gum bleeding, gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding. questions.question: What is the infective form of Leishmania donovani?
questions.solution: Promastigote is the infective form of Leishmania donovani.   A female sandfly (e.g., Phlebotomus, Lutzomyia) bites an infected mammal and ingests blood containing amastigotes.   Inside the sandfly’s midgut, amastigotes transform into promastigotes, which multiply and migrate to the proboscis.   When the sandfly bites a new host, it injects the infective promastigotes.   Promastigotes are engulfed by macrophages and transform into amastigotes, which are non-flagellated and replicate intracellularly.   Amastigotes multiply within macrophages, causing cell lysis and releasing new amastigotes to infect other macrophages.   If an uninfected sandfly bites the infected host, it ingests amastigotes, and the cycle continues.

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman with a travel history to South America presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, mild chest pain, and palpitations. She reports a history of fever, malaise, and swelling around her right eye 11 months ago, which resolved spontaneously. On examination, her heart rate is irregular, and she has mild cardiomegaly on chest X-ray. Which treatment options are most appropriate for her at this stage?
questions.solution: This patient's presentation is consistent with chronic Chagas disease, caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi. The history of fever and eyelid swelling points to a possible acute phase of the infection, while her current symptoms of fatigue, chest pain, palpitations, and cardiomegaly are typical complications of chronic Chagas disease. Benznidazole is one of the two mainstays of treatment for Chagas disease. It is effective in both the acute and chronic phases, particularly when cardiac symptoms are present. Early treatment can help reduce the risk of progression to severe cardiac disease and complications. The recommended treatment duration is typically 60 days. Nifurtimox (Option B) is another option for treating Chagas disease, but it is often associated with more significant side effects, including gastrointestinal issues and neurotoxicity. It is reserved for cases where benznidazole is contraindicated or not tolerated. Supportive care and monitoring (Option C): While essential for managing symptoms and potential complications of Chagas disease (such as arrhythmias), this approach does not address the underlying infection. Antiarrhythmic medications only (Option D) can help manage the arrhythmias associated with Chagas-related cardiomyopathy, E.g., beta-blockers and digoxin. Supportive treatment such as pacemakers to manage arrhythmias and surgery for correction of megaesophagus and megacolon may be useful.

questions.question: A 50-year-old man presents with persistent fatigue, chest pain, and difficulty breathing. He grew up in rural northern Argentina, where a childhood bug bite caused left eye swelling. Examination reveals leg swelling, an S3 gallop, and fatigue. IgG antibodies to Trypanosoma cruzi are detected by ELIS
questions.solution: The clinical presentation with cardiac involvement leading to fatigue, difficulty breathing, and Trypanosoma cruzi antibody detection in the peripheral blood is consistent with a chronic form of Chagas disease. Chagas disease is caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, transmitted by triatomine bugs. Chagas’ disease occurs in four stages. 1. Early Stage Disease: It is characterised by cutaneous and ocular manifestations   Chagoma: a painful subcutaneous nodule at the site of deposition of bug’s faeces, commonly seen on the face.   Romana’s sign: It causes unilateral painless oedema of the eyelid and conjunctivitis. 2. Acute Chagas’ disease:   About 1% of patients, progress to acute-stage disease, characterised by fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy (Statement 5) 3. Indeterminate stage:   It is the asymptomatic phase; lasting for years to decades, before progressing into the symptomatic chronic stage 4. Chronic Chagas’ disease:   The parasite multiples in the muscles (cardiac and GIT) and nervous tissue, producing various types of manifestations.   Cardiac form: Occurs in 30% of the patients. The patient develops dilated cardiomyopathy, rhythm disturbances and thromboembolism.   Gastrointestinal form: Megaesophagus and megacolon.   Autoimmune hypothesis: T. cruzi antigens cross-react with mammalian antigens (molecular mimicry), producing autoantibodies that may be responsible for tissue injury seen in chronic Chagas’ disease Treatment of Chagas disease   Therapy for Chagas’ disease is still unsatisfactory.   In acute disease, Benznidazole is the drug of choice in Latin America. Nifurtimox or allopurinol is given alternatively.   In chronic disease, these drugs lack efficacy and may cause many side effects. Supportive treatment, such as pacemakers to manage arrhythmias and surgery to correct megaesophagus and megacolon, may be useful (Statement 2). In acute Chagas disease, the trypomastigotes are frequently found in peripheral blood, which can be detected by:   Wet mount preparation   Thick and thin smear examination. Antibody detection: Chronic Chagas disease is diagnosed by detecting specific IgG antibodies using ELISA, Western blot and Chagas RIPA (radioimmunoprecipitation assay) (Statement 4).

questions.question: What is the drug of choice to treat Colpitis macularis caused by Trichomonas vaginalis?
questions.solution: Strawberry appearance of vaginal mucosa or cervix (Colpitis macularis) is observed in 2% of patients with Trichomoniasis. It is characterised by small punctate hemorrhagic spots on vaginal or cervical mucosa. Metronidazole or tinidazole is the drug of choice for Trichomonas vaginalis.   Standard therapy: 2 g, single dose is usually effective.   Both sexual partners must be treated simultaneously to prevent reinfection, especially asymptomatic males.   Resistance to metronidazole is rare but reported (2.5-10%). If the standard therapy fails (with 5-day therapy), consider repeating the treatment course. Trichomoniasis can be prevented by:   Treatment of both sexual partners.   Safe sex practices like the use of condoms.   Avoidance of sex with an infected person.

questions.question: A 40-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a high fever, chills, and dark-coloured urine. He recently returned from a trip to a malaria-endemic region in West Africa and self-treated with antimalarial medication. On examination, he is febrile (39.5°C), tachycardic, and has jaundice. Laboratory investigations show: Hemoglobin: 8 g/dL LDH: Elevated Urinalysis: Dark brown urine, positive for haemoglobin. Total Bilirubin: 4 mg/dL (direct: 1 mg/dL, indirect: 3 mg/dL) Which of the following best explains the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Blackwater fever is a severe form of malaria primarily associated with Plasmodium falciparum infection; it commonly occurs in patients with repeated malaria infections or inadequate treatment with quinine.   It is characterised by hemoglobinuria (dark-coloured urine), severe hemolytic anaemia, and jaundice.   It results from the severe hemolysis of red blood cells, which releases free haemoglobin into the bloodstream and its subsequent excretion in the urine. questions.question: A 30-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with a history of malaria treated six months prior. questions.solution: Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale are the two species capable of causing malaria relapses. questions.question: A 28-year-old woman presents with a very high fever, chills, and shivering after returning from a tropical region. Laboratory tests confirm infection with a Plasmodium species. It is noted that infected red blood cells adhere to the endothelium of blood vessels. In which species of Plasmodium is this phenomenon primarily observed?
questions.solution: Plasmodium falciparum is the primary species associated with cytoadherence, where infected red blood cells adhere to endothelial cells in blood vessels. This leads to complications like cerebral malaria due to vessel blockage and reduced blood flow. Pathogenesis of Malignant Malaria: Cytoadherence:   In Plasmodium falciparum malaria, late-stage schizonts secrete proteins that create knob-like protrusions on the surfaces of infected RBCs. This results in the expression of the adhesive protein PfEMP-1 (P. falciparum Erythrocyte Membrane Protein), which makes the infected RBCs sticky.   Inflammatory cytokines, particularly IFN-γ, enhance the expression of endothelial receptors such as thrombospondin, E-selectin, VCAM-1, and ICAM-1 in the brain, chondroitin sulfate B in the placenta, and CD36 in most other organs. These receptors promote the cytoadherence of infected RBCs to the endothelium, leading to blockage of capillaries and venules. questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with liver imaging that reveals a cystic mass with an invasive, infiltrative growth pattern spreading into surrounding tissues. Serology confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following species is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) E. multilocularis Explanation: E. multilocularis is responsible for alveolar echinococcosis, known for its invasive, infiltrative growth pattern that lacks a well-defined capsule, allowing the infection to spread similarly to malignant tumors, especially within the liver. Echinococcus multilocularis Echinococcus multilocularis is a parasitic tapeworm causing alveolar echinococcosis (AE) in humans. It primarily infects the liver, forming tumour-like lesions that can infiltrate surrounding tissues and spread to other organs. Epidemiology: Found in Europe, Asia, and North America, with rural residents in contact with foxes or dogs at higher risk. Pathology:   Multiloculated, invasive liver cysts lacking a true capsule, resembling malignant tumors.   It also affects the lungs, spleen, and brain by metastasis. Life Cycle:   Definitive hosts: Foxes, dogs, and other canids host adult worms in their intestines, shedding eggs in feces.   Intermediate hosts: Rodents ingest eggs, which hatch, migrate to the liver, and form multilocular cysts.   Accidental hosts (humans): Humans ingest eggs from contaminated sources, with larvae forming invasive cysts primarily in the liver. Clinical presentation:   It is often asymptomatic initially but can progress to symptoms like abdominal pain, jaundice, and hepatomegaly.   If untreated, the disease may spread to other organs, such as the lungs, brain, and bones. Investigations: Imaging:   Ultrasound: Detects irregular liver cysts.   CT/MRI: Defines extent and spread of cysts. Serology: ELISA/Immunoblot: Detect antibodies against E. multilocularis. Histopathology: Confirms the presence of larval elements when a biopsy is performed. Management: Surgery:   Radical Resection: Preferred for curative treatment.   Liver Transplantation: Considered for extensive, unresectable disease. Pharmacotherapy: Albendazole: The main drug used, often requiring prolonged or lifelong treatment. E. oligarthrus (Option D): E. oligarthrus is a rare cause of polycystic formations in humans, primarily affecting animals, and does not display the invasive growth pattern seen with E. multilocularis.

Cysticercosis Infection direct consumption of T. solium eggs via contaminated food Caused by the larval stage (cysticercus cellulosae) of Taenia solium. Pathology Can affect any organ or tissue, with the most common sites being subcutaneous tissues and muscles. Other affected areas include Eyes and the brain Less often, heart, liver, lungs, abdominal cavity and spinal cord. Cysticercus is surrounded by a fibrous capsule except in the eye and brain ventricles. The larvae trigger a cellular reaction, initially involving neutrophils, eosinophils, lymphocytes, plasma cells, and occasionally giant cells. This reaction leads to fibrosis, death of the larva, and eventual calcification. Clinical Featur es ... Cutaneous amoebiasis (Option B) typically presents with painful, foul-smelling ulcers and is associated with dysenteric diarrhea and liver abscesses. The absence of these symptoms and the specific microscopy findings in this case make cutaneous amoebiasis unlikely. Cutaneous leishmaniasis (Option C) is caused by protozoan parasites of the Leishmania genus, transmitted by sandflies, and typically presents as a painless lesion that evolves into a chronic ulcer. The absence of such lesions, along with the patient's history of consuming undercooked pork and the specific microscopy findings, make cutaneous leishmaniasis unlikely. Cutaneous larva migrans (Option D) is caused by hookworms such as Ancylostoma braziliense or Ancylostoma caninum, entering the skin, presenting as a small reddish papule that progresses to a serpiginous, pruritic rash. The absence of this characteristic rash and the patient’s history of consuming undercooked pork make cutaneous larva migrans unlikely.

questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Simulium Explanation: The clinical presentation suggests onchocerciasis, also known as "river blindness," which is caused by the parasite Onchocerca volvulus. This disease is transmitted by the Simulium fly, commonly known as the blackfly, which breeds in fast-flowing rivers and streams, consistent with the patient's recent camping near a river. Onchocerca volvulus Onchocerca volvulus is a parasitic nematode responsible for onchocerciasis, also known as " river blindness." It primarily affects the skin and eyes, leading to severe itching, disfigurement, and potential blindness. Transmission: Simulium blackflies, commonly found near fast-flowing rivers and streams. Morphology Adult Worms: Long and thin; males are around 3–5 cm, while females are significantly larger, reaching up to 50 cm. Both sexes have a cuticle with annular grooves. Microfilariae: Small, thread-like, measuring around 220–250 µm in length. They lack a sheath and migrate mainly to the skin and eyes. Life Cycle Presentation Skin: Severe itching, dermatitis, and skin depigmentation ("leopard skin"). Chronic cases may show skin thickening and loss of elasticity. Eyes: Microfilariae in the eye leads to punctate keratitis, sclerosing keratitis, chorioretinitis, and eventual blindness ("river blindness"). Nodules: Subcutaneous nodules (onchocercomas) often form over bony prominences. Investigations   Skin snip: A small sample of skin is examined microscopically to detect microfilariae.   Mazzotti test: An oral dose of diethylcarbamazine (DEC) causes a pruritic reaction in the affected skin, but due to severe side effects, it’s rarely used now.   Serology: ELISA and rapid antibody tests can aid in diagnosis, especially in non-endemic areas.   Slit-Lamp Examination: For detecting microfilariae in the cornea and anterior chamber of the eye. Management Ivermectin:   Primary treatment.   Kills microfilariae and reduces symptoms, though it does not kill adult worms.   Administered every 6-12 months to control infection spread and symptoms. Doxycycline:   Targets Wolbachia, an endosymbiotic bacteria essential for the survival of adult worms, which helps reduce microfilariae production.

Symptoms: painful blisters with erythema, fever, nausea, pruritus; common sites include lower leg, ankle, foot. Secondary bacterial infections possible at blister sites. Laboratory Diagnosis Detection of Adult Worm: Identify female worms in blisters; X-ray for calcified worms. Detection of L1 Larvae: Microscopic examination after placing the leg in cold water. Treatment Worm Removal: Gentle extraction over 15-20 days with a stick; avoid heavy pressure. Symptomatic Treatment: Wet compresses, analgesics, topical antibiotics; no known effective anti-helminthic drugs. questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Muscle biopsy Explanation: Presentation of fever, myalgia, periorbital swelling, and a history of consuming undercooked pork, which raises suspicion for trichinellosis (caused by the parasite Trichinella spiralis). Muscle biopsy is the most definitive test for confirming trichinellosis. A muscle biopsy can reveal the presence of encysted Trichinella larvae within muscle tissues. This method provides direct evidence of the infection and is particularly helpful in cases where serological tests are inconclusive. Investigations and Management of Trichinella spiralis Investigations and Tests:   Serology (Option A): ELISA and Western blot tests, which detect specific antibodies against the parasite's antigens. These tests typically yield positive results by the second week of infection. However, they may not be definitive, especially in the early stages, as antibodies can take time to develop, leading to false negatives.   Muscle Biopsy:   If serology is inconclusive, a biopsy can reveal encysted larvae in muscle tissue. This method provides direct evidence of the infection and is particularly helpful in cases where serological tests are inconclusive.   Sites of biopsy: deltoid, gastrocnemius, and biceps.   Bachman Intradermal Test: This historical diagnostic skin test was used to identify trichinellosis by detecting a delayed hypersensitivity reaction (Type IV hypersensitivity). Management Antiparasitic therapy: Albendazole or Mebendazole. Stool examination for ova and parasites (Option B): Trichinella spiralis larvae do not mature in the intestines to produce eggs that can be found in stool samples. Complete blood count with differential (Option D): Although a complete blood count may show eosinophilia, which can occur in parasitic infections, it is not a definitive test for diagnosing trichinellosis.

questions.solution: Correct Answer: D) Trichinellosis Explanation: Trichinellosis, or trichinosis, is an infection caused by the Trichinella spiralis, typically contracted from eating undercooked pork containing the larvae. Symptoms include muscle pain, fever, and periorbital edema, resulting from the larvae migrating into muscle tissues. Trichinella spiralis Trichinella spiralis is a parasitic roundworm responsible for trichinellosis (or trichinosis), an infection contracted through eating undercooked or raw meat containing infective larvae, primarily pork. Transmission: Acquired by eating contaminated meat with Trichinella cysts. Morphology   Adult Worms: Small, thread-like worms in the intestines of the host.   Larvae and Nurse Cells: Larvae encapsulate in muscle fibers, forming specialized nurse cells that support larval survival within muscle tissue. Life Cycle   Ingestion: Infection begins when undercooked meat with cysts is eaten.   Larval Release and Intestinal Phase: Stomach acids release larvae from cysts. These larvae then invade the intestinal lining, where they mature and reproduce.   Migration Phase: Female worms release new larvae that enter the bloodstream, spreading to striated muscles, where they encyst.   Encystment and Muscle Phase: Larvae mature within muscle tissue, becoming infective in 2-3 weeks, and can persist for months or years in muscle fibers. Clinical Presentation   Intestinal Phase (Initial Symptoms): 1-2 days post-ingestion, gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain may occur.   Muscle Phase: Symptoms include fever, muscle pain (especially in the neck and calves), periorbital edema (swelling around the eyes), and generalized weakness. Severe cases may result in myocarditis, encephalitis, or respiratory distress as larvae migrate to the heart, brain, or diaphragm.   Late Phase: Chronic inflammation in muscles may lead to long-lasting pain, weakness, and muscle dysfunction as larvae encapsulate and eventually die. Leptospirosis (Option A): Usually presents with muscle pain and fever but is often associated with exposure to contaminated water, not undercooked meat. Toxoplasmosis (Option B): This infection typically presents with mild flu-like symptoms or lymphadenopathy and lacks the periorbital swelling and muscle involvement seen here. Taeniasis (Option C): Caused by Taenia tapeworms, this infection is more likely to present with gastrointestinal symptoms rather than muscle pain and periorbital edema.

questions.solution: Correct Answer: C) Ivermectin Explanation:   Ivermectin is the treatment of choice for Strongyloides stercoralis infection, even in mild or asymptomatic cases, to prevent potential complications.   Mechanism of action: It causes hyperpolarisation by enhancing chloride influx by targeting GABA receptors resulting in paralysis of the worm. Pathogenesis and Clinical Features of Strongyloides Stercoralis Infection Effect of Migrating Larvae Asymptomatic Infection: Over 50% may be asymptomatic. Rashes: Recurrent maculopapular or urticarial rashes on buttocks, perineum, and thighs. Cutaneous Larva Migrans: Serpiginous rash (larva currens) advancing up to 10 cm/hour. Pulmonary Symptoms: Rare, mainly in chronic obstructive lung disease. Effects of Adult Worms & Filariform Larvae Mild to Moderate Load: Epigastric pain, nausea, diarrhea, constipation, and blood loss. Heavy Larval Load: Risk of hyperinfection syndrome and disseminated strongyloidiasis. Hyperinfection Syndrome Cause: Repeated autoinfection leads to increased filariform larvae. Risk Factors: Glucocorticoid therapy, immunosuppressive conditions, HTLV-1/HIV coinfection. Features: Colitis, enteritis, malabsorption, possible progression to disseminated strongyloidiasis. Disseminated Strongyloidiasis Pathophysiology: Larvae invade GIT and other organs. Disrupted mucosa may allow enteric flora to cause bacterial sepsis, pneumonia, or meningitis. Clinical Manifestations: CNS invasion, brain abscesses, meningitis; larvae in CSF. Eosinophilia, often absent in severe cases. Mortality Rate: Nearing 100% untreated; over 25% even with treatment. Laboratory Diagnosis Stool Microscopy: Rhabditiform larvae; requires multiple samples (4+) for accurate diagnosis. Microscopy of Other Specimens: Entero-test for duodenal aspirates; high filariform larvae are found in stool, sputum, and tissue biopsies for disseminated cases. Stool Culture: Differentiates rhabditiform from hookworm larvae. Serology: ELISA for antibodies; may show cross-reactivity, less effective for recent infections. Coproantigen Detection: Antigen capture ELISA specific to Strongyloides. Molecular Diagnosis: Real-time PCR targeting specific genes. Treatment Asymptomatic Treatment: Strongyloidiasis should be treated regardless of symptoms due to the risk of hyperinfection. Ivermectin (200 mg/kg daily for 2 days) (Option C) Albendazole and mebendazole (Option A & B) are not effective against Strongyloides stercoralis, a tissue nematode, as they primarily target intestinal nematodes. Praziquantel (Option D) Is indicated for trematode infections (flukes) and schistosomiasis but ineffective for Strongyloides stercoralis.

questions.question: A 35-year-old man presents with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhea, and significant weight loss over the past month. He recently traveled to a rural area where he ingested aquatic plants while swimming in a freshwater lake. On examination, he exhibits pallor and mild abdominal tenderness. A stool examination reveals the presence of eggs. Considering his symptoms and recent travel history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: B) Skin penetration by filariform larvae. Explanation: The scenario indicates an infection with Strongyloides stercoralis, characterized by the patient’s chronic cough, wheezing, abdominal pain, and the presence of rhabditiform larvae in the stool. Humans are infected when filariform (L3) larvae penetrate the skin, often through barefootcontact with contaminated soil. After entering the bloodstream, these larvae migrate to the lungs,are swallowed, and eventually reach the gastrointestinal tract, where they mature. Strongyloides Stercoralis (Threadworm) Morphology Smallest nematode known to cause human infection. Forms: Exists in three forms: adult worms, larvae (4 stages), & eggs. Adult Worm: Only females inhabit the human small intestine (2–3 mm long). Males are free-living in the environment. Eggs: Ovoviviparous, hatch into larvae immediately upon laying. (Option A) Life Cycle Hosts: Primarily humans; occasionally domestic pets act as reservoirs. Infective Form: L3 (filariform) larva. ... (content truncated) Phases of Infection Migratory Phase: L3 larvae enter subcutaneous venules, reach lungs via venous circulation, migrate to alveolar spaces, ascend to the pharynx, and are swallowed to enter the GIT. Intestinal Phase: L3 larvae mature into adult females in the small intestine mucosa (males are absent in humans). Female worms lay eggs through parthenogenesis, & rhabditiform (L1) (Option C & D) larvae hatch & are either excreted in feces or mature to L3 for autoinfection. Autoinfection & Chronicity L1 larvae in the intestine can transform into L3 larvae within the host, penetrate the intestinal wall or perianal skin, enter circulation, and migrate to the lungs. This can sustain infection for up to 30–40 years and may lead to disseminated disease. Environmental Development Direct Development: L1 larvae molt to L3 in moist, warm soil, becoming directly infective to humans (common in temperate climates). Indirect Development: L1 larvae molt into adults (both sexes) in tropical climates. These adults reproduce, producing eggs that hatch into L1 larvae, which then develop into infective L3 larvae.

questions.question: A 35-year-old female with a long-standing history of fever presents with discoloration of the skin over the lower limb and edema. Microscopy reveals a sheathed organism with no nuclei at the tip of the tail. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Option A - Wuchereria bancrofti:   Wuchereria bancrofti is the organism responsible for causing lymphatic filariasis. The characteristic finding on microscopy for Wuchereria bancrofti is a sheathed microfilaria with no nuclei at the tip of the tail. Incorrect Options: Option B - Brugia malayi: Brugia malayi’s microfilariae have two nuclei that extend to the tip of the tail. Option C - Loa Loa: The microfilariae of Loa Loa are sheathed, but the nuclei form a continuous row at the tip of the tail. Option D - Mansonelia: The microfilariae of Mansonelia are unsheathed and extend to the tip of the tail.

questions.question: Which of the following is a xenodiagnostic method ?

options.A: Rabbit ileal loop assay for ETEC
options.B: Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue
options.C: Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis
options.D: Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria

questions.solution: Correct Option B - Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue:   In the Xenodiagnostic method, arthropod vectors are fed on infected patients for 2-4 weeks, after which the vectors are examined for parasite presence.   It involves injecting the thorax of Aedes mosquitoes (the vector for dengue virus) with blood from a patient suspected to have dengue. The mosquitoes are then observed for viral replication and transmission, which can help confirm the diagnosis. Incorrect Options: Option A - Rabbit ileal loop assay for ETEC: It is not a xenodiagnostic method as it does not involve the use of a vector and the organism is being detected for the disease is bacteria. Option C - Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis: This is not a xenodiagnostic method as the vector for leishmaniasis is sandfly. Option D - Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria: This is not a xenodiagnostic method as it does not involve the use of a vector, and the organism is being detected for the disease is bacteria.

questions.question: Which of the following is/are an advantage(s) of a saline mount compared to an iodine mount? Motility of trophozoites Internal structure of cysts Differentiate bile stained vs non bile stained
questions.solution: Correct Option B- 1 and 3: Motility of Trophozoites:   Advantage of Saline Mount: Saline mounts are suitable for observing the motility of trophozoites (the active, motile form of some protozoa). In Iodine mount - trophozoites are immobilized. Internal Structure of Cysts:   Advantage of Iodine Mount: Iodine mounts are often preferred for the examination of internal structures, including the nuclear and cytoplasmic details of cysts. Iodine enhances the contrast and visibility of internal features. Differentiation Between Bile-Stained and Non-Bile-Stained:   Advantage of Saline Mount: In iodine mounts, both bile- stained and non-bile-stained helminthic ova are stained brown.

questions.question: A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of frequent diarrhea, abdominal cramps, bloating, and weight loss over the past two weeks. She mentions that she recently traveled to a rural area for a camping trip and drank untreated stream water during her stay. On physical examination, no fever is noted, but mild tenderness is present in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Stool examination reveals the presence of trophozoites and cysts with characteristic " falling leaf" motility under microscopy. Which organism is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution: Correct Option C - Giardia lamblia   Giardia lamblia is a protozoan parasite that commonly causes gastrointestinal symptoms such as diarrhea, abdominal cramps, bloating, and weight loss. The "falling leaf" motility pattern is a classic finding seen in Giardia infections. This motility pattern is due to the unique flagella arrangement of Giardia trophozoites. The fact that the patient drank untreated stream water during her camping trip makes Giardia infection a likely culprit, as it is transmitted via contaminated water sources. Incorrect Options: Option A - Salmonella typhi: Salmonella typhi is a bacterium that causes typhoid fever. It typically presents with fever, abdominal pain, headache, and constipation rather than diarrhea. The symptoms described in the scenario, including frequent diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and " falling leaf" motility in the stool, are not characteristic of Salmonella typhi infection. Option B - Entamoeba histolytica: Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite that causes amoebic dysentery. While it can lead to diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss, the "falling leaf" motility is not a characteristic finding for Entamoeba histolytica. Additionally, there is no mention of bloody diarrhea or the presence of colonic ulcers, which are often associated with this infection. Option D - Cryptosporidium parvum: Cryptosporidium parvum is another protozoan parasite that causes diarrhea. However, the symptoms of cryptosporidiosis are generally more severe in immunocompromised individuals. The stool examination findings in cryptosporidiosis typically reveal oocysts, which are not described as "falling leaf" motility.

questions.question: Choose the wrong statement about Plasmodium species:

options.B: Presence of duffy blood group antigen is protective against vivax
options.C: Severe malaria with shock is called algid malaria
options.D: Relapse is seen in P. ovale

questions.solution: Correct Option B - Presence of duffy blood group antigen is protective against vivax:   The invasion of red cells by merozoites requires specific glycoprotein receptors, i.e., Duffy blood group antigen, to invade red blood cells. Individuals who lack this antigen are generally resistant to P. vivax infection, while those who have it are susceptible to the parasite. Incorrect Options: Option A - Drug-resistant falciparum is seen in India: Drug-resistant Plasmodium falciparum, the most virulent species of malaria, is indeed seen in India. Option C - Severe malaria with shock is called algid malaria: Algid malaria is characterized by peripheral circulatory failure, rapid thready pulse with low blood pressure, and cold, clammy skin. There may be severe abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and profound shock. Option D - Relapse is seen in P. Ovale: Relapse is a unique characteristic of Plasmodium ovale and vivax infection. After the initial infection is treated, the parasite can remain dormant in the liver and cause relapses of malaria symptoms months or even years later.

Formol-ether sedimentation is a commonly used technique for concentrating parasites and ova from stool samples when the egg burden is low. In this technique, the stool sample is mixed with a formalin-ether solution. It takes advantage of the high specific gravity of protozoan cysts and helminth eggs compared to water.
